Maximum Likelihood Estimation in Gaussian Process Regression is Ill-Posed

\nameToni Karvonen \emailtoni.karvonen@helsinki.fi
\addrDepartment of Mathematics and Statistics
University of Helsinki
PL 56 (Pietari Kalmin katu 5)
00014 Helsingin yliopisto, Finland \AND\nameChris J.Â Oates \emailchris.oates@ncl.ac.uk
\addrSchool of Mathematics, Statistics and Physics
Newcastle University
Newcastle upon Tyne, NE1 7RU, United Kingdom
Abstract

Gaussian process regression underpins countless academic and industrial applications of machine learning and statistics, with maximum likelihood estimation routinely used to select appropriate parameters for the covariance kernel. However, it remains an open problem to establish the circumstances in which maximum likelihood estimation is well-posed, that is, when the predictions of the regression model are insensitive to small perturbations of the data. This article identifies scenarios where the maximum likelihood estimator fails to be well-posed, in that the predictive distributions are not Lipschitz in the data with respect to the Hellinger distance. These failure cases occur in the noiseless data setting, for any Gaussian process with a stationary covariance function whose lengthscale parameter is estimated using maximum likelihood. Although the failure of maximum likelihood estimation is part of Gaussian process folklore, these rigorous theoretical results appear to be the first of their kind. The implication of these negative results is that well-posedness may need to be assessed post-hoc, on a case-by-case basis, when maximum likelihood estimation is used to train a Gaussian process model.

Keywords: Gaussian processes, maximum likelihood estimation, ill-posedness, stationary kernels

1 Introduction

Gaussian process regression is a popular tool used to construct a predictive model for a response variable as a function of one or more covariates of interest. As a strict generalisation of classical linear regression, and with the support of production-level software, Gaussian process regression has found myriad applications in both the academic and industrial contexts. The success of Gaussian process regression, both in terms of predictive performance and quality of uncertainty quantification, is contingent on the use of a suitable covariance kernelÂ Kğ¾K for the Gaussian process model. This is often achieved by choosing Kğ¾K from a parametric setÂ {KÎ¸}Î¸âˆˆÎ˜subscriptsubscriptğ¾ğœƒğœƒÎ˜\{K_{\theta}\}_{\theta\in\Theta} of candidate covariance kernels, with the parameter Î¸âˆˆÎ˜ğœƒÎ˜\theta\in\Theta being selected based on the training data set. The predictive performance of Gaussian processes is well-understood in a variety of asymptotic settingsÂ (e.g., Stein, 1999; Anderes, 2010; vanÂ der Vaart and van Zanten, 2011; Bachoc etÂ al., 2017; Karvonen etÂ al., 2020). However, not much is known about the non-asymptotic setting whenÂ Î¸ğœƒ\theta is estimated from a training data set. In particular, it is an open problem to understand when the predictions from a Gaussian process model are well-posed, in the sense that the predictions of the model are either continuous in the training data set or insensitive to small perturbations of the training data set. Theoretical understanding of well-posedness is urgently needed to support the use of Gaussian process regression in sensitive applications, such as in mine gas safety monitoringÂ (Dong, 2012), malicious maritime activity detectionÂ (Kowalska and Peel, 2012), and climate modellingÂ (Revell etÂ al., 2018), where the reliability and robustness of predictions is critical.

Several methods exist to estimate Î¸ğœƒ\theta, including maximum likelihood estimation (Mardia and Marshall, 1984), maximum a posteriori estimation (e.g., Cunningham etÂ al., 2008), cross-validation (Geisser and Eddy, 1979), Bayesian inference (MacKay, 1992), kernel flows (Chen etÂ al., 2021), and various bespoke approaches, for example when Î¸ğœƒ\theta are the parameters of a neural network in a deep kernelÂ (Wilson etÂ al., 2016). Among these, maximum likelihood estimators Î¸MLsubscriptğœƒML\theta_{\textup{ML}} are arguably most widely used, for example being the default approach in Gaussian process software (Rasmussen and Nickisch, 2010; Pedregosa etÂ al., 2011; Roustant etÂ al., 2012; GPy, since 2012; Matthews etÂ al., 2017). In addition to statistics and machine learning, maximum likelihood is also occasionally used in the applied mathematical literature to construct a kernel interpolant; see Fasshauer and McCourt (2015, SectionÂ 14.3) and Cavoretto (2021) for recent examples. Compared to other approaches, maximum likelihood is attractive due to the absence of any additional degrees of freedom (e.g., cross-validation requires a choice for how data are partitioned) and the possibility for automatic gradient-based optimisation.

Suppose that the data are modelled as being generated by a Gaussian process defined by a mean function mğ‘šm and a positive-definite covariance kernel KÎ¸subscriptğ¾ğœƒK_{\theta}. For a noiseless training data set Y=(y1,â€¦,yn)âˆˆâ„nğ‘Œsubscriptğ‘¦1â€¦subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘›superscriptâ„ğ‘›Y=(y_{1},\ldots,y_{n})\in\mathbb{R}^{n}, associated to a set Xğ‘‹X of distinct covariates x1,â€¦,xnâˆˆâ„dsubscriptğ‘¥1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›superscriptâ„ğ‘‘x_{1},\ldots,x_{n}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, a maximum likelihood estimator Î¸MLsubscriptğœƒML\theta_{\textup{ML}} of Î¸ğœƒ\theta satisfies

Î¸MLâˆˆargâ€‹minÎ¸âˆˆÎ˜â¡â„“â€‹(Î¸âˆ£Y)â€‹Â withÂ â€‹â„“â€‹(Î¸âˆ£Y)=Ymğ–³â€‹KÎ¸â€‹(X,X)âˆ’1â€‹Ym+logâ€‹detKÎ¸â€‹(X,X),subscriptğœƒMLsubscriptargminğœƒÎ˜â„“conditionalğœƒğ‘ŒÂ withÂ â„“conditionalğœƒğ‘Œsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘šğ–³subscriptğ¾ğœƒsuperscriptğ‘‹ğ‘‹1subscriptğ‘Œğ‘šsubscriptğ¾ğœƒğ‘‹ğ‘‹\theta_{\textup{ML}}\in\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{\theta\in\Theta}\ell(\theta\mid Y)\>\>\text{ with }\>\>\ell(\theta\mid Y)=Y_{m}^{\mathsf{T}}K_{\theta}(X,X)^{-1}Y_{m}+\log\det K_{\theta}(X,X), (1.1)

where KÎ¸â€‹(X,X)=(KÎ¸â€‹(xi,xj))i,j=1nâˆˆâ„nÃ—nsubscriptğ¾ğœƒğ‘‹ğ‘‹superscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ¾ğœƒsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—ğ‘–ğ‘—1ğ‘›superscriptâ„ğ‘›ğ‘›K_{\theta}(X,X)=(K_{\theta}(x_{i},x_{j}))_{i,j=1}^{n}\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times n} is the positive-definite covariance matrix and Ym=(yiâˆ’mâ€‹(xi))i=1nâˆˆâ„nsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘–1ğ‘›superscriptâ„ğ‘›Y_{m}=(y_{i}-m(x_{i}))_{i=1}^{n}\in\mathbb{R}^{n}. See Stein (1999, SectionÂ 6.4) or Rasmussen and Williams (2006, SectionÂ 5.4.1). Despite the simple form of the optimisation problemÂ (1.1), there is only limited understanding of the behaviour of Î¸MLsubscriptğœƒML\theta_{\textup{ML}} in the deterministic interpolation regime, where the data yi=fâ€‹(xi)subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–ğ‘“subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–y_{i}=f(x_{i}) are, in truth, generated from a fixed but unknown function f:â„dâ†’â„:ğ‘“â†’superscriptâ„ğ‘‘â„f\colon\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R}. An important open problem is to understand the behaviour of Î¸MLsubscriptğœƒML\theta_{\textup{ML}} in terms of the data-generating function fğ‘“f and the set of covariates, and the implications of this behaviour for predictions produced by the Gaussian process model.

The deterministic interpolation regime represents a simple but important instance of Gaussian process regression widely used in, for example, emulation of computer experimentsÂ (Sacks etÂ al., 1989; Kennedy and Oâ€™Hagan, 2002), probabilistic numerical computationÂ (Diaconis, 1988; Cockayne etÂ al., 2019; Hennig etÂ al., 2022), and Bayesian optimisationÂ (Snoek etÂ al., 2012). However, this regime is challenging to analyse, and results concerning maximum likelihood estimation appear limited to the asymptotic analyses. Xu and Stein (2017); Karvonen etÂ al. (2020); and Wang (2021) exploited a closed form for the maximum likelihood estimator of a scale parameter (i.e., Î¸={Ïƒ}ğœƒğœ\theta=\{\sigma\} and KÎ¸=Ïƒ2â€‹Ksubscriptğ¾ğœƒsuperscriptğœ2ğ¾K_{\theta}=\sigma^{2}K) to analyse its behaviour as nâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘›n\to\infty in the fixed domain setting where the covariates {xi}i=1âˆsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘–1\{x_{i}\}_{i=1}^{\infty} are dense in a compact subset of â„dsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbb{R}^{d}. In a similar manner, Karvonen etÂ al. (2019) analysed maximum likelihood estimation of the scale and lengthscale parameters (i.e., Î¸={Ïƒ,Î»}ğœƒğœğœ†\theta=\{\sigma,\lambda\} and KÎ¸â€‹(x,xâ€²)=Ïƒ2â€‹Kâ€‹(x/Î»,xâ€²/Î»)subscriptğ¾ğœƒğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¥â€²superscriptğœ2ğ¾ğ‘¥ğœ†superscriptğ‘¥â€²ğœ†K_{\theta}(x,x^{\prime})=\sigma^{2}K(x/\lambda,x^{\prime}/\lambda)) for a particular non-stationary Ornsteinâ€“Uhlenbeck process, while Karvonen (2023) obtained asymptotic lower bounds on estimates of the smoothness parameter of the MatÃ©rn model. The non-asymptotic behaviour of maximum likelihood estimation in the deterministic interpolation regime has yet to be studied.

1.1 Contributions

The principal contributions of this work are to demonstrate how the concept of well-posedness can be applied to Gaussian process interpolation and how rigorous theoretical analysis of well-posedness can be performed. We prove that, in the deterministic interpolation regime, maximum likelihood estimation of a lengthscale parameter can fail to be well-posed. We emphasise that this is a non-asymptotic (i.e., the number nğ‘›n of observations is kept fixed) result, in contrast to earlier work, and is based on the observation that the maximum likelihood estimate Î»MLsubscriptğœ†ML\lambda_{\textup{ML}} of a lengthscale parameter Î»ğœ†\lambda is infinite if the observations differ from the prior mean function by a constant vertical shift.

To be more precise, consider a Gaussian process with prior mean function mğ‘šm and stationary covariance function of the form

KÎ»â€‹(x,y)=Î¦â€‹(xâˆ’yÎ»)Â forÂ x,yâˆˆâ„d,formulae-sequencesubscriptğ¾ğœ†ğ‘¥ğ‘¦Î¦ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğœ†Â forÂ ğ‘¥ğ‘¦superscriptâ„ğ‘‘K_{\lambda}(x,y)=\Phi\bigg{(}\frac{x-y}{\lambda}\bigg{)}\quad\text{ for }\quad x,y\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, (1.2)

where the lengthscale parameter Î»>0ğœ†0\lambda>0 determines the spatial correlation distance of the resulting Gaussian random field. If the function Î¦:â„dâ†’â„:Î¦â†’superscriptâ„ğ‘‘â„\Phi\colon\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R} is continuous, the covariance functionÂ (1.2) tends pointwise to the constant Î¦â€‹(0)Î¦0\Phi(0) as Î»â†’âˆâ†’ğœ†\lambda\to\infty. Thus, if the data are approximately shifted from the mean function mğ‘šm by a constant, it is intuitive that a large value will be taken by the maximum likelihood estimateÂ Î»MLsubscriptğœ†ML\lambda_{\textup{ML}}. It is rigorously proven in this article (see TheoremÂ 2.3) that if (a) nâ‰¥2ğ‘›2n\geq 2 is fixed, (b) the function Î¦Î¦\Phi inÂ (1.2) satisfies certain mild regularity conditions, and (c) there is a constant câˆˆâ„ğ‘â„c\in\mathbb{R} such that the data are mğ‘šm-constant in that

yi=mâ€‹(xi)+cÂ forÂ i=1,â€¦,n,formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘Â forÂ ğ‘–1â€¦ğ‘›y_{i}=m(x_{i})+c\quad\text{ for }\quad i=1,\ldots,n, (1.3)

then Î»ML=âˆsubscriptğœ†ML\lambda_{\textup{ML}}=\infty. This result can be viewed as a generalisation of the simple fact that maximum likelihood estimation fails if the data are fully explained by the prior mean: if yi=mâ€‹(xi)subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–y_{i}=m(x_{i}) for every i=1,â€¦,nğ‘–1â€¦ğ‘›i=1,\ldots,n, the first term of â„“â€‹(Î»âˆ£Y)â„“conditionalğœ†ğ‘Œ\ell(\lambda\mid Y) inÂ (1.1) is zero and thus the estimate of Î»ğœ†\lambda must be infinite because KÎ»â€‹(X,X)subscriptğ¾ğœ†ğ‘‹ğ‘‹K_{\lambda}(X,X) tends to a singular matrix if and only if Î»â†’âˆâ†’ğœ†\lambda\to\infty. From Î»ML=âˆsubscriptğœ†ML\lambda_{\textup{ML}}=\infty it follows that the pointwise predictions produced by the fitted Gaussian process model assign all probability to a single point (see TheoremÂ 2.6). This phenomenon is undesirable, as it is not reasonable to claim infinite precision from a finite data set (which could, in this case, involve as few as n=2ğ‘›2n=2 values being observed). Secondly, we prove that if the data are not mğ‘šm-constant, then Î»ML<âˆsubscriptğœ†ML\lambda_{\textup{ML}}<\infty so that the predictive distributions are non-degenerate. Using these results we show in SectionÂ 2.4 that maximum likelihood estimation is not well-posed in general, in the sense that the resulting predictive distributions are not Lipschitz in the data with respect to the Hellinger distance, which means that predictive inference can be sensitive to small perturbations of the data set.111Note that this notion of well-posedness of a parameter estimation method is stronger than that of its robustness, defined by Gu etÂ al. (2018, SectionÂ 3) essentially as the impossibility of obtaining a singular covariance matrix.

A constant mean shift inÂ (1.3) is not a pathological case in the deterministic interpolation context, though it does highlight one sense in which mathematical analysis may be easier when the data are assumed to come from a stochastic process, since a constant mean shift may be neglected as a measure zero event in that setting. For example, Gaussian process regression has been used to explore discrepancy between computer models (Brevault etÂ al., 2020), where a constant mean shift between the output of two computer models for the same phenomenon could reasonably be expected. Similarly, in probabilistic numerical computation one could encounter a constant mean shift (e.g., when modelling an integrand in Bayesian cubature, if that integrand is in fact constant; Briol etÂ al., 2019), or in applications of Bayesian optimisation, where the data are obtained in a region where the objective function is constant. The role of this article is therefore to highlight an important failure mode of maximum likelihood estimation in Gaussian process interpolation and, in doing so, to underscore the need for an improved theoretical understanding of parameter estimation in general.

It would be tempting to attribute these failings to the simplicity of the maximum likelihood estimator and the modelling choices that we consider, for surely something more sophisticated ought to render the problem well-posed. SectionÂ 3 demonstrates that there may not exist an easy solution in the deterministic interpolation regime, at least if the tractability of a Gaussian process model is to be retained. Namely, we prove the following extensions:

  1. (i)

    A certain cross-validation estimator of the scale parameter shares the undesirable property of producing infinite lengthscale estimates when the data are mğ‘šm-constant.

  2. (ii)

    Inclusion of a parametric prior mean function, which too is estimated from the data (i.e., as in universal kriging), does not prevent ill-posedness.

  3. (iii)

    Simultaneous maximum likelihood estimation of the scale and lengthscale parameters does not prevent ill-posedness.

What does guarantee well-posedness is the inclusion of a regularisation or a nugget term, which corresponds to an assumption by the user that the data are corrupted by additive Gaussian noise. It is intuitive that the maximum likelihood estimator should be more well-behaved if the data-generating process is noisy as it may be merely by chance that the data set is mğ‘šm-constant. Less intuitive is the numerical evidence in SectionÂ 4.1, which indicates that Î»MLsubscriptğœ†ML\lambda_{\textup{ML}} is infinite even in the regularised setting as long as the regularisation term is sufficiently large. A possible interpretation of this observation is that for sufficiently large assumed noise level any data could have been plausibly generated by a constant mean shift of the prior mean. The use of regularisation can hardly be considered a proper solution to ill-posedness because the interpolation property of the conditional process, desirable in many applications, is lost and an influential degree of freedom is introduced. As demonstrated in SectionÂ 4.2, another option for guaranteeing that the lengthscale estimates are always finite is to place a hyperprior on the lengthscale and use maximum a posteriori estimation. However, because the hyperprior determines the estimator, this approach is rather arbitrary and does not lend itself well to automation in software.

Most of our results apply to MatÃ©rn-type covariance functions whose Fourier transforms decay polynomially (see AssumptionÂ 2.2). SectionÂ 5 discusses generalisations of this Fourier assumption, lengthscale estimation for product kernels, and the use of general linear information, such as derivative data. Our proofs are predominantly based on reproducing kernel Hilbert space (RKHS) techniques and approximation theory in Sobolev spaces. Complete proofs are relegated to SectionÂ 7. No familiarity with RKHSs or Sobolev spaces is required to understand the statements of our main results and, outside the proofs, it is only in SectionÂ 5 that these concepts are used. Practical and theoretical implications of our results are discussed in SectionÂ 6.

1.2 Related Literature

For fixed kernel parameters Î¸ğœƒ\theta, the mathematical properties of Gaussian process interpolation as nâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘›n\to\infty can be deduced from the equivalent perspective of optimal interpolation in an RKHS. See Fasshauer (2011); Scheuerer etÂ al. (2013); and Kanagawa etÂ al. (2018) for reviews on this equivalence. The setting where the data-generating function fğ‘“f is randomised has received considerable attention and a large number of results have been obtained. Consistency and asymptotic normality results for maximum likelihood estimation of scale and lengthscale parameters can be found in, for example, Ying (1991); Zhang (2004); Loh (2005); Du etÂ al. (2009); Anderes (2010); Kaufman and Shaby (2013); Bachoc (2013); and Bevilacqua etÂ al. (2019). The use of maximum likelihood to estimate smoothness parameters (i.e., controlling the differentiability of the Gaussian process sample paths) has also been considered, notably by SzabÃ³ etÂ al. (2015); Knapik etÂ al. (2016); Chen etÂ al. (2021); and Karvonen (2023). A well known issue with maximum likelihood estimation occurs when Î¸ğœƒ\theta is non-identifiable, as can happen when one attempts to simultaneously estimate scale, lengthscale, and smoothness parameters in the MatÃ©rn covariance modelÂ (Zhang, 2004). However, a lack of identifiability does not affect the predictions produced by the model or the combinations of parameters that can be identified (the so-called microergodic parameters). These related works, whilst providing useful insight and powerful theoretical tools and techniques, do not apply in the non-asymptotic deterministic interpolation regime where Î¸ğœƒ\theta is estimated using maximum likelihood.

2 Maximum Likelihood Estimation Is Not Well-Posed

Given any function fğ‘“f and a set Xğ‘‹X of points x1,â€¦,xnsubscriptğ‘¥1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›x_{1},\ldots,x_{n} in the domain of fğ‘“f, we use fâ€‹(X)ğ‘“ğ‘‹f(X) to denote the nğ‘›n-vector (fâ€‹(x1),â€¦,fâ€‹(xn))ğ‘“subscriptğ‘¥1â€¦ğ‘“subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›(f(x_{1}),\ldots,f(x_{n})). All vectors in this article are to be understood to be in column format.

2.1 Gaussian Process Interpolation

In Gaussian process interpolation, the data are modelled as discrete and noiseless observations from a Gaussian process sample path. A Gaussian process fGPâˆ¼GPâ€‹(m,K)similar-tosubscriptğ‘“GPGPğ‘šğ¾f_{\textup{GP}}\sim\mathrm{GP}(m,K) on â„dsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbb{R}^{d} is a stochastic process characterised by a mean function m:â„dâ†’â„:ğ‘šâ†’superscriptâ„ğ‘‘â„m\colon\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R} and a covariance kernel K:â„dÃ—â„dâ†’â„:ğ¾â†’superscriptâ„ğ‘‘superscriptâ„ğ‘‘â„K\colon\mathbb{R}^{d}\times\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R}:

ğ”¼â€‹[fGPâ€‹(x)]=mâ€‹(x)Â andÂ Covâ€‹[fGPâ€‹(x),fGPâ€‹(y)]=Kâ€‹(x,y)formulae-sequenceğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptğ‘“GPğ‘¥ğ‘šğ‘¥Â andÂ Covsubscriptğ‘“GPğ‘¥subscriptğ‘“GPğ‘¦ğ¾ğ‘¥ğ‘¦\mathbb{E}[f_{\textup{GP}}(x)]=m(x)\quad\text{ and }\quad\mathrm{Cov}[f_{\textup{GP}}(x),f_{\textup{GP}}(y)]=K(x,y)

for all x,yâˆˆâ„dğ‘¥ğ‘¦superscriptâ„ğ‘‘x,y\in\mathbb{R}^{d}. Let Kâ€‹(X,X)=(Kâ€‹(xi,xj))i,j=1nâˆˆâ„nÃ—nğ¾ğ‘‹ğ‘‹superscriptsubscriptğ¾subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—ğ‘–ğ‘—1ğ‘›superscriptâ„ğ‘›ğ‘›K(X,X)=(K(x_{i},x_{j}))_{i,j=1}^{n}\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times n}. That fGPsubscriptğ‘“GPf_{\textup{GP}} is Gaussian means that all its finite-dimensional distributions are normally distributed, which is to say that

fGPâ€‹(X)âˆ¼Nâ€‹(mâ€‹(X),Kâ€‹(X,X))similar-tosubscriptğ‘“GPğ‘‹Nğ‘šğ‘‹ğ¾ğ‘‹ğ‘‹f_{\textup{GP}}(X)\sim\mathrm{N}(m(X),K(X,X))

for any finite set of points XâŠ‚â„dğ‘‹superscriptâ„ğ‘‘X\subset\mathbb{R}^{d}. Throughout this article the covariance kernel is assumed to be (strictly) positive-definite, which means that

âˆ‘i=1nâˆ‘j=1naiâ€‹ajâ€‹Kâ€‹(xi,xj)>0superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ‘›subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘—ğ¾subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—0\sum_{i=1}^{n}\sum_{j=1}^{n}a_{i}a_{j}K(x_{i},x_{j})>0 (2.1)

for any nâˆˆâ„•ğ‘›â„•n\in\mathbb{N}, any non-zero vector a=(a1,â€¦,an)ğ‘subscriptğ‘1â€¦subscriptğ‘ğ‘›a=(a_{1},\ldots,a_{n}), and any distinct points xiâˆˆâ„dsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–superscriptâ„ğ‘‘x_{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}. This implies that the covariance matrix Kâ€‹(X,X)ğ¾ğ‘‹ğ‘‹K(X,X) is positive-definite and non-singular if Xğ‘‹X consists of distinct points. A covariance kernel is stationary if there is a function Î¦:â„dâ†’â„:Î¦â†’superscriptâ„ğ‘‘â„\Phi\colon\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R} such that

Kâ€‹(x,y)=Î¦â€‹(xâˆ’y)Â for allÂ x,yâˆˆâ„d.formulae-sequenceğ¾ğ‘¥ğ‘¦Î¦ğ‘¥ğ‘¦Â for allÂ ğ‘¥ğ‘¦superscriptâ„ğ‘‘K(x,y)=\Phi(x-y)\quad\text{ for all }\quad x,y\in\mathbb{R}^{d}. (2.2)

If Î¦Î¦\Phi is to yield a positive-definite covariance kernel, it is necessary that Î¦â€‹(0)>0Î¦00\Phi(0)>0 because otherwise the conditionÂ (2.1) fails for n=1ğ‘›1n=1. For the purposes of this article, the MatÃ©rn kernels constitute the most important class of stationary covariance functions. Let Ïƒğœ\sigma, Î»ğœ†\lambda, and Î½ğœˆ\nu be positive. A MatÃ©rn kernel with scale Ïƒğœ\sigma, lengthscale Î»ğœ†\lambda, and smoothness Î½ğœˆ\nu is given by

Kâ€‹(x,y)=Ïƒ2â€‹21âˆ’Î½Î“â€‹(Î½)â€‹(2â€‹Î½â€‹âˆ¥xâˆ’yâˆ¥Î»)Î½â€‹ğ’¦Î½â€‹(2â€‹Î½â€‹âˆ¥xâˆ’yâˆ¥Î»),ğ¾ğ‘¥ğ‘¦superscriptğœ2superscript21ğœˆÎ“ğœˆsuperscript2ğœˆdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğœ†ğœˆsubscriptğ’¦ğœˆ2ğœˆdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğœ†K(x,y)=\sigma^{2}\frac{2^{1-\nu}}{\Gamma(\nu)}\bigg{(}\frac{\sqrt{2\nu}\mathinner{\lVert x-y\rVert}}{\lambda}\bigg{)}^{\nu}\mathcal{K}_{\nu}\bigg{(}\frac{\sqrt{2\nu}\mathinner{\lVert x-y\rVert}}{\lambda}\bigg{)}, (2.3)

where Î“Î“\Gamma is the Gamma function and ğ’¦Î½subscriptğ’¦ğœˆ\mathcal{K}_{\nu} the modified Bessel function of the second kind.

Suppose that a noiseless training data set Y=(y1,â€¦,yn)âˆˆâ„nğ‘Œsubscriptğ‘¦1â€¦subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘›superscriptâ„ğ‘›Y=(y_{1},\ldots,y_{n})\in\mathbb{R}^{n} associated to a set Xğ‘‹X of distinct covariates x1,â€¦,xnâˆˆâ„dsubscriptğ‘¥1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›superscriptâ„ğ‘‘x_{1},\ldots,x_{n}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} has been obtained and let Ym=Yâˆ’mâ€‹(X)subscriptğ‘Œğ‘šğ‘Œğ‘šğ‘‹Y_{m}=Y-m(X). Define

Kâ€‹(x,X)=(Kâ€‹(x,xi))i=1nâˆˆâ„nÂ andÂ Kâ€‹(X,y)=(Kâ€‹(xi,y))i=1nâˆˆâ„nformulae-sequenceğ¾ğ‘¥ğ‘‹superscriptsubscriptğ¾ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘–1ğ‘›superscriptâ„ğ‘›Â andÂ ğ¾ğ‘‹ğ‘¦superscriptsubscriptğ¾subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘¦ğ‘–1ğ‘›superscriptâ„ğ‘›K(x,X)=(K(x,x_{i}))_{i=1}^{n}\in\mathbb{R}^{n}\quad\text{ and }\quad K(X,y)=(K(x_{i},y))_{i=1}^{n}\in\mathbb{R}^{n}

for any x,yâˆˆâ„dğ‘¥ğ‘¦superscriptâ„ğ‘‘x,y\in\mathbb{R}^{d}. The mean and covariance functions of the conditional Gaussian process fGPâˆ£Yconditionalsubscriptğ‘“GPğ‘Œf_{\textup{GP}}\mid Y are obtained from the well known expressions

Î¼â€‹(x)=ğ”¼â€‹[fGPâ€‹(x)âˆ£Y]=mâ€‹(x)+Kâ€‹(x,X)ğ–³â€‹Kâ€‹(X,X)âˆ’1â€‹Ymğœ‡ğ‘¥ğ”¼delimited-[]conditionalsubscriptğ‘“GPğ‘¥ğ‘Œğ‘šğ‘¥ğ¾superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘‹ğ–³ğ¾superscriptğ‘‹ğ‘‹1subscriptğ‘Œğ‘š\mu(x)=\mathbb{E}[f_{\textup{GP}}(x)\mid Y]=m(x)+K(x,X)^{\mathsf{T}}K(X,X)^{-1}Y_{m} (2.4)

and

Pâ€‹(x,y)2=Covâ€‹[fGPâ€‹(x),fGPâ€‹(y)âˆ£Y]=Kâ€‹(x,y)âˆ’Kâ€‹(x,X)ğ–³â€‹Kâ€‹(X,X)âˆ’1â€‹Kâ€‹(X,y).ğ‘ƒsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¦2Covsubscriptğ‘“GPğ‘¥conditionalsubscriptğ‘“GPğ‘¦ğ‘Œğ¾ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ¾superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘‹ğ–³ğ¾superscriptğ‘‹ğ‘‹1ğ¾ğ‘‹ğ‘¦P(x,y)^{2}=\mathrm{Cov}[f_{\textup{GP}}(x),f_{\textup{GP}}(y)\mid Y]=K(x,y)-K(x,X)^{\mathsf{T}}K(X,X)^{-1}K(X,y). (2.5)

We use the simplified notation Pâ€‹(x,x)2=Pâ€‹(x)2ğ‘ƒsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¥2ğ‘ƒsuperscriptğ‘¥2P(x,x)^{2}=P(x)^{2} for the conditional variance. It is often convenient, especially in our proofs, to use the function

sâ€‹(x)=Kâ€‹(x,X)ğ–³â€‹Kâ€‹(X,X)âˆ’1â€‹Ymğ‘ ğ‘¥ğ¾superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘‹ğ–³ğ¾superscriptğ‘‹ğ‘‹1subscriptğ‘Œğ‘šs(x)=K(x,X)^{\mathsf{T}}K(X,X)^{-1}Y_{m} (2.6)

and write the conditional mean as Î¼=m+sğœ‡ğ‘šğ‘ \mu=m+s. The assumption that there is no noise means that we are in the deterministic interpolation regime where Î¼ğœ‡\mu is an interpolant to the data, which is to say that Î¼â€‹(xi)=yiğœ‡subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–\mu(x_{i})=y_{i} and Pâ€‹(xi)=0ğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–0P(x_{i})=0 for everyÂ i=1,â€¦,nğ‘–1â€¦ğ‘›i=1,\ldots,n. Crucially, this assumption allows us to leverage well known equivalences, reviewed in SectionÂ 7.1, between Gaussian process interpolation and kernel-based minimum-norm interpolationÂ (e.g., Scheuerer etÂ al., 2013; Kanagawa etÂ al., 2018).

2.2 Maximum Likelihood Estimation

Maximum likelihood estimation is the most common method used to select parameters Î¸âˆˆÎ˜ğœƒÎ˜\theta\in\Theta of a parametrised covariance kernel KÎ¸subscriptğ¾ğœƒK_{\theta}. Under the Gaussian process model GPâ€‹(m,KÎ¸)GPğ‘šsubscriptğ¾ğœƒ\mathrm{GP}(m,K_{\theta}), the probability density function of the data Yğ‘ŒY given Î¸ğœƒ\theta isÂ (e.g., Rasmussen and Williams, 2006, SectionÂ 5.4.1)

1det(2â€‹Ï€â€‹KÎ¸â€‹(X,X))1/2â€‹expâ¡(âˆ’12â€‹Ymğ–³â€‹KÎ¸â€‹(X,X)âˆ’1â€‹Ym).1superscript2ğœ‹subscriptğ¾ğœƒğ‘‹ğ‘‹1212superscriptsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘šğ–³subscriptğ¾ğœƒsuperscriptğ‘‹ğ‘‹1subscriptğ‘Œğ‘š\frac{1}{\det(2\pi K_{\theta}(X,X))^{1/2}}\exp\bigg{(}\!\!-\frac{1}{2}Y_{m}^{\mathsf{T}}K_{\theta}(X,X)^{-1}Y_{m}\bigg{)}. (2.7)

MaximisingÂ (2.7) over Î˜Î˜\Theta is equivalent to minimising

â„“â€‹(Î¸âˆ£Y)=Ymğ–³â€‹KÎ¸â€‹(X,X)âˆ’1â€‹Ym+logâ€‹detKÎ¸â€‹(X,X),â„“conditionalğœƒğ‘Œsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘šğ–³subscriptğ¾ğœƒsuperscriptğ‘‹ğ‘‹1subscriptğ‘Œğ‘šsubscriptğ¾ğœƒğ‘‹ğ‘‹\ell(\theta\mid Y)=Y_{m}^{\mathsf{T}}K_{\theta}(X,X)^{-1}Y_{m}+\log\det K_{\theta}(X,X), (2.8)

which we call the modified log-likelihood function, being the log-likelihood function up to subtraction and multiplication by negative constants. That is, any maximum likelihood estimate (which may not be unique if â„“â„“\ell is multimodal) of Î¸ğœƒ\theta satisfies

Î¸MLâˆˆargâ€‹minÎ¸âˆˆÎ˜â¡â„“â€‹(Î¸âˆ£Y).subscriptğœƒMLsubscriptargminğœƒÎ˜â„“conditionalğœƒğ‘Œ\theta_{\textup{ML}}\in\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{\theta\in\Theta}\ell(\theta\mid Y).

The two terms that comprise the modified log-likelihood functionÂ (2.8) are usually called the (negative) data-fit and model complexity terms, respectively. Throughout the article we use subscripts to denote that various quantities depend on the kernel parameters. For example, the parameter-dependent conditional mean and covariance are

Î¼Î¸â€‹(x)subscriptğœ‡ğœƒğ‘¥\displaystyle\mu_{\theta}(x) =mâ€‹(x)+KÎ¸â€‹(x,X)ğ–³â€‹KÎ¸â€‹(X,X)âˆ’1â€‹Ym,absentğ‘šğ‘¥subscriptğ¾ğœƒsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘‹ğ–³subscriptğ¾ğœƒsuperscriptğ‘‹ğ‘‹1subscriptğ‘Œğ‘š\displaystyle=m(x)+K_{\theta}(x,X)^{\mathsf{T}}K_{\theta}(X,X)^{-1}Y_{m},
PÎ¸â€‹(x,y)2subscriptğ‘ƒğœƒsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¦2\displaystyle P_{\theta}(x,y)^{2} =KÎ¸â€‹(x,y)âˆ’KÎ¸â€‹(x,X)ğ–³â€‹KÎ¸â€‹(X,X)âˆ’1â€‹KÎ¸â€‹(X,y).absentsubscriptğ¾ğœƒğ‘¥ğ‘¦subscriptğ¾ğœƒsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘‹ğ–³subscriptğ¾ğœƒsuperscriptğ‘‹ğ‘‹1subscriptğ¾ğœƒğ‘‹ğ‘¦\displaystyle=K_{\theta}(x,y)-K_{\theta}(x,X)^{\mathsf{T}}K_{\theta}(X,X)^{-1}K_{\theta}(X,y).

We are interested in estimation of the lengthscale parameter Î»>0ğœ†0\lambda>0 which parametrises any stationary kernel of the formÂ (2.2) as

KÎ»â€‹(x,y)=Î¦â€‹(xâˆ’yÎ»)subscriptğ¾ğœ†ğ‘¥ğ‘¦Î¦ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğœ†K_{\lambda}(x,y)=\Phi\bigg{(}\frac{x-y}{\lambda}\bigg{)}

and determines the spatial correlation distance of the resulting Gaussian process (see FigureÂ 1). A maximum likelihood estimate of Î»ğœ†\lambda therefore satisfies

Î»MLâˆˆargâ€‹minÎ»>0â¡â„“â€‹(Î»âˆ£Y)=argâ€‹minÎ»>0â¡{Ymğ–³â€‹KÎ»â€‹(X,X)âˆ’1â€‹Ym+logâ€‹detKÎ»â€‹(X,X)}.subscriptğœ†MLsubscriptargminğœ†0â„“conditionalğœ†ğ‘Œsubscriptargminğœ†0superscriptsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘šğ–³subscriptğ¾ğœ†superscriptğ‘‹ğ‘‹1subscriptğ‘Œğ‘šsubscriptğ¾ğœ†ğ‘‹ğ‘‹\lambda_{\textup{ML}}\in\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{\lambda>0}\ell(\lambda\mid Y)=\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{\lambda>0}\big{\{}Y_{m}^{\mathsf{T}}K_{\lambda}(X,X)^{-1}Y_{m}+\log\det K_{\lambda}(X,X)\big{\}}.

Specifically, we are interested in rigorously proving that Î»ML=âˆsubscriptğœ†ML\lambda_{\textup{ML}}=\infty in certain cases. AsÂ Î»ğœ†\lambda increases, the kernel KÎ»subscriptğ¾ğœ†K_{\lambda} tends pointwise to Î¦â€‹(0)Î¦0\Phi(0), which is not positive-definite, and the covariance matrices in the predictive meanÂ (2.4) and covarianceÂ (2.5) become singular if n>1ğ‘›1n>1. However, the limits limÎ»â†’âˆÎ¼Î»subscriptâ†’ğœ†subscriptğœ‡ğœ†\lim_{\lambda\to\infty}\mu_{\lambda} and limÎ»â†’âˆPÎ»â€‹(x,y)2subscriptâ†’ğœ†subscriptğ‘ƒğœ†superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¦2\lim_{\lambda\to\infty}P_{\lambda}(x,y)^{2} do exist for most commonly used kernels, such as MatÃ©rns and the Gaussian, and it is in this limiting sense that one should interpret the conditional moments when Î»=âˆğœ†\lambda=\infty. This is discussed in more detail in SectionÂ 2.3.

Our results on the behaviour of Î»MLsubscriptğœ†ML\lambda_{\textup{ML}} (and, later, other estimators of Î»ğœ†\lambda) show that Gaussian process interpolation fails, producing degenerate predictive distributions, when the data are mğ‘šm-constant and the function Î¦Î¦\Phi has a polynomially decaying Fourier transform.

Definition 2.1 (Constant data)

Given a mean function mğ‘šm, we say that the data Yğ‘ŒY are mğ‘šm-constant if there is a constant câˆˆâ„ğ‘â„c\in\mathbb{R} such that

Ym=Yâˆ’mâ€‹(X)=(c,â€¦,c)âˆˆâ„n.subscriptğ‘Œğ‘šğ‘Œğ‘šğ‘‹ğ‘â€¦ğ‘superscriptâ„ğ‘›Y_{m}=Y-m(X)=(c,\ldots,c)\in\mathbb{R}^{n}.

Let f^â€‹(Î¾)=âˆ«â„dgâ€‹(x)â€‹eâˆ’iâ€‹Î¾ğ–³â€‹xâ€‹dâ¡x^ğ‘“ğœ‰subscriptsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘ğ‘”ğ‘¥superscripteisuperscriptğœ‰ğ–³ğ‘¥dğ‘¥\widehat{f}(\xi)=\int_{\mathbb{R}^{d}}g(x)\mathrm{e}^{-\mathrm{i}\xi^{\mathsf{T}}x}\operatorname{d\!}x denote the Fourier transform of an integrable function f:â„dâ†’â„:ğ‘“â†’superscriptâ„ğ‘‘â„f\colon\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R}. We use the following assumption on the rate of decay of the Fourier transform of a stationary kernel.

Assumption 2.2 (Stationary Sobolev kernel)

There are a continuous and integrable function Î¦:â„dâ†’â„:Î¦â†’superscriptâ„ğ‘‘â„\Phi\colon\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R} and constants C1subscriptğ¶1C_{1}, C2>0subscriptğ¶20C_{2}>0 and Î±>d/2ğ›¼ğ‘‘2\alpha>d/2 such that Kâ€‹(x,y)=Î¦â€‹(xâˆ’y)ğ¾ğ‘¥ğ‘¦Î¦ğ‘¥ğ‘¦K(x,y)=\Phi(x-y) for all x,yâˆˆâ„dğ‘¥ğ‘¦superscriptâ„ğ‘‘x,y\in\mathbb{R}^{d} and

C1â€‹(1+âˆ¥Î¾âˆ¥2)âˆ’Î±â‰¤Î¦^â€‹(Î¾)â‰¤C2â€‹(1+âˆ¥Î¾âˆ¥2)âˆ’Î±subscriptğ¶1superscript1superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğœ‰2ğ›¼^Î¦ğœ‰subscriptğ¶2superscript1superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğœ‰2ğ›¼C_{1}(1+\mathinner{\lVert\xi\rVert}^{2})^{-\alpha}\leq\widehat{\Phi}(\xi)\leq C_{2}(1+\mathinner{\lVert\xi\rVert}^{2})^{-\alpha} (2.9)

for all Î¾âˆˆâ„dğœ‰superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\xi\in\mathbb{R}^{d}.

If d=1ğ‘‘1d=1 and AssumptionÂ 2.2 holds for Î±=p+1âˆˆâ„•ğ›¼ğ‘1â„•\alpha=p+1\in\mathbb{N}, the kernel is pğ‘p times differentiable in that the derivative

âˆ‚2â€‹pâˆ‚xpâ€‹âˆ‚ypâ€‹Kâ€‹(x,y)|x=0y=0=(âˆ’1)pâ€‹Î¦2â€‹pâ€‹(0)evaluated-atsuperscript2ğ‘superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘superscriptğ‘¦ğ‘ğ¾ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘¥0ğ‘¦0superscript1ğ‘superscriptÎ¦2ğ‘0\frac{\partial^{2p}}{\partial x^{p}\partial y^{p}}K(x,y)\Bigr{|}_{\begin{subarray}{c}x=0\\ y=0\end{subarray}}=(-1)^{p}\Phi^{2p}(0)

exists. As a consequence, the process fGPâˆ¼GPâ€‹(m,K)similar-tosubscriptğ‘“GPGPğ‘šğ¾f_{\textup{GP}}\sim\mathrm{GP}(m,K) is pğ‘p times mean-square differentiableÂ (Stein, 1999, SectionÂ 2.4). That a kernel satisfyingÂ (2.9) is called a Sobolev kernel is because its RKHS is norm-equivalent to the Sobolev space W2Î±â€‹(â„d)superscriptsubscriptğ‘Š2ğ›¼superscriptâ„ğ‘‘W_{2}^{\alpha}(\mathbb{R}^{d}) of order Î±ğ›¼\alpha. The norm-equivalence is a crucial ingredient in several of our proofs and is reviewed, together with Sobolev spaces, in more detail in SectionÂ 7.3. One can also prove that the sample paths of fGPsubscriptğ‘“GPf_{\textup{GP}} are elements of certain Sobolev spacesÂ (Scheuerer, 2011; Steinwart, 2019; Henderson, 2022). The Fourier transform of the function

Î¦â€‹(z)=Ïƒ2â€‹21âˆ’Î½Î“â€‹(Î½)â€‹(2â€‹Î½â€‹âˆ¥zâˆ¥)Î½â€‹ğ’¦Î½â€‹(2â€‹Î½â€‹âˆ¥zâˆ¥),zâˆˆâ„d,formulae-sequenceÎ¦ğ‘§superscriptğœ2superscript21ğœˆÎ“ğœˆsuperscript2ğœˆdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ‘§ğœˆsubscriptğ’¦ğœˆ2ğœˆdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ‘§ğ‘§superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\Phi(z)=\sigma^{2}\frac{2^{1-\nu}}{\Gamma(\nu)}\big{(}\sqrt{2\nu}\mathinner{\lVert z\rVert}\big{)}^{\nu}\mathcal{K}_{\nu}\big{(}\sqrt{2\nu}\mathinner{\!\left\lVert z\right\rVert}\big{)},\quad z\in\mathbb{R}^{d},

which defines a MatÃ©rn kernel inÂ (2.3), isÂ (e.g., Stein, 1999, p.Â 49)

Î¦^â€‹(Î¾)=Ïƒ2â€‹Î“â€‹(Î½+d/2)Ï€d/2â€‹Î“â€‹(Î½)â€‹(2â€‹Î½)Î½â€‹(2â€‹Î½+âˆ¥Î¾âˆ¥2)âˆ’(Î½+d/2).^Î¦ğœ‰superscriptğœ2Î“ğœˆğ‘‘2superscriptğœ‹ğ‘‘2Î“ğœˆsuperscript2ğœˆğœˆsuperscript2ğœˆsuperscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğœ‰2ğœˆğ‘‘2\widehat{\Phi}(\xi)=\sigma^{2}\frac{\Gamma(\nu+d/2)}{\pi^{d/2}\Gamma(\nu)}(2\nu)^{\nu}\big{(}2\nu+\mathinner{\lVert\xi\rVert}^{2}\big{)}^{-(\nu+d/2)}. (2.10)

Therefore a MatÃ©rn kernel with smoothness Î½>0ğœˆ0\nu>0 satisfies AssumptionÂ 2.2 with Î±=Î½+d/2ğ›¼ğœˆğ‘‘2\alpha=\nu+d/2.

With these preliminaries we are ready to state the main result of this article on the behaviour of maximum likelihood estimates of Î»ğœ†\lambda. The result is illustrated in FigureÂ 2.

Theorem 2.3 (Maximum likelihood estimation)

Suppose that the kernel Kğ¾K satisfies AssumptionÂ 2.2 and nâ‰¥2ğ‘›2n\geq 2. If the data Yğ‘ŒY are mğ‘šm-constant, then

limÎ»â†’âˆâ„“â€‹(Î»âˆ£Y)=âˆ’âˆÂ andÂ Î»ML=âˆ.formulae-sequencesubscriptâ†’ğœ†â„“conditionalğœ†ğ‘ŒÂ andÂ subscriptğœ†ML\lim_{\lambda\to\infty}\ell(\lambda\mid Y)=-\infty\quad\text{ and }\quad\lambda_{\textup{ML}}=\infty. (2.11)

If the data Yğ‘ŒY are not mğ‘šm-constant, then

limÎ»â†’âˆâ„“â€‹(Î»âˆ£Y)=âˆÂ andÂ Î»ML<âˆ.formulae-sequencesubscriptâ†’ğœ†â„“conditionalğœ†ğ‘ŒÂ andÂ subscriptğœ†ML\lim_{\lambda\to\infty}\ell(\lambda\mid Y)=\infty\quad\text{ and }\quad\lambda_{\textup{ML}}<\infty. (2.12)

ProofÂ  See SectionÂ 7.4. The proof uses RKHS techniques to show that under AssumptionÂ 2.2 the data-fit term, as a function of Î»ğœ†\lambda, (a)Â is upper bounded if the data are mğ‘šm-constant and (b)Â grows polynomially if the data are not mğ‘šm-constant, while the covariance matrix tends to the matrix consisting of Î¦â€‹(0)Î¦0\Phi(0)â€™s as Î»â†’âˆâ†’ğœ†\lambda\to\infty and it can be shown that its log-determinant (i.e., the model complexity) tends to negative infinity with at most rate âˆ’logâ¡Î»ğœ†-\log\lambda. Â 

Remark 2.4

It would be very interesting and useful to obtain a more quantitative version of TheoremÂ 2.3 which would, for example, state that

Î»MLâ‰¥gâ€‹(constmâ€‹(Y))subscriptğœ†MLğ‘”subscriptconstğ‘šğ‘Œ\lambda_{\textup{ML}}\geq g(\mathrm{const}_{m}(Y)) (2.13)

for some measure constmâ€‹(Y)subscriptconstğ‘šğ‘Œ\mathrm{const}_{m}(Y) of how far Yğ‘ŒY are from being mğ‘šm-constant (i.e., constmâ€‹(Y)=0subscriptconstğ‘šğ‘Œ0\mathrm{const}_{m}(Y)=0 if and only if Yğ‘ŒY are mğ‘šm-constant) and some decreasing function g:(0,âˆ)â†’â„:ğ‘”â†’0â„g\colon(0,\infty)\to\mathbb{R} such that gâ€‹(r)â†’âˆâ†’ğ‘”ğ‘Ÿg(r)\to\infty as râ†’0â†’ğ‘Ÿ0r\to 0. Unfortunately, the techniques we use to prove TheoremÂ 2.3 are not precise enough to prove any form ofÂ (2.13).

Remark 2.5

For simplicity, suppose that mâ‰¡0ğ‘š0m\equiv 0 so that the data being mğ‘šm-constant means that Y=(c,â€¦,c)ğ‘Œğ‘â€¦ğ‘Y=(c,\ldots,c) for some câˆˆâ„ğ‘â„c\in\mathbb{R}. Because the case Î»=âˆğœ†\lambda=\infty formally corresponds to a model with a constant kernel, one might be tempted to interpret TheoremÂ 2.3 as a special case of a general theorem which would state that Î¸MLsubscriptğœƒML\theta_{\textup{ML}} takes the value Î¸Â¯Â¯ğœƒ\bar{\theta} for which the data are fully explained by a single translate of KÎ¸Â¯subscriptğ¾Â¯ğœƒK_{\bar{\theta}}. However, there can be no such theorem. For suppose that there are Î¸Â¯âˆˆÎ˜Â¯ğœƒÎ˜\bar{\theta}\in\Theta and iâˆˆ{1,â€¦,n}ğ‘–1â€¦ğ‘›i\in\{1,\ldots,n\} such that the data could have been generated by the translate of KÎ¸Â¯subscriptğ¾Â¯ğœƒK_{\bar{\theta}} at xisubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x_{i}. That is, Y=aâ€‹KÎ¸Â¯â€‹(xi,X)ğ‘Œğ‘subscriptğ¾Â¯ğœƒsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘‹Y=aK_{\bar{\theta}}(x_{i},X) for some aâˆˆâ„ğ‘â„a\in\mathbb{R}. Then

â„“â€‹(Î¸âˆ£Y)=Yğ–³â€‹KÎ¸â€‹(X,X)âˆ’1â€‹Y+logâ€‹detKÎ¸â€‹(X,X)â„“conditionalğœƒğ‘Œsuperscriptğ‘Œğ–³subscriptğ¾ğœƒsuperscriptğ‘‹ğ‘‹1ğ‘Œsubscriptğ¾ğœƒğ‘‹ğ‘‹\ell(\theta\mid Y)=Y^{\mathsf{T}}K_{\theta}(X,X)^{-1}Y+\log\det K_{\theta}(X,X)

would have to attain its minimum at Î¸=Î¸Â¯ğœƒÂ¯ğœƒ\theta=\bar{\theta}. But because the data-fit term is non-negative and the model complexity term does not depend on the data, it is clear that a minimum can be attained at Î¸Â¯Â¯ğœƒ\bar{\theta} only by â€œchanceâ€ or if logâ€‹detKÎ¸Â¯â€‹(X,X)=âˆ’âˆsubscriptğ¾Â¯ğœƒğ‘‹ğ‘‹\log\det K_{\bar{\theta}}(X,X)=-\infty, which happens only if KÎ¸Â¯â€‹(X,X)subscriptğ¾Â¯ğœƒğ‘‹ğ‘‹K_{\bar{\theta}}(X,X) is singular or, in other words, if KÎ¸Â¯subscriptğ¾Â¯ğœƒK_{\bar{\theta}} is not a valid positive-definite kernel. That is, there can be no general theorem that Î¸ML=Î¸Â¯subscriptğœƒMLÂ¯ğœƒ\theta_{\textup{ML}}=\bar{\theta} if it is required that KÎ¸Â¯subscriptğ¾Â¯ğœƒK_{\bar{\theta}} be a well-defined positive-definite kernel.

Next we discuss the behaviour of the conditional mean and covariance and give a precise meaning to ill-posedness of Gaussian process interpolation that we have repeatedly alluded to.

2.3 Conditional Mean and Variance in the Flat Limit

Given TheoremÂ 2.3, the question that arises is how the conditional meanÂ (2.4) and covarianceÂ (2.5) behave if the data are mğ‘šm-constant. As the kernel becomes constant for Î»=âˆğœ†\lambda=\infty, the linear systems in the equations which define the conditional moments are singular if nâ‰¥2ğ‘›2n\geq 2. The sensible approach is therefore to consider the limits of Î¼Î»â€‹(x)subscriptğœ‡ğœ†ğ‘¥\mu_{\lambda}(x) and PÎ»â€‹(x,y)subscriptğ‘ƒğœ†ğ‘¥ğ‘¦P_{\lambda}(x,y) as Î»â†’âˆâ†’ğœ†\lambda\to\infty. This flat limit has been extensively studied during the past twenty years in the literature on radial basis function interpolation; see, for instance, Lee etÂ al. (2015) or BarthelmÃ© and Usevich (2021) and the references therein. Flat limits have been recently considered in the context of Gaussian process interpolation by BarthelmÃ© etÂ al. (2022). The conclusion of this body of research is that, under certain assumptions on the kernel and the covariate set geometry, the kernel-dependent term of the conditional mean inÂ (2.6) tends pointwise to (a)Â a polynomial interpolant if the kernel is infinitely differentiableÂ (Lee etÂ al., 2007, TheoremÂ 3.4) or (b)Â a polyharmonic spline interpolant if the kernel is finitely differentiableÂ (Song etÂ al., 2012, TheoremÂ 1). Interestingly, if the data are mğ‘šm-constant, we find that it is possible to present a simpler proof that is completely self-contained.

Theorem 2.6

Suppose that Kğ¾K satisfies AssumptionÂ 2.2 and nâ‰¥1ğ‘›1n\geq 1. If Ym=(c,â€¦,c)subscriptğ‘Œğ‘šğ‘â€¦ğ‘Y_{m}=(c,\ldots,c) for some câˆˆâ„ğ‘â„c\in\mathbb{R}, then

limÎ»â†’âˆÎ¼Î»â€‹(x)=mâ€‹(x)+cÂ andÂ limÎ»â†’âˆ|PÎ»â€‹(x,y)|=0formulae-sequencesubscriptâ†’ğœ†subscriptğœ‡ğœ†ğ‘¥ğ‘šğ‘¥ğ‘Â andÂ subscriptâ†’ğœ†subscriptğ‘ƒğœ†ğ‘¥ğ‘¦0\lim_{\lambda\to\infty}\mu_{\lambda}(x)=m(x)+c\quad\text{ and }\quad\lim_{\lambda\to\infty}\mathinner{\lvert P_{\lambda}(x,y)\rvert}=0

for any x,yâˆˆâ„dğ‘¥ğ‘¦superscriptâ„ğ‘‘x,y\in\mathbb{R}^{d}.

ProofÂ  See SectionÂ 7.5. Â 

TheoremÂ 2.6 is illustrated in FigureÂ 3. Since Î¦Î¦\Phi is assumed continuous in AssumptionÂ 2.2, Î¼Î»â€‹(x)subscriptğœ‡ğœ†ğ‘¥\mu_{\lambda}(x) and PÎ»â€‹(x,y)subscriptğ‘ƒğœ†ğ‘¥ğ‘¦P_{\lambda}(x,y) are continuous functions of Î»ğœ†\lambda for any fixed x,yâˆˆâ„dğ‘¥ğ‘¦superscriptâ„ğ‘‘x,y\in\mathbb{R}^{d} (which is proved similarly to LemmaÂ 7.1). Therefore TheoremÂ 2.6 justifies writing

Î¼Î»=âˆâ€‹(x)=mâ€‹(x)+cÂ andÂ PÎ»=âˆâ€‹(x,y)=0.formulae-sequencesubscriptğœ‡ğœ†ğ‘¥ğ‘šğ‘¥ğ‘Â andÂ subscriptğ‘ƒğœ†ğ‘¥ğ‘¦0\mu_{\lambda=\infty}(x)=m(x)+c\quad\text{ and }\quad P_{\lambda=\infty}(x,y)=0. (2.14)

2.4 Ill-Posedness

By the classical definition of Hadamard, an inference or estimation problem is well-posed if (i) a solution exists, (ii) the solution is unique, and (iii) the solution depends on continuously on the data. If these conditions are not met, the problem is ill-posed. In the Bayesian inverse problems literature, where the solution is a posterior measure, the third condition is often strengthened to a requirement that the posterior be locally Lipschitz in the data with respect to the Hellinger distanceÂ (Stuart, 2010, SectionÂ 4). One of the reasons that make Hellinger distance suitable in our context is that two distributions that are close in Hellinger distance are close also in mean and variance. However, one may also consider other probability metricsÂ (e.g., Latz, 2020). In this section we show that prediction using Gaussian process interpolation is not well-posed in the latter Lipschitzâ€“Hellinger sense if the lengthscale parameter is set using maximum likelihood. Bringing formal notions of well-posedness to bear on Gaussian process interpolation has not, to the best of our knowledge, previously been attempted.

Let Q1subscriptğ‘„1Q_{1} and Q2subscriptğ‘„2Q_{2} be two probability distributions on â„qsuperscriptâ„ğ‘\mathbb{R}^{q} that are absolutely continuous with respect a reference measure Î½ğœˆ\nu on â„qsuperscriptâ„ğ‘\mathbb{R}^{q} and let q1subscriptğ‘1q_{1} and q2subscriptğ‘2q_{2} denote their Radonâ€“Nikodym derivatives with respect to Î½ğœˆ\nu. The squared Hellinger distance between Q1subscriptğ‘„1Q_{1} and Q2subscriptğ‘„2Q_{2} is

dHelâ€‹(Q1,Q2)2=12â€‹âˆ«â„q(q1â€‹(x)1/2âˆ’q2â€‹(x)1/2)2â€‹dâ¡Î½â€‹(x).subscriptğ‘‘Helsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘„1subscriptğ‘„2212subscriptsuperscriptâ„ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘1superscriptğ‘¥12subscriptğ‘2superscriptğ‘¥122dğœˆğ‘¥d_{\textup{Hel}}(Q_{1},Q_{2})^{2}=\frac{1}{2}\int_{\mathbb{R}^{q}}\big{(}q_{1}(x)^{1/2}-q_{2}(x)^{1/2}\big{)}^{2}\operatorname{d\!}\nu(x). (2.15)

The Hellinger distance does not depend on the reference measure Î½ğœˆ\nu, which means that for distributions that admit Lebesgue density functions we may set dâ¡Î½â€‹(x)=dâ¡xdğœˆğ‘¥dğ‘¥\operatorname{d\!}\nu(x)=\operatorname{d\!}x. For univariate Gaussians Q1=Nâ€‹(Î¼1,Î£1)subscriptğ‘„1Nsubscriptğœ‡1subscriptÎ£1Q_{1}=\mathrm{N}(\mu_{1},\Sigma_{1}) and Q2=Nâ€‹(Î¼2,Î£2)subscriptğ‘„2Nsubscriptğœ‡2subscriptÎ£2Q_{2}=\mathrm{N}(\mu_{2},\Sigma_{2}), we have

dHelâ€‹(Q1,Q2)2=1âˆ’2â€‹(Î£1â€‹Î£2)1/4Î£1+Î£2â€‹expâ¡(âˆ’(Î¼1âˆ’Î¼2)24â€‹(Î£1+Î£2)).subscriptğ‘‘Helsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘„1subscriptğ‘„2212superscriptsubscriptÎ£1subscriptÎ£214subscriptÎ£1subscriptÎ£2superscriptsubscriptğœ‡1subscriptğœ‡224subscriptÎ£1subscriptÎ£2d_{\textup{Hel}}(Q_{1},Q_{2})^{2}=1-\frac{\sqrt{2}(\Sigma_{1}\Sigma_{2})^{1/4}}{\sqrt{\Sigma_{1}+\Sigma_{2}}}\exp\bigg{(}\!-\frac{(\mu_{1}-\mu_{2})^{2}}{4(\Sigma_{1}+\Sigma_{2})}\bigg{)}. (2.16)

Let Qâ€‹(Y)ğ‘„ğ‘ŒQ(Y) stand for a posterior measure given an observed data vector Yâˆˆâ„nğ‘Œsuperscriptâ„ğ‘›Y\in\mathbb{R}^{n}. The posterior is said to be well-posed if for every Îµ>0ğœ€0\varepsilon>0 there exists L>0ğ¿0L>0 such that

dHelâ€‹(Qâ€‹(Y),Qâ€‹(Yâ€²))â‰¤Lâ€‹âˆ¥Yâˆ’Yâ€²âˆ¥subscriptğ‘‘Helğ‘„ğ‘Œğ‘„superscriptğ‘Œâ€²ğ¿delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ‘Œsuperscriptğ‘Œâ€²d_{\textup{Hel}}\big{(}Q(Y),Q(Y^{\prime})\big{)}\leq L\mathinner{\lVert Y-Y^{\prime}\rVert} (2.17)

for any data vectors Y,Yâ€²âˆˆâ„nğ‘Œsuperscriptğ‘Œâ€²superscriptâ„ğ‘›Y,Y^{\prime}\in\mathbb{R}^{n} for which âˆ¥Yâˆ’Yâ€²âˆ¥â‰¤Îµdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ‘Œsuperscriptğ‘Œâ€²ğœ€\mathinner{\lVert Y-Y^{\prime}\rVert}\leq\varepsilon.

Let us consider the Gaussian process predictive distribution at some unobserved point x0âˆ‰Xsubscriptğ‘¥0ğ‘‹x_{0}\notin X as the posterior and set

QGPâ€‹(Y)=Nâ€‹(Î¼Î»MLâ€‹(Y)â€‹(x0),PÎ»MLâ€‹(Y)â€‹(x0)2),subscriptğ‘„GPğ‘ŒNsubscriptğœ‡subscriptğœ†MLğ‘Œsubscriptğ‘¥0subscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğœ†MLğ‘Œsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥02Q_{\textup{GP}}(Y)=\mathrm{N}(\mu_{\lambda_{\textup{ML}}(Y)}(x_{0}),P_{\lambda_{\textup{ML}}(Y)}(x_{0})^{2}), (2.18)

where we use Î»MLâ€‹(Y)subscriptğœ†MLğ‘Œ\lambda_{\textup{ML}}(Y) to denote that a maximum likelihood estimate depends on the data Yğ‘ŒY. We may assume that Î»MLâ€‹(Y)subscriptğœ†MLğ‘Œ\lambda_{\textup{ML}}(Y) (or, if the modified log-likelihood function has multiple global minimum points, the largest of these) is a continuous function of the data, for otherwise predictions would not be continuous in the data, let alone Lipschitz. Let Îµ>0ğœ€0\varepsilon>0 and let (Yk)k=1âˆsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘˜ğ‘˜1(Y_{k})_{k=1}^{\infty} and (Ykâ€²)k=1âˆsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘˜â€²ğ‘˜1(Y_{k}^{\prime})_{k=1}^{\infty} be two data sequences which satisfy âˆ¥Ykâˆ’Ykâ€²âˆ¥â‰¤Îµdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ‘Œğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘˜â€²ğœ€\mathinner{\lVert Y_{k}-Y_{k}^{\prime}\rVert}\leq\varepsilon for every kâˆˆâ„•ğ‘˜â„•k\in\mathbb{N} and which converge to an mğ‘šm-constant data set:

limkâ†’âˆYkâˆ’mâ€‹(X)=limkâ†’âˆYkâ€²âˆ’mâ€‹(X)=(c,â€¦,c)âˆˆâ„nsubscriptâ†’ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘Œğ‘˜ğ‘šğ‘‹subscriptâ†’ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘˜â€²ğ‘šğ‘‹ğ‘â€¦ğ‘superscriptâ„ğ‘›\lim_{k\to\infty}Y_{k}-m(X)=\lim_{k\to\infty}Y_{k}^{\prime}-m(X)=(c,\ldots,c)\in\mathbb{R}^{n}

for some câˆˆâ„ğ‘â„c\in\mathbb{R}. By TheoremsÂ 2.3 andÂ 2.6 and the assumed continuity of Î»MLâ€‹(Y)subscriptğœ†MLğ‘Œ\lambda_{\textup{ML}}(Y) in the data, these sequences can be selected such that

Î£kâ‰”PÎ»MLâ€‹(Yk)â€‹(x0)2=C1â€‹eâˆ’kÂ andÂ Î£kâ€²â‰”PÎ»MLâ€‹(Ykâ€²)â€‹(x0)2=C2â€‹kâˆ’1formulae-sequenceâ‰”subscriptÎ£ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğœ†MLsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥02subscriptğ¶1superscripteğ‘˜â‰”Â andÂ superscriptsubscriptÎ£ğ‘˜â€²subscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğœ†MLsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘˜â€²superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥02subscriptğ¶2superscriptğ‘˜1\Sigma_{k}\coloneqq P_{\lambda_{\textup{ML}}(Y_{k})}(x_{0})^{2}=C_{1}\mathrm{e}^{-k}\quad\text{ and }\quad\Sigma_{k}^{\prime}\coloneqq P_{\lambda_{\textup{ML}}(Y_{k}^{\prime})}(x_{0})^{2}=C_{2}k^{-1}

for some positive constants C1subscriptğ¶1C_{1} and C2subscriptğ¶2C_{2}. Since eâˆ’xâ‰¤1superscripteğ‘¥1\operatorname{e}^{-x}\leq 1 for all xâ‰¥0ğ‘¥0x\geq 0, we get fromÂ (2.16) andÂ (2.18) that

dHelâ€‹(QGPâ€‹(Yk),QGPâ€‹(Ykâ€²))2â‰¥1âˆ’2â€‹(Î£kâ€‹Î£kâ€²)1/4Î£k+Î£kâ€²=1âˆ’2â€‹(C1â€‹C2)1/4â€‹kâˆ’1/4â€‹eâˆ’k/4C1â€‹eâˆ’k+C2â€‹kâˆ’1â‰¥1âˆ’2â€‹C11/4â€‹C2âˆ’1/4â€‹k1/4â€‹eâˆ’k/4,subscriptğ‘‘Helsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘„GPsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘˜subscriptğ‘„GPsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘˜â€²212superscriptsubscriptÎ£ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptÎ£ğ‘˜â€²14subscriptÎ£ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptÎ£ğ‘˜â€²12superscriptsubscriptğ¶1subscriptğ¶214superscriptğ‘˜14superscripteğ‘˜4subscriptğ¶1superscripteğ‘˜subscriptğ¶2superscriptğ‘˜112superscriptsubscriptğ¶114superscriptsubscriptğ¶214superscriptğ‘˜14superscripteğ‘˜4\begin{split}d_{\textup{Hel}}(Q_{\textup{GP}}(Y_{k}),Q_{\textup{GP}}(Y_{k}^{\prime}))^{2}\geq 1-\frac{\sqrt{2}(\Sigma_{k}\Sigma_{k}^{\prime})^{1/4}}{\sqrt{\smash[b]{\Sigma_{k}+\Sigma_{k}^{\prime}}}}&=1-\frac{\sqrt{2}(C_{1}C_{2})^{1/4}k^{-1/4}\mathrm{e}^{-k/4}}{\sqrt{\smash[b]{C_{1}\mathrm{e}^{-k}+C_{2}k^{-1}}}}\\ &\geq 1-\sqrt{2}\,C_{1}^{1/4}C_{2}^{-1/4}k^{1/4}\mathrm{e}^{-k/4},\end{split}

where the second term tends to zero as kâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘˜k\to\infty. Therefore

dHelâ€‹(QGPâ€‹(Yk),QGPâ€‹(Ykâ€²))â†’1Â asÂ kâ†’âˆformulae-sequenceâ†’subscriptğ‘‘Helsubscriptğ‘„GPsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘˜subscriptğ‘„GPsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘˜â€²1Â asÂ â†’ğ‘˜d_{\textup{Hel}}(Q_{\textup{GP}}(Y_{k}),Q_{\textup{GP}}(Y_{k}^{\prime}))\to 1\quad\text{ as }\quad k\to\infty

even though âˆ¥Ykâˆ’Ykâ€²âˆ¥â†’0â†’delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ‘Œğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘˜â€²0\mathinner{\lVert Y_{k}-Y_{k}^{\prime}\rVert}\to 0 as kâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘˜k\to\infty. This shows that the Lipschitz conditionÂ (2.17) fails to hold when the data domain is

â„›n={Yâˆˆâ„n:Yâ€‹Â is notÂ m-constantÂ }âŠ‚â„n,superscriptâ„›ğ‘›ğ‘Œsuperscriptâ„ğ‘›:ğ‘ŒÂ is notÂ m-constantÂ superscriptâ„ğ‘›\mathcal{R}^{n}=\{Y\in\mathbb{R}^{n}\,\mathrel{\mathop{\ordinarycolon}}\,Y\text{ is not $m$-constant }\}\subset\mathbb{R}^{n},

the set of data sets that are not mğ‘šm-constant. That is, we have shown that the mapping QGP:â„›nâ†’ğ’«:subscriptğ‘„GPâ†’superscriptâ„›ğ‘›ğ’«Q_{\textup{GP}}\colon\mathcal{R}^{n}\to\mathcal{P} defined inÂ (2.18) is not Lipschitz, where ğ’«ğ’«\mathcal{P} is the space of probability distributions on â„â„\mathbb{R} equipped with the Hellinger distance.

The above derivation is a consequence of the fact that, from TheoremÂ 2.3 and the interpretation inÂ (2.14),

PÎ»MLâ€‹(Y)â€‹(x0)2=0subscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğœ†MLğ‘Œsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥020P_{\lambda_{\textup{ML}}(Y)}(x_{0})^{2}=0

if the data Yğ‘ŒY are mğ‘šm-constant. Then for any data Yâ€²superscriptğ‘Œâ€²Y^{\prime} which are not mğ‘šm-constant we compute fromÂ (2.16) that

dHelâ€‹(QGPâ€‹(Y),QGPâ€‹(Yâ€²))=1,subscriptğ‘‘Helsubscriptğ‘„GPğ‘Œsubscriptğ‘„GPsuperscriptğ‘Œâ€²1d_{\textup{Hel}}(Q_{\textup{GP}}(Y),Q_{\textup{GP}}(Y^{\prime}))=1,

which means that the predictive distribution is not continuous at any data which are mğ‘šm-constant. Note that this is a purely formal computation becauseÂ (2.15) andÂ (2.16) are valid only for measures which are absolutely continuous with respect a common reference measure, which is not the case with the degenerate Gaussian predictive distribution Yğ‘ŒY that arises from mğ‘šm-constant data and the non-degenerate Gaussian Yâ€²superscriptğ‘Œâ€²Y^{\prime}. By observing that the argument above uses TheoremÂ 2.3 only to guarantee the existence of data Yğ‘ŒY for which Î»MLâ€‹(Y)=âˆsubscriptğœ†MLğ‘Œ\lambda_{\textup{ML}}(Y)=\infty, we may formulate the following generic ill-posedness theorem.

Theorem 2.7 (Ill-posedness)

Suppose that Kğ¾K satisfies AssumptionÂ 2.2 and nâ‰¥1ğ‘›1n\geq 1. Let Î»Â¯:â„nâ†’[0,âˆ]:Â¯ğœ†â†’superscriptâ„ğ‘›0\bar{\lambda}\colon\mathbb{R}^{n}\to[0,\infty] be any estimator of Î»ğœ†\lambda and define â„›n={Yâˆˆâ„n:Î»Â¯â€‹(Y)<âˆ}âŠ‚â„nsuperscriptâ„›ğ‘›ğ‘Œsuperscriptâ„ğ‘›:Â¯ğœ†ğ‘Œsuperscriptâ„ğ‘›\mathcal{R}^{n}=\{Y\in\mathbb{R}^{n}\,\mathrel{\mathop{\ordinarycolon}}\,\bar{\lambda}(Y)<\infty\}\subset\mathbb{R}^{n}. If there are data Yâˆˆâ„nğ‘Œsuperscriptâ„ğ‘›Y\in\mathbb{R}^{n} such that Î»Â¯â€‹(Y)=âˆÂ¯ğœ†ğ‘Œ\bar{\lambda}(Y)=\infty (i.e., â„›nâ‰ â„nsuperscriptâ„›ğ‘›superscriptâ„ğ‘›\mathcal{R}^{n}\neq\mathbb{R}^{n}), then Gaussian process interpolation is ill-posed, in the sense that the predictive distribution mapping QGP:â„›nâ†’ğ’«:subscriptğ‘„GPâ†’superscriptâ„›ğ‘›ğ’«Q_{\textup{GP}}\colon\mathcal{R}^{n}\to\mathcal{P} defined inÂ (2.18) is not Lipschitz for any x0âˆ‰Xsubscriptğ‘¥0ğ‘‹x_{0}\notin X.

The main message of TheoremÂ 2.7 is that a lengthscale estimator, whatever it might be, must be finite for any data in order for Gaussian process interpolation to be well-posed.

3 What Does Not Help

The Gaussian process model in TheoremÂ 2.3 is fairly simple, having a fixed prior mean function and a single estimated hyperparameter. One might hope that additional modelling choicesâ€”or the use of an altogether different parameter estimation methodâ€”would yield a well-posed Gaussian process model. In this section we show that this is not to be for several common approaches. Each theorem in this section shows that an estimator of Î»ğœ†\lambda is infinite if the data are mğ‘šm-constant, so that TheoremÂ 2.7 consequently establishes that Gaussian process interpolation is ill-posed.

3.1 Cross-Validation

Leave-one-out cross-validation is a popular alternative to maximum likelihood estimation that has been shown to confer robustness when the Gaussian process model is misspecifiedÂ (Bachoc, 2013). In Gaussian process interpolation the objective function that is typically used is

â„“CVâ€‹(Î¸âˆ£Y)=âˆ‘k=1n[(ykâˆ’Î¼Î¸,n,kâ€‹(xk)PÎ¸,n,kâ€‹(xk))2+logâ¡[PÎ¸,n,kâ€‹(xk)2]],subscriptâ„“CVconditionalğœƒğ‘Œsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ‘›delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘˜subscriptğœ‡ğœƒğ‘›ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘ƒğœƒğ‘›ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜2subscriptğ‘ƒğœƒğ‘›ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜2\ell_{\textup{CV}}(\theta\mid Y)=\sum_{k=1}^{n}\bigg{[}\bigg{(}\frac{y_{k}-\mu_{\theta,n,k}(x_{k})}{P_{\theta,n,k}(x_{k})}\bigg{)}^{2}+\log[P_{\theta,n,k}(x_{k})^{2}]\bigg{]}, (3.1)

where Î¼Î¸,n,k=m+sÎ¸,n,ksubscriptğœ‡ğœƒğ‘›ğ‘˜ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘ ğœƒğ‘›ğ‘˜\mu_{\theta,n,k}=m+s_{\theta,n,k} and PÎ¸,n,ksubscriptğ‘ƒğœƒğ‘›ğ‘˜P_{\theta,n,k} denote the Gaussian process conditional mean and standard deviation functions inÂ (2.4)â€“(2.6) based on data at the points Xâˆ–{xk}ğ‘‹subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜X\setminus\{x_{k}\}; see, for example, SectionÂ 4.2 in Currin etÂ al. (1988) or SectionÂ 5.4.1 in Rasmussen and Williams (2006). Subscripts are again used to make explicit the dependency of these functions on the kernel parameters Î¸ğœƒ\theta. Any corresponding parameter estimate Î¸CVsubscriptğœƒCV\theta_{\textup{CV}} satisfies

Î¸CVâˆˆargâ€‹minÎ¸âˆˆÎ˜â¡â„“CVâ€‹(Î¸âˆ£Y).subscriptğœƒCVsubscriptargminğœƒÎ˜subscriptâ„“CVconditionalğœƒğ‘Œ\theta_{\textup{CV}}\in\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{\theta\in\Theta}\ell_{\textup{CV}}(\theta\mid Y).

The cross-validation objective functionÂ (3.1) is obtained by summing negative predictive log-probabilities of yksubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘˜y_{k} given data at Xâˆ–{xk}ğ‘‹subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜X\setminus\{x_{k}\} and discarding terms which do not depend onÂ Î¸ğœƒ\theta. Unfortunately, leave-one-out cross-validation also fails to be well-posed. This may not be surprising given that there is a close connection between maximum likelihood estimation and cross-validationÂ (Fong and Holmes, 2020).

Theorem 3.1 (Cross-validation)

Suppose that Kğ¾K satisfies AssumptionÂ 2.2 and nâ‰¥2ğ‘›2n\geq 2. If the dataÂ Yğ‘ŒY are mğ‘šm-constant, then

limÎ»â†’âˆâ„“CVâ€‹(Î»âˆ£Y)=âˆ’âˆÂ andÂ Î»CV=âˆ.formulae-sequencesubscriptâ†’ğœ†subscriptâ„“CVconditionalğœ†ğ‘ŒÂ andÂ subscriptğœ†CV\lim_{\lambda\to\infty}\ell_{\textup{CV}}(\lambda\mid Y)=-\infty\quad\text{ and }\quad\lambda_{\textup{CV}}=\infty. (3.2)

ProofÂ  See SectionÂ 7.6. Despite the ostensibly different forms of the objective functionsÂ (2.8) andÂ (3.1), the proof is, in consequence of PropositionÂ 7.5, in essence all but identical to the proof of EquationÂ 2.11 in TheoremÂ 2.3. Â 

We believe that â„“CVâ€‹(Î»âˆ£Y)subscriptâ„“CVconditionalğœ†ğ‘Œ\ell_{\textup{CV}}(\lambda\mid Y) and Î»CVsubscriptğœ†CV\lambda_{\textup{CV}} satisfy a version of EquationÂ 2.12 if the data are not mğ‘šm-constant but have been unable to furnish a proof; see RemarkÂ 7.8.

Remark 3.2

A non-probabilistic alternative toÂ (3.1) is to simply minimise the sum of squared leave-one-out errorsÂ (e.g., Rippa, 1999):

â„“CVâ€‹(2)â€‹(Î¸âˆ£Y)=âˆ‘k=1n(ykâˆ’Î¼Î¸,n,kâ€‹(xk))2â‰¥0Â andÂ Î¸CVâ€‹(2)âˆˆargâ€‹minÎ¸âˆˆÎ˜â¡â„“CVâ€‹(2)â€‹(Î¸âˆ£Y).formulae-sequencesubscriptâ„“CV2conditionalğœƒğ‘Œsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘˜subscriptğœ‡ğœƒğ‘›ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜20Â andÂ subscriptğœƒCV2subscriptargminğœƒÎ˜subscriptâ„“CV2conditionalğœƒğ‘Œ\ell_{\textup{CV}(2)}(\theta\mid Y)=\sum_{k=1}^{n}(y_{k}-\mu_{\theta,n,k}(x_{k}))^{2}\geq 0\quad\text{ and }\quad\theta_{\textup{CV}(2)}\in\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{\theta\in\Theta}\ell_{\textup{CV}(2)}(\theta\mid Y).

Consider estimating the lengthscale parameter Î»ğœ†\lambda using this procedure. If the data Yğ‘ŒY are mğ‘šm-constant such that Ym=Yâˆ’mâ€‹(X)=(c,â€¦,c)subscriptğ‘Œğ‘šğ‘Œğ‘šğ‘‹ğ‘â€¦ğ‘Y_{m}=Y-m(X)=(c,\ldots,c), it follows from TheoremÂ 2.6 that Î¼Î»,n,ksubscriptğœ‡ğœ†ğ‘›ğ‘˜\mu_{\lambda,n,k} tends pointwise to m+cğ‘šğ‘m+c as Î»â†’âˆâ†’ğœ†\lambda\to\infty if Kğ¾K satisfies AssumptionÂ 2.2. Therefore

limÎ»â†’âˆâ„“CVâ€‹(2)â€‹(Î»âˆ£Y)=limÎ»â†’âˆâˆ‘k=1n(mâ€‹(xk)+câˆ’Î¼Î»,n,kâ€‹(xk))2=0,subscriptâ†’ğœ†subscriptâ„“CV2conditionalğœ†ğ‘Œsubscriptâ†’ğœ†superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ‘›superscriptğ‘šsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜ğ‘subscriptğœ‡ğœ†ğ‘›ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜20\lim_{\lambda\to\infty}\ell_{\textup{CV}(2)}(\lambda\mid Y)=\lim_{\lambda\to\infty}\sum_{k=1}^{n}(m(x_{k})+c-\mu_{\lambda,n,k}(x_{k}))^{2}=0,

from which it follows that Î»CVâ€‹(2)=âˆsubscriptğœ†CV2\lambda_{\textup{CV}(2)}=\infty, or at least that â„“CVâ€‹(2)â€‹(Î»âˆ£Y)subscriptâ„“CV2conditionalğœ†ğ‘Œ\ell_{\textup{CV}(2)}(\lambda\mid Y) has one of its minima at infinity. Therefore also this procedure is ill-posed.

3.2 Unknown Parametric Prior Mean

So far we have considered a setting where the prior mean function mğ‘šm is known and fixed. But in methods such as universal kriging the mean is assumed to be an unknown element of the linear span of a finite number of basis functions, typically polynomials, and its coefficients are estimated from the data. See, for example, Oâ€™Hagan (1978) or ChaptersÂ 3 andÂ 4 in Santner etÂ al. (2003).

Let the basis functions be Ï†1,â€¦,Ï†qsubscriptğœ‘1â€¦subscriptğœ‘ğ‘\varphi_{1},\ldots,\varphi_{q} for qâ‰¤nğ‘ğ‘›q\leq n and define the matrix Vâ€‹(X)âˆˆâ„nÃ—qğ‘‰ğ‘‹superscriptâ„ğ‘›ğ‘{V(X)\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times q}} with elements

(Vâ€‹(X))i,j=Ï†jâ€‹(xi).subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘‹ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğœ‘ğ‘—subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–(V(X))_{i,j}=\varphi_{j}(x_{i}).

Suppose that the mean function is m=âˆ‘j=1qÎ²jâ€‹Ï†jğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ‘subscriptğ›½ğ‘—subscriptğœ‘ğ‘—m=\sum_{j=1}^{q}\beta_{j}\varphi_{j} for unknown coefficients Î²=(Î²1,â€¦,Î²q)ğ›½subscriptğ›½1â€¦subscriptğ›½ğ‘\beta=(\beta_{1},\ldots,\beta_{q}) which we wish to estimate using maximum likelihood. The full modified log-likelihood function for both the kernel parameters Î¸ğœƒ\theta and the coefficients Î²ğ›½\beta is obtained by inserting the parametric prior mean inÂ (2.8):

â„“â€‹(Î¸,Î²âˆ£Y)=(Yâˆ’Vâ€‹(X)â€‹Î²)ğ–³â€‹KÎ¸â€‹(X,X)âˆ’1â€‹(Yâˆ’Vâ€‹(X)â€‹Î²)+logâ€‹detKÎ¸â€‹(X,X).â„“ğœƒconditionalğ›½ğ‘Œsuperscriptğ‘Œğ‘‰ğ‘‹ğ›½ğ–³subscriptğ¾ğœƒsuperscriptğ‘‹ğ‘‹1ğ‘Œğ‘‰ğ‘‹ğ›½subscriptğ¾ğœƒğ‘‹ğ‘‹\ell(\theta,\beta\mid Y)=(Y-V(X)\beta)^{\mathsf{T}}K_{\theta}(X,X)^{-1}(Y-V(X)\beta)+\log\det K_{\theta}(X,X). (3.3)

Any maximum likelihood estimates satisfy

{Î¸ML,Î²ML}âˆˆargâ€‹minÎ¸âˆˆÎ˜,Î²âˆˆâ„qâ¡â„“â€‹(Î¸,Î²âˆ£Y).subscriptğœƒMLsubscriptğ›½MLsubscriptargminformulae-sequenceğœƒÎ˜ğ›½superscriptâ„ğ‘â„“ğœƒconditionalğ›½ğ‘Œ\{\theta_{\textup{ML}},\beta_{\textup{ML}}\}\in\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{\theta\in\Theta,\,\beta\in\mathbb{R}^{q}}\ell(\theta,\beta\mid Y).

The natural generalisation of DefinitionÂ 2.1 to this setting is that there exist some coefficients for which the data are mğ‘šm-constant. That is, that there exist constants cğ‘c and Î²âˆ—=(Î²1âˆ—,â€¦,Î²qâˆ—)superscriptğ›½superscriptsubscriptğ›½1â€¦superscriptsubscriptğ›½ğ‘\beta^{*}=(\beta_{1}^{*},\ldots,\beta_{q}^{*}) (which need not be unique) such that

yiâˆ’âˆ‘j=1qÎ²jâˆ—â€‹Ï†jâ€‹(xi)=cÂ for everyÂ i=1,â€¦,n.formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ›½ğ‘—subscriptğœ‘ğ‘—subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘Â for everyÂ ğ‘–1â€¦ğ‘›y_{i}-\sum_{j=1}^{q}\beta_{j}^{*}\varphi_{j}(x_{i})=c\quad\text{ for every }\quad i=1,\ldots,n. (3.4)

The next theorem shows that the maximum likelihood estimate of the lengthscale parameterÂ Î»ğœ†\lambda is badly behaved if the data satisfy the above assumption.

Theorem 3.3

Suppose that Kğ¾K satisfies AssumptionÂ 2.2 and nâ‰¥2ğ‘›2n\geq 2. If the data Yğ‘ŒY satisfyÂ (3.4), then

Î»ML=âˆÂ ifÂ {Î»ML,Î²ML}âˆˆargâ€‹minÎ»>0,Î²âˆˆâ„qâ¡â„“â€‹(Î»,Î²âˆ£Y).formulae-sequencesubscriptğœ†MLÂ ifÂ subscriptğœ†MLsubscriptğ›½MLsubscriptargminformulae-sequenceğœ†0ğ›½superscriptâ„ğ‘â„“ğœ†conditionalğ›½ğ‘Œ\lambda_{\textup{ML}}=\infty\quad\text{ if }\quad\{\lambda_{\textup{ML}},\beta_{\textup{ML}}\}\in\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{\lambda>0,\,\beta\in\mathbb{R}^{q}}\ell(\lambda,\beta\mid Y).

ProofÂ  See SectionÂ 7.6. The proof is similar to that of EquationÂ 2.11 in TheoremÂ 2.3. Â 

Remark 3.4

If the matrix Vâ€‹(X)ğ‘‰ğ‘‹V(X) has full rank, one can compute that

Î²ML=[Vâ€‹(X)ğ–³â€‹KÎ¸â€‹(X,X)âˆ’1â€‹Vâ€‹(X)]âˆ’1â€‹Vâ€‹(X)ğ–³â€‹KÎ¸â€‹(X,X)âˆ’1â€‹Ysubscriptğ›½MLsuperscriptdelimited-[]ğ‘‰superscriptğ‘‹ğ–³subscriptğ¾ğœƒsuperscriptğ‘‹ğ‘‹1ğ‘‰ğ‘‹1ğ‘‰superscriptğ‘‹ğ–³subscriptğ¾ğœƒsuperscriptğ‘‹ğ‘‹1ğ‘Œ\beta_{\textup{ML}}=\big{[}V(X)^{\mathsf{T}}K_{\theta}(X,X)^{-1}V(X)\big{]}^{-1}V(X)^{\mathsf{T}}K_{\theta}(X,X)^{-1}Y

for any fixed Î¸ğœƒ\theta. If q=nğ‘ğ‘›q=n, the matrix Vâ€‹(X)ğ‘‰ğ‘‹V(X) is square and non-singular so that the above maximum likelihood estimate simplifies to Î²ML=Vâ€‹(X)âˆ’1â€‹Ysubscriptğ›½MLğ‘‰superscriptğ‘‹1ğ‘Œ\beta_{\textup{ML}}=V(X)^{-1}Y. Inserting this toÂ (3.3) eliminates the data-fit term and we are left with â„“â€‹(Î¸,Î²MLâˆ£Y)=logâ€‹detKÎ¸â€‹(X,X)â„“ğœƒconditionalsubscriptğ›½MLğ‘Œsubscriptğ¾ğœƒğ‘‹ğ‘‹\ell(\theta,\beta_{\textup{ML}}\mid Y)=\log\det K_{\theta}(X,X). The maximum likelihood estimate of Î¸ğœƒ\theta is therefore obtained by minimising complexity of the model. If Î¸=Î»ğœƒğœ†\theta=\lambda, this naturally leads to Î»ML=âˆsubscriptğœ†ML\lambda_{\textup{ML}}=\infty since this is the only value of the lengthscale parameter for which the covariance matrix becomes singular. The interpretation of this phenomenon is that maximum likelihood estimation picks the simplest possible model if the data are fully explained by the prior mean.

3.3 Simultaneous Estimation of the Scaling Parameter

One typically estimates the lengthscale parameter simultaneously with the scale or magnitude parameter Ïƒ>0ğœ0\sigma>0. Suppose that Î¸={Î»,Ïƒ}ğœƒğœ†ğœ\theta=\{\lambda,\sigma\} and the covariance kernel is parametrised as KÎ¸â€‹(x,y)=Ïƒ2â€‹KÎ»â€‹(x,y)subscriptğ¾ğœƒğ‘¥ğ‘¦superscriptğœ2subscriptğ¾ğœ†ğ‘¥ğ‘¦K_{\theta}(x,y)=\sigma^{2}K_{\lambda}(x,y). Then

â„“â€‹(Î»,Ïƒâˆ£Y)=1Ïƒ2â€‹Ymğ–³â€‹KÎ»â€‹(X,X)âˆ’1â€‹Ym+logâ€‹detKÎ»â€‹(X,X)+nâ€‹logâ¡Ïƒ2â„“ğœ†conditionalğœğ‘Œ1superscriptğœ2superscriptsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘šğ–³subscriptğ¾ğœ†superscriptğ‘‹ğ‘‹1subscriptğ‘Œğ‘šsubscriptğ¾ğœ†ğ‘‹ğ‘‹ğ‘›superscriptğœ2\ell(\lambda,\sigma\mid Y)=\frac{1}{\sigma^{2}}Y_{m}^{\mathsf{T}}K_{\lambda}(X,X)^{-1}Y_{m}+\log\det K_{\lambda}(X,X)+n\log\sigma^{2}

and maximum likelihood estimates satisfy

{Î»ML,ÏƒML}âˆˆargâ€‹minÏƒ,Î»>0â¡â„“â€‹(Î»,Ïƒâˆ£Y).subscriptğœ†MLsubscriptğœMLsubscriptargminğœğœ†0â„“ğœ†conditionalğœğ‘Œ\{\lambda_{\textup{ML}},\sigma_{\textup{ML}}\}\in\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{\sigma,\lambda>0}\ell(\lambda,\sigma\mid Y). (3.5)

Unfortunately, the behaviour of the maximum likelihood estimate Î»MLsubscriptğœ†ML\lambda_{\textup{ML}} is identical to the case in TheoremÂ 2.3 where Ïƒğœ\sigma is held fixed. Let ÏƒMLâ€‹(Î»)subscriptğœMLğœ†\sigma_{\textup{ML}}(\lambda) denote the maximum likelihood estimate of Ïƒğœ\sigma for a fixed Î»>0ğœ†0\lambda>0.

Theorem 3.5 (Simultaneous estimation)

Suppose that Kğ¾K satisfies AssumptionÂ 2.2 and nâ‰¥2ğ‘›2n\geq 2. Consider the maximum likelihood estimates inÂ (3.5). If the data Yğ‘ŒY are mğ‘šm-constant and Ymâ‰ 0subscriptğ‘Œğ‘š0Y_{m}\neq 0, then

limÎ»â†’âˆâ„“â€‹(Î»,ÏƒMLâ€‹(Î»)âˆ£Y)=âˆ’âˆÂ andÂ Î»ML=âˆ.formulae-sequencesubscriptâ†’ğœ†â„“ğœ†conditionalsubscriptğœMLğœ†ğ‘ŒÂ andÂ subscriptğœ†ML\lim_{\lambda\to\infty}\ell(\lambda,\sigma_{\textup{ML}}(\lambda)\mid Y)=-\infty\quad\text{ and }\quad\lambda_{\textup{ML}}=\infty.

ProofÂ  See SectionÂ 7.6. The proof does not fundamentally differ from that of TheoremÂ 2.3. Â 

If it happens that Ym=0subscriptğ‘Œğ‘š0Y_{m}=0, the modified log-likelihood function is simply

â„“â€‹(Î»,Ïƒâˆ£Y)=logâ€‹detKÎ»â€‹(X,X)+nâ€‹logâ¡Ïƒ2.â„“ğœ†conditionalğœğ‘Œsubscriptğ¾ğœ†ğ‘‹ğ‘‹ğ‘›superscriptğœ2\ell(\lambda,\sigma\mid Y)=\log\det K_{\lambda}(X,X)+n\log\sigma^{2}.

Then â„“â€‹(Î»,Ïƒâˆ£Y)=âˆ’âˆâ„“ğœ†conditionalğœğ‘Œ\ell(\lambda,\sigma\mid Y)=-\infty if and only if Î»â†’âˆâ†’ğœ†\lambda\to\infty or Ïƒâ†’0â†’ğœ0\sigma\to 0. Either of these cases results zero conditional variance and degenerate predictive distributions.

4 Regularisation

This section discusses two types of regularisation that can be used to ensure the well-posedness of Gaussian process regression or finiteness of a lengthscale estimator. However, these approaches may induce unwanted side effects and are, to some extent, arbitrary.

4.1 Regularisation via Observation Noise

Let Î´>0ğ›¿0\delta>0 be a regularisation parameter (alternatively, smoothing parameter, nugget or jitter). Denote the nÃ—nğ‘›ğ‘›n\times n identity matrix with Insubscriptğ¼ğ‘›I_{n}. The regularised versions of the Gaussian process conditional mean and covariance inÂ (2.4) andÂ (2.5) are

Î¼Î´â€‹(x)superscriptğœ‡ğ›¿ğ‘¥\displaystyle\mu^{\delta}(x) =mâ€‹(x)+Kâ€‹(x,X)ğ–³â€‹(Kâ€‹(X,X)+Î´2â€‹In)âˆ’1â€‹Ym,absentğ‘šğ‘¥ğ¾superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘‹ğ–³superscriptğ¾ğ‘‹ğ‘‹superscriptğ›¿2subscriptğ¼ğ‘›1subscriptğ‘Œğ‘š\displaystyle=m(x)+K(x,X)^{\mathsf{T}}(K(X,X)+\delta^{2}I_{n})^{-1}Y_{m},
PÎ´â€‹(x,y)2superscriptğ‘ƒğ›¿superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¦2\displaystyle P^{\delta}(x,y)^{2} =Kâ€‹(x,y)âˆ’Kâ€‹(x,X)ğ–³â€‹(Kâ€‹(X,X)+Î´2â€‹In)âˆ’1â€‹Kâ€‹(X,y)absentğ¾ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ¾superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘‹ğ–³superscriptğ¾ğ‘‹ğ‘‹superscriptğ›¿2subscriptğ¼ğ‘›1ğ¾ğ‘‹ğ‘¦\displaystyle=K(x,y)-K(x,X)^{\mathsf{T}}(K(X,X)+\delta^{2}I_{n})^{-1}K(X,y)

and that of the modified log-likelihood function is

â„“Î´â€‹(Î»âˆ£Y)=Ymğ–³â€‹(KÎ»â€‹(X,X)+Î´2â€‹In)âˆ’1â€‹Ym+logâ€‹det(KÎ»â€‹(X,X)+Î´2â€‹In).superscriptâ„“ğ›¿conditionalğœ†ğ‘Œsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘šğ–³superscriptsubscriptğ¾ğœ†ğ‘‹ğ‘‹superscriptğ›¿2subscriptğ¼ğ‘›1subscriptğ‘Œğ‘šsubscriptğ¾ğœ†ğ‘‹ğ‘‹superscriptğ›¿2subscriptğ¼ğ‘›\ell^{\delta}(\lambda\mid Y)=Y_{m}^{\mathsf{T}}(K_{\lambda}(X,X)+\delta^{2}I_{n})^{-1}Y_{m}+\log\det(K_{\lambda}(X,X)+\delta^{2}I_{n}). (4.1)

In this section every quantity which is superscripted with Î´ğ›¿\delta stands for the corresponding quantity defined in SectionÂ 2 but with Kâ€‹(X,X)ğ¾ğ‘‹ğ‘‹K(X,X) replaced by Kâ€‹(X,X)+Î´2â€‹Inğ¾ğ‘‹ğ‘‹superscriptğ›¿2subscriptğ¼ğ‘›K(X,X)+\delta^{2}I_{n}. Although the above expressions arise from assuming that the data are corrupted by additive and independent zero-mean Gaussian noise terms with variances Î´2superscriptğ›¿2\delta^{2}, regularisation is often used purely out of convenience (that is, even when one does not believe that the data are noisy) as it improves the condition number of the covariance matrix that needs to be invertedÂ (e.g., Ranjan etÂ al., 2011; Adrianakis and Challenor, 2012).

Because (Kâ€‹(X,X)+Î´2â€‹In)âˆ’1<Kâ€‹(X,X)âˆ’1superscriptğ¾ğ‘‹ğ‘‹superscriptğ›¿2subscriptğ¼ğ‘›1ğ¾superscriptğ‘‹ğ‘‹1(K(X,X)+\delta^{2}I_{n})^{-1}<K(X,X)^{-1} in the Loewner ordering of positive-semidefinite matrices, we easily derive that the regularised conditional variance is everywhere positive:

PÎ´â€‹(x)2=PÎ´â€‹(x,x)2>Pâ€‹(x)2â‰¥0Â for everyÂ xâˆˆâ„d.formulae-sequencesuperscriptğ‘ƒğ›¿superscriptğ‘¥2superscriptğ‘ƒğ›¿superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¥2ğ‘ƒsuperscriptğ‘¥20Â for everyÂ ğ‘¥superscriptâ„ğ‘‘P^{\delta}(x)^{2}=P^{\delta}(x,x)^{2}>P(x)^{2}\geq 0\quad\text{ for every }\quad x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}.

Consider then the lengthscale parameter Î»ğœ†\lambda and the corresponding kernel KÎ»subscriptğ¾ğœ†K_{\lambda} and assume for simplicity that KÎ»â€‹(x,y)â†’1â†’subscriptğ¾ğœ†ğ‘¥ğ‘¦1K_{\lambda}(x,y)\to 1 as Î»â†’âˆâ†’ğœ†\lambda\to\infty for all x,yâˆˆÎ©ğ‘¥ğ‘¦Î©x,y\in\Omega. Then it is straightforward to use the Shermanâ€“Morrison formula to compute that

limÎ»â†’âˆPÎ»Î´â€‹(x)2=limÎ»â†’âˆ[KÎ»â€‹(x,y)âˆ’KÎ»â€‹(x,X)ğ–³â€‹(KÎ»â€‹(X,X)+Î´2â€‹In)âˆ’1â€‹KÎ»â€‹(x,X)]=11+nâ€‹Î´âˆ’2subscriptâ†’ğœ†superscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒğœ†ğ›¿superscriptğ‘¥2subscriptâ†’ğœ†delimited-[]subscriptğ¾ğœ†ğ‘¥ğ‘¦subscriptğ¾ğœ†superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘‹ğ–³superscriptsubscriptğ¾ğœ†ğ‘‹ğ‘‹superscriptğ›¿2subscriptğ¼ğ‘›1subscriptğ¾ğœ†ğ‘¥ğ‘‹11ğ‘›superscriptğ›¿2\lim_{\lambda\to\infty}P_{\lambda}^{\delta}(x)^{2}=\lim_{\lambda\to\infty}\big{[}K_{\lambda}(x,y)-K_{\lambda}(x,X)^{\mathsf{T}}(K_{\lambda}(X,X)+\delta^{2}I_{n})^{-1}K_{\lambda}(x,X)\big{]}=\frac{1}{1+n\delta^{-2}}

and

limÎ»â†’âˆÎ¼Î»Î´â€‹(x)=mâ€‹(x)+Î´âˆ’21+nâ€‹Î´âˆ’2â€‹âˆ‘i=1n(yiâˆ’mâ€‹(xi))subscriptâ†’ğœ†superscriptsubscriptğœ‡ğœ†ğ›¿ğ‘¥ğ‘šğ‘¥superscriptğ›¿21ğ‘›superscriptğ›¿2superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–\lim_{\lambda\to\infty}\mu_{\lambda}^{\delta}(x)=m(x)+\frac{\delta^{-2}}{1+n\delta^{-2}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}(y_{i}-m(x_{i}))

for any xâˆˆâ„dğ‘¥superscriptâ„ğ‘‘x\in\mathbb{R}^{d} and Ymâˆˆâ„nsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘šsuperscriptâ„ğ‘›Y_{m}\in\mathbb{R}^{n}. These estimates and computations establish that under regularisation no finite-dimensional distribution of the conditional Gaussian process can tend to a degenerate Gaussian as Î»ğœ†\lambda varies. It follows that regularised Gaussian process interpolation is well-posed in the sense discussed in SectionÂ 2.4 as long as the estimator of Î»ğœ†\lambda is continuous in the data. However, the price one pays for vanquishing ill-conditioning is that the conditional mean no longer interpolates the data, which may be undesirable in applications where the data are truly noiseless, and that an additional degree of freedom is introduced. Favorable convergence rates of Gaussian process interpolation (asymptotically as nâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘›n\to\infty) are also lost under regularisation unless one has the regularisation parameter tend to zero with an appropriate rateÂ (Wendland and Rieger, 2005, SectionÂ 3).

Even though maximum likelihood estimation of Î»ğœ†\lambda cannot cause ill-posedness in the regularised setting (assuming the estimator is continuous in the data), there remains the interesting question of how Î»MLÎ´superscriptsubscriptğœ†MLğ›¿\lambda_{\textup{ML}}^{\delta}, as computed by minimising the regularised modified log-likelihood function inÂ (4.1), behaves if the data are mğ‘šm-constant. Our attempts at proving any properties of Î»MLÎ´superscriptsubscriptğœ†MLğ›¿\lambda_{\textup{ML}}^{\delta} have been unsuccessful, and therefore here we limit ourselves to a simple numerical investigation, the results of which are depicted in FigureÂ 4. This figure plots

Î»MLÎ´=argâ€‹minÎ»>0â¡â„“Î´â€‹(Î»âˆ£Y)superscriptsubscriptğœ†MLğ›¿subscriptargminğœ†0superscriptâ„“ğ›¿conditionalğœ†ğ‘Œ\lambda_{\textup{ML}}^{\delta}=\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{\lambda>0}\ell^{\delta}(\lambda\mid Y) (4.2)

as a function of Î´>0ğ›¿0\delta>0 for four different data vectors Yâˆˆâ„3ğ‘Œsuperscriptâ„3Y\in\mathbb{R}^{3} (we set mâ‰¡0ğ‘š0m\equiv 0) when X={1,1.2,2.0}âŠ‚â„ğ‘‹11.22.0â„X=\{1,1.2,2.0\}\subset\mathbb{R} and Kğ¾K is the MatÃ©rn kernel inÂ (2.3) with parameters Ïƒ=1ğœ1\sigma=1 and Î½=3/2ğœˆ32\nu=3/2. Minimisation was performed using grid search. It appears that for each data set the maximum likelihood estimate Î»MLÎ´superscriptsubscriptğœ†MLğ›¿\lambda_{\textup{ML}}^{\delta} has a singularity at a certain value Î´âˆsubscriptğ›¿\delta_{\infty} of Î´ğ›¿\delta and that Î´âˆsubscriptğ›¿\delta_{\infty} is smaller when the data Yğ‘ŒY are closer to being constant. This suggests that, for a sufficiently large Î´ğ›¿\delta, maximum likelihood estimation always reverts to the simplest possible model, that obtained with Î»=âˆğœ†\lambda=\infty. One way to interpret this observation is that any given data set could have been plausibly generated by a constant function if the data set is assumed to be corrupted by Gaussian noise with sufficiently large variance (i.e., if Î´2superscriptğ›¿2\delta^{2} is sufficiently large).

4.2 Regularisation via Lengthscale Hyperprior

Suppose that a prior with a density function pğ‘p is placed on the parameters Î¸ğœƒ\theta. Then the posterior for Î¸ğœƒ\theta has the log-density

logâ¡pâ€‹(Î¸âˆ£Y)=âˆ’12â€‹â„“â€‹(Î¸âˆ£Y)+logâ¡pâ€‹(Î¸)+constant,ğ‘conditionalğœƒğ‘Œ12â„“conditionalğœƒğ‘Œğ‘ğœƒconstant\log p(\theta\mid Y)=-\frac{1}{2}\ell(\theta\mid Y)+\log p(\theta)+\text{constant},

where â„“â€‹(Î¸âˆ£Y)â„“conditionalğœƒğ‘Œ\ell(\theta\mid Y) is the modified log-likelihood function inÂ (2.8). Any maximiser Î¸MAPsubscriptğœƒMAP\theta_{\textup{MAP}} of the posterior density is called a maximum a posteriori (MAP) estimate of Î¸ğœƒ\theta. Equivalently,

Î¸MAPâˆˆargâ€‹minÎ¸âˆˆÎ˜â¡â„“MAPâ€‹(Î¸âˆ£Y)Â forÂ â„“MAPâ€‹(Î¸âˆ£Y)=12â€‹â„“â€‹(Î¸âˆ£Y)âˆ’logâ¡pâ€‹(Î¸).formulae-sequencesubscriptğœƒMAPsubscriptargminğœƒÎ˜subscriptâ„“MAPconditionalğœƒğ‘ŒÂ forÂ subscriptâ„“MAPconditionalğœƒğ‘Œ12â„“conditionalğœƒğ‘Œğ‘ğœƒ\theta_{\textup{MAP}}\in\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{\theta\in\Theta}\ell_{\textup{MAP}}(\theta\mid Y)\quad\text{ for }\quad\ell_{\textup{MAP}}(\theta\mid Y)=\frac{1}{2}\ell(\theta\mid Y)-\log p(\theta). (4.3)

The following theorem shows that assigning a non-heavy-tailed hyperprior on the lengthscaleÂ Î»ğœ†\lambda ensures that its MAP estimate is finite regardless of the data.

Theorem 4.1

Suppose that Kğ¾K satisfies AssumptionÂ 2.2, nâ‰¥1ğ‘›1n\geq 1, and

Î»(Î±âˆ’d/2)â€‹nâ€‹pâ€‹(Î»)â†’0Â asÂ Î»â†’âˆ,formulae-sequenceâ†’superscriptğœ†ğ›¼ğ‘‘2ğ‘›ğ‘ğœ†0Â asÂ â†’ğœ†\lambda^{(\alpha-d/2)n}p(\lambda)\to 0\quad\text{ as }\quad\lambda\to\infty, (4.4)

where Î±>d/2ğ›¼ğ‘‘2\alpha>d/2 is the constant in AssumptionÂ 2.2. If Yâˆˆâ„nğ‘Œsuperscriptâ„ğ‘›Y\in\mathbb{R}^{n} are any data, then

limÎ»â†’âˆâ„“MAPâ€‹(Î»âˆ£Y)=âˆÂ andÂ Î»MAP<âˆ.formulae-sequencesubscriptâ†’ğœ†subscriptâ„“MAPconditionalğœ†ğ‘ŒÂ andÂ subscriptğœ†MAP\lim_{\lambda\to\infty}\ell_{\textup{MAP}}(\lambda\mid Y)=\infty\quad\text{ and }\quad\lambda_{\textup{MAP}}<\infty.

ProofÂ  See SectionÂ 7.7. The essence of the proof is that the assumption on tail decay of pğ‘p ensures that âˆ’logâ¡pâ€‹(Î»)ğ‘ğœ†-\log p(\lambda) dominates â„“MAPâ€‹(Î»âˆ£Y)subscriptâ„“MAPconditionalğœ†ğ‘Œ\ell_{\textup{MAP}}(\lambda\mid Y) as Î»â†’âˆâ†’ğœ†\lambda\to\infty. Â 

Because, for fixed Yğ‘ŒY, the choice of the hyperprior pğ‘p completely determines the estimator, MAP estimation is rather arbitrary and not well-suited to deployment in general-purpose software.

5 Generalisations and Extensions

This section discusses some generalisations of TheoremÂ 2.3 for (a) general linear data, (b) lengthscale estimation for product kernels, and (c) kernels which do not satisfy the Fourier decay assumption inÂ (2.9).

5.1 Linear Information and General Kernels

In this section we generalise part of TheoremÂ 2.3 by replacing the domain â„dsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbb{R}^{d} with an arbitrary vector space Î©Î©\Omega, using a more liberal definition of a lengthscale parameter, and considering general linear data, such as derivative evaluations. Though somewhat technical, the assumptions that this generalisation requires can be verified in some settings of practical interest.

Let Î©Î©\Omega be a vector space and KÎ¸:Î©Ã—Î©â†’â„:subscriptğ¾ğœƒâ†’Î©Î©â„K_{\theta}\colon\Omega\times\Omega\to\mathbb{R} a positive-definite kernel on Î©Î©\Omega for each Î¸âˆˆÎ˜ğœƒÎ˜\theta\in\Theta. We use Hâ€‹(KÎ¸,Î©)ğ»subscriptğ¾ğœƒÎ©H(K_{\theta},\Omega) to denote the RKHS of KÎ¸subscriptğ¾ğœƒK_{\theta} on Î©Î©\Omega; see SectionÂ 7.1 for details. Let Fâ€‹(Î©)ğ¹Î©F(\Omega) be a set of real-valued functions defined on Î©Î©\Omega which contains Hâ€‹(KÎ¸,Î©)ğ»subscriptğ¾ğœƒÎ©H(K_{\theta},\Omega) for every Î¸âˆˆÎ˜ğœƒÎ˜\theta\in\Theta as well as all constant functions and the prior mean function mğ‘šm. Let â„’={L1,â€¦,Ln}â„’subscriptğ¿1â€¦subscriptğ¿ğ‘›\mathcal{L}=\{L_{1},\ldots,L_{n}\} be a collection of nâ‰¥2ğ‘›2n\geq 2 non-trivial (i.e., none of them is the zero functional) linear information functionals defined on Fâ€‹(Î©)ğ¹Î©F(\Omega). These functionals are assumed to be linearly independent and bounded on Hâ€‹(KÎ¸,Î©)ğ»subscriptğ¾ğœƒÎ©H(K_{\theta},\Omega) for every Î¸âˆˆÎ˜ğœƒÎ˜\theta\in\Theta, in that there is CÎ¸>0subscriptğ¶ğœƒ0C_{\theta}>0 such that |Liâ€‹(f)|â‰¤CÎ¸â€‹âˆ¥fâˆ¥Hâ€‹(KÎ¸,Î©)subscriptğ¿ğ‘–ğ‘“subscriptğ¶ğœƒsubscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ‘“ğ»subscriptğ¾ğœƒÎ©\mathinner{\lvert L_{i}(f)\rvert}\leq C_{\theta}\mathinner{\lVert f\rVert}_{H(K_{\theta},\Omega)} for every fâˆˆHâ€‹(KÎ¸,Î©)ğ‘“ğ»subscriptğ¾ğœƒÎ©f\in H(K_{\theta},\Omega). We assume that the data

Yâ„’=(L1â€‹f,â€¦,Lnâ€‹f)âˆˆâ„nsubscriptğ‘Œâ„’subscriptğ¿1ğ‘“â€¦subscriptğ¿ğ‘›ğ‘“superscriptâ„ğ‘›Y_{\mathcal{L}}=(L_{1}f,\ldots,L_{n}f)\in\mathbb{R}^{n} (5.1)

consist of applications of the information functionals to an underlying (and unknown) data-generating function fâˆˆFâ€‹(Î©)ğ‘“ğ¹Î©f\in F(\Omega). The setting considered earlier in this article is recovered by selecting the point evaluation functionals defined as Liâ€‹f=fâ€‹(xi)subscriptğ¿ğ‘–ğ‘“ğ‘“subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–L_{i}f=f(x_{i}). Partial derivative data, defined by Liâ€‹f=âˆ‚pifâ€‹(xi)subscriptğ¿ğ‘–ğ‘“subscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘“subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–L_{i}f=\partial_{p_{i}}f(x_{i}) for some xiâˆˆÎ©subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–Î©x_{i}\in\Omega and piâ‰¥0subscriptğ‘ğ‘–0p_{i}\geq 0, also occurs commonly in Gaussian process applicationsÂ (e.g., Solak etÂ al., 2002). If necessary to avoid ambiguity, we use superscripts to denote the argument with respect to which an information functional is to be applied.

Let â„’â€‹(m)=(Liâ€‹m)i=1nâˆˆâ„nâ„’ğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ¿ğ‘–ğ‘šğ‘–1ğ‘›superscriptâ„ğ‘›\mathcal{L}(m)=(L_{i}m)_{i=1}^{n}\in\mathbb{R}^{n} and set Yâ„’,m=Yâ„’âˆ’â„’â€‹(m)âˆˆâ„nsubscriptğ‘Œâ„’ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘Œâ„’â„’ğ‘šsuperscriptâ„ğ‘›Y_{\mathcal{L},m}=Y_{\mathcal{L}}-\mathcal{L}(m)\in\mathbb{R}^{n}. Also set

KÎ¸â€‹(â„’,â„’)=(Lixâ€‹Ljyâ€‹KÎ¸â€‹(x,y))i,j=1nâˆˆâ„nÃ—nÂ andÂ KÎ¸â€‹(â„’,x)=(Liâ€‹KÎ¸â€‹(â‹…,x))i=1nâˆˆâ„n,formulae-sequencesubscriptğ¾ğœƒâ„’â„’superscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğ¿ğ‘–ğ‘¥superscriptsubscriptğ¿ğ‘—ğ‘¦subscriptğ¾ğœƒğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘–ğ‘—1ğ‘›superscriptâ„ğ‘›ğ‘›Â andÂ subscriptğ¾ğœƒâ„’ğ‘¥superscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ¿ğ‘–subscriptğ¾ğœƒâ‹…ğ‘¥ğ‘–1ğ‘›superscriptâ„ğ‘›K_{\theta}(\mathcal{L},\mathcal{L})=(L_{i}^{x}L_{j}^{y}K_{\theta}(x,y))_{i,j=1}^{n}\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times n}\quad\text{ and }\quad K_{\theta}(\mathcal{L},x)=(L_{i}K_{\theta}(\cdot,x))_{i=1}^{n}\in\mathbb{R}^{n},

which are well-defined by the assumption that the information functionals are bounded on Hâ€‹(KÎ¸,Î©)ğ»subscriptğ¾ğœƒÎ©H(K_{\theta},\Omega). The vector KÎ¸â€‹(x,â„’)subscriptğ¾ğœƒğ‘¥â„’K_{\theta}(x,\mathcal{L}) is defined analogously to KÎ¸â€‹(â„’,x)subscriptğ¾ğœƒâ„’ğ‘¥K_{\theta}(\mathcal{L},x) but with the information functionals applied to the second argument. The Gaussian process fGPâˆ¼GPâ€‹(m,KÎ¸)similar-tosubscriptğ‘“GPGPğ‘šsubscriptğ¾ğœƒf_{\textup{GP}}\sim\mathrm{GP}(m,K_{\theta}) conditioned on the general linear data Yâ„’subscriptğ‘Œâ„’Y_{\mathcal{L}} inÂ (5.1) has the mean

ğ”¼â€‹[fGPâ€‹(x)âˆ£Yâ„’]=Yâ„’,mğ–³â€‹KÎ¸â€‹(â„’,â„’)âˆ’1â€‹KÎ¸â€‹(â„’,x),ğ”¼delimited-[]conditionalsubscriptğ‘“GPğ‘¥subscriptğ‘Œâ„’superscriptsubscriptğ‘Œâ„’ğ‘šğ–³subscriptğ¾ğœƒsuperscriptâ„’â„’1subscriptğ¾ğœƒâ„’ğ‘¥\mathbb{E}[f_{\textup{GP}}(x)\mid Y_{\mathcal{L}}]=Y_{\mathcal{L},m}^{\mathsf{T}}K_{\theta}(\mathcal{L},\mathcal{L})^{-1}K_{\theta}(\mathcal{L},x),

and covariance

Covâ€‹[fGPâ€‹(x),fGPâ€‹(y)âˆ£Yâ„’]=KÎ¸â€‹(x,y)âˆ’KÎ¸â€‹(x,â„’)ğ–³â€‹KÎ¸â€‹(â„’,â„’)âˆ’1â€‹KÎ¸â€‹(â„’,y).Covsubscriptğ‘“GPğ‘¥conditionalsubscriptğ‘“GPğ‘¦subscriptğ‘Œâ„’subscriptğ¾ğœƒğ‘¥ğ‘¦subscriptğ¾ğœƒsuperscriptğ‘¥â„’ğ–³subscriptğ¾ğœƒsuperscriptâ„’â„’1subscriptğ¾ğœƒâ„’ğ‘¦\mathrm{Cov}[f_{\textup{GP}}(x),f_{\textup{GP}}(y)\mid Y_{\mathcal{L}}]=K_{\theta}(x,y)-K_{\theta}(x,\mathcal{L})^{\mathsf{T}}K_{\theta}(\mathcal{L},\mathcal{L})^{-1}K_{\theta}(\mathcal{L},y).

The modified log-likelihood function is

â„“â€‹(Î¸âˆ£Yâ„’)=Yâ„’,mğ–³â€‹KÎ¸â€‹(â„’,â„’)âˆ’1â€‹Yâ„’,m+logâ€‹detKÎ¸â€‹(â„’,â„’).â„“conditionalğœƒsubscriptğ‘Œâ„’superscriptsubscriptğ‘Œâ„’ğ‘šğ–³subscriptğ¾ğœƒsuperscriptâ„’â„’1subscriptğ‘Œâ„’ğ‘šsubscriptğ¾ğœƒâ„’â„’\ell(\theta\mid Y_{\mathcal{L}})=Y_{\mathcal{L},m}^{\mathsf{T}}K_{\theta}(\mathcal{L},\mathcal{L})^{-1}Y_{\mathcal{L},m}+\log\det K_{\theta}(\mathcal{L},\mathcal{L}). (5.2)

Let g:(0,âˆ)â†’(0,âˆ):ğ‘”â†’00g\colon(0,\infty)\to(0,\infty) be a continuous function such that (a) lim supÎ»â†’0gâ€‹(Î»)<âˆsubscriptlimit-supremumâ†’ğœ†0ğ‘”ğœ†\limsup_{\lambda\to 0}g(\lambda)<\infty, (b) limÎ»â†’âˆgâ€‹(Î»)=âˆsubscriptâ†’ğœ†ğ‘”ğœ†\lim_{\lambda\to\infty}g(\lambda)=\infty, and (c) gâ€‹(Î»1)=1ğ‘”subscriptğœ†11g(\lambda_{1})=1 for some Î»1>0subscriptğœ†10\lambda_{1}>0. Define
