KÎ»â€‹(x,y)=Kâ€‹(xgâ€‹(Î»),ygâ€‹(Î»))Â for anyÂ Î»>0â€‹Â andÂ â€‹x,yâˆˆÎ©.formulae-sequencesubscriptğ¾ğœ†ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ¾ğ‘¥ğ‘”ğœ†ğ‘¦ğ‘”ğœ†Â for anyÂ formulae-sequenceğœ†0Â andÂ ğ‘¥ğ‘¦Î©K_{\lambda}(x,y)=K\bigg{(}\frac{x}{g(\lambda)},\frac{y}{g(\lambda)}\bigg{)}\quad\text{ for any }\quad\lambda>0\>\text{ and }\>x,y\in\Omega. (5.3)

The parameter Î»ğœ†\lambda can be interpreted as a generalised version of the lengthscale parameter of a stationary kernel inÂ (1.2). Stationary kernels are recovered fromÂ (5.3) by setting gâ€‹(Î»)=Î»ğ‘”ğœ†ğœ†g(\lambda)=\lambda and Kâ€‹(x,y)=Î¦â€‹(xâˆ’y)ğ¾ğ‘¥ğ‘¦Î¦ğ‘¥ğ‘¦K(x,y)=\Phi(x-y). The exponential kernel KÎ»â€‹(x,y)=expâ¡(xâ€‹y/Î»)subscriptğ¾ğœ†ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğœ†K_{\lambda}(x,y)=\exp(xy/\lambda) is a simple non-stationary example that is occasionally used. We are interested in maximum likelihood estimates Î»MLâ€‹(â„’)subscriptğœ†MLâ„’\lambda_{\textup{ML}(\mathcal{L})} of Î»ğœ†\lambda, any of which satisfies

Î»MLâ€‹(â„’)âˆˆargâ€‹minÎ»>0â¡â„“â€‹(Î»âˆ£Yâ„’)=argâ€‹minÎ»>0â¡{Yâ„’,mğ–³â€‹KÎ»â€‹(â„’,â„’)âˆ’1â€‹Yâ„’,m+logâ€‹detKÎ»â€‹(â„’,â„’)}.subscriptğœ†MLâ„’subscriptargminğœ†0â„“conditionalğœ†subscriptğ‘Œâ„’subscriptargminğœ†0superscriptsubscriptğ‘Œâ„’ğ‘šğ–³subscriptğ¾ğœ†superscriptâ„’â„’1subscriptğ‘Œâ„’ğ‘šsubscriptğ¾ğœ†â„’â„’\lambda_{\textup{ML}(\mathcal{L})}\in\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{\lambda>0}\ell(\lambda\mid Y_{\mathcal{L}})=\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{\lambda>0}\big{\{}Y_{\mathcal{L},m}^{\mathsf{T}}K_{\lambda}(\mathcal{L},\mathcal{L})^{-1}Y_{\mathcal{L},m}+\log\det K_{\lambda}(\mathcal{L},\mathcal{L})\big{\}}.

In this setting we say that the data Yâ„’subscriptğ‘Œâ„’Y_{\mathcal{L}} are mğ‘šm-constant if there is a constant function c:Î©â†’â„:ğ‘â†’Î©â„c\colon\Omega\to\mathbb{R} such that

Yâ„’,m=(L1â€‹c,â€¦,Lnâ€‹c).subscriptğ‘Œâ„’ğ‘šsubscriptğ¿1ğ‘â€¦subscriptğ¿ğ‘›ğ‘Y_{\mathcal{L},m}=(L_{1}c,\ldots,L_{n}c). (5.4)

To prove a generalisation of TheoremÂ 2.3 we need the following technical assumption.

Assumption 5.1

Every element of the matrix KÎ»â€‹(â„’,â„’)subscriptğ¾ğœ†â„’â„’K_{\lambda}(\mathcal{L},\mathcal{L}) is a continuous function of Î»>0ğœ†0\lambda>0 and

(a)lim infÎ»â†’0eminâ€‹(KÎ»â€‹(â„’,â„’))>0Â andÂ (b)limÎ»â†’âˆdetKÎ»â€‹(â„’,â„’)=0,formulae-sequence(a)subscriptlimit-infimumâ†’ğœ†0subscriptğ‘’minsubscriptğ¾ğœ†â„’â„’0Â andÂ (b)subscriptâ†’ğœ†subscriptğ¾ğœ†â„’â„’0\text{(a)}\quad\liminf_{\lambda\to 0}e_{\textup{min}}(K_{\lambda}(\mathcal{L},\mathcal{L}))>0\quad\text{ and }\quad\text{(b)}\quad\lim_{\lambda\to\infty}\det K_{\lambda}(\mathcal{L},\mathcal{L})=0,

where eminâ€‹(A)subscriptğ‘’minğ´e_{\textup{min}}(A) denotes the smallest eigenvalue of a matrix Ağ´A.

Theorem 5.2

Suppose that AssumptionÂ 5.1 holds and let Î©bsubscriptÎ©ğ‘\Omega_{b} be any convex subset of Î©Î©\Omega such that (a) 0âˆˆÎ©b0subscriptÎ©ğ‘0\in\Omega_{b} and (b) Lâ€‹f1=Lâ€‹f2ğ¿subscriptğ‘“1ğ¿subscriptğ‘“2Lf_{1}=Lf_{2} for every Lâˆˆâ„’ğ¿â„’L\in\mathcal{L} and all f1,f2âˆˆFâ€‹(Î©)subscriptğ‘“1subscriptğ‘“2ğ¹Î©f_{1},f_{2}\in F(\Omega) such that f1=f2subscriptğ‘“1subscriptğ‘“2f_{1}=f_{2} on Î©bsubscriptÎ©ğ‘\Omega_{b}. If the data Yâ„’subscriptğ‘Œâ„’Y_{\mathcal{L}} are mğ‘šm-constant and constant functions are contained in Hâ€‹(K,Î©b)ğ»ğ¾subscriptÎ©ğ‘H(K,\Omega_{b}), then

limÎ»â†’âˆâ„“â€‹(Î»âˆ£Yâ„’)=âˆ’âˆÂ andÂ Î»MLâ€‹(â„’)=âˆ.formulae-sequencesubscriptâ†’ğœ†â„“conditionalğœ†subscriptğ‘Œâ„’Â andÂ subscriptğœ†MLâ„’\lim_{\lambda\to\infty}\ell(\lambda\mid Y_{\mathcal{L}})=-\infty\quad\text{ and }\quad\lambda_{\textup{ML}(\mathcal{L})}=\infty.

ProofÂ  See SectionÂ 7.8. The proof is in essence identical to that ofÂ (2.11), but more technical. Â 

AssumptionÂ 5.1 and other assumptions in TheoremÂ 5.2 may be verified on case-by-case basis. For example, let Î©=â„Î©â„\Omega=\mathbb{R} and

KÎ»â€‹(x,y)=(1+3â€‹|xâˆ’y|Î»)â€‹expâ¡(âˆ’3â€‹|xâˆ’y|Î»),subscriptğ¾ğœ†ğ‘¥ğ‘¦13ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğœ†3ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğœ†K_{\lambda}(x,y)=\bigg{(}1+\frac{\sqrt{3}\mathinner{\lvert x-y\rvert}}{\lambda}\bigg{)}\exp\bigg{(}\!-\frac{\sqrt{3}\mathinner{\lvert x-y\rvert}}{\lambda}\bigg{)},

which is the MatÃ©rn kernel inÂ (2.3) with smoothness Î½=3/2ğœˆ32\nu=3/2. Suppose that L1â€‹f=fâ€²â€‹(x1)subscriptğ¿1ğ‘“superscriptğ‘“â€²subscriptğ‘¥1L_{1}f=f^{\prime}(x_{1}) and Liâ€‹f=fâ€‹(xi)subscriptğ¿ğ‘–ğ‘“ğ‘“subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–L_{i}f=f(x_{i}) for i=2,â€¦,nğ‘–2â€¦ğ‘›i=2,\ldots,n and distinct x2,â€¦,xnsubscriptğ‘¥2â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›x_{2},\ldots,x_{n}. One may easily find a convex Î©bâŠ‚â„subscriptÎ©ğ‘â„\Omega_{b}\subset\mathbb{R} such that 0,x1,x2,â€¦,xnâˆˆÎ©b0subscriptğ‘¥1subscriptğ‘¥2â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›subscriptÎ©ğ‘0,x_{1},x_{2},\ldots,x_{n}\in\Omega_{b} (e.g., a ball centered at the origin with radius that exceeds the maximal norm of the points). Because this set can be taken to be bounded, it follows fromÂ (2.10) and the results reviewed in SectionÂ 7.3 that constant functions are contained in Hâ€‹(K,Î©b)ğ»ğ¾subscriptÎ©ğ‘H(K,\Omega_{b}). To verify AssumptionÂ 5.1, observe that the generalised covariance matrix is

KÎ»â€‹(â„’,â„’)=(aÎ»bÎ»ğ–³bÎ»KÎ»â€‹(Xâ€²,Xâ€²)),subscriptğ¾ğœ†â„’â„’matrixsubscriptğ‘ğœ†superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğœ†ğ–³subscriptğ‘ğœ†subscriptğ¾ğœ†superscriptğ‘‹â€²superscriptğ‘‹â€²K_{\lambda}(\mathcal{L},\mathcal{L})=\begin{pmatrix}a_{\lambda}&b_{\lambda}^{\mathsf{T}}\\ b_{\lambda}&K_{\lambda}(X^{\prime},X^{\prime})\end{pmatrix}, (5.5)

where KÎ»â€‹(Xâ€²,Xâ€²)âˆˆâ„(nâˆ’1)Ã—(nâˆ’1)subscriptğ¾ğœ†superscriptğ‘‹â€²superscriptğ‘‹â€²superscriptâ„ğ‘›1ğ‘›1K_{\lambda}(X^{\prime},X^{\prime})\in\mathbb{R}^{(n-1)\times(n-1)} is the regular covariance matrix for the points x2,â€¦,xnsubscriptğ‘¥2â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›x_{2},\ldots,x_{n},

aÎ»=âˆ‚2âˆ‚xâ€‹âˆ‚yKÎ»(x,y)|x=x1y=x1=3Î»2,a_{\lambda}=\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial x\partial y}K_{\lambda}(x,y)\biggl{|}_{\begin{subarray}{c}x=x_{1}\\ y=x_{1}\end{subarray}}=\frac{3}{\lambda^{2}},

and

(bÎ»)iâˆ’1=âˆ‚âˆ‚xKÎ»(x,xi)|x=x1=âˆ’3Î»2(x1âˆ’xi)exp(âˆ’3â€‹|x1âˆ’xi|Î»)(b_{\lambda})_{i-1}=\frac{\partial}{\partial x}K_{\lambda}(x,x_{i})\biggl{|}_{x=x_{1}}=-\frac{3}{\lambda^{2}}(x_{1}-x_{i})\exp\bigg{(}\!-\frac{\sqrt{3}\mathinner{\lvert x_{1}-x_{i}\rvert}}{\lambda}\bigg{)}

for i=2,â€¦,nğ‘–2â€¦ğ‘›i=2,\ldots,n. The entries of bÎ»subscriptğ‘ğœ†b_{\lambda}, as well as aÎ»subscriptğ‘ğœ†a_{\lambda}, are continuous in Î»ğœ†\lambda on (0,âˆ)0(0,\infty). We compute limÎ»â†’0aÎ»=âˆsubscriptâ†’ğœ†0subscriptğ‘ğœ†\lim_{\lambda\to 0}a_{\lambda}=\infty and limÎ»â†’âˆaÎ»=0subscriptâ†’ğœ†subscriptğ‘ğœ†0\lim_{\lambda\to\infty}a_{\lambda}=0, as well as limÎ»â†’0(bÎ»)iâˆ’1=0subscriptâ†’ğœ†0subscriptsubscriptğ‘ğœ†ğ‘–10\lim_{\lambda\to 0}(b_{\lambda})_{i-1}=0 and limÎ»â†’âˆ(bÎ»)iâˆ’1=0subscriptâ†’ğœ†subscriptsubscriptğ‘ğœ†ğ‘–10\lim_{\lambda\to\infty}(b_{\lambda})_{i-1}=0 for each i=2,â€¦,nğ‘–2â€¦ğ‘›i=2,\ldots,n. Therefore limÎ»â†’0KÎ»â€‹(â„’,â„’)=diagâ€‹(âˆ,1,â€¦,1)subscriptâ†’ğœ†0subscriptğ¾ğœ†â„’â„’diag1â€¦1\lim_{\lambda\to 0}K_{\lambda}(\mathcal{L},\mathcal{L})=\mathrm{diag}(\infty,1,\ldots,1) and limÎ»â†’âˆKÎ»â€‹(â„’,â„’)subscriptâ†’ğœ†subscriptğ¾ğœ†â„’â„’\lim_{\lambda\to\infty}K_{\lambda}(\mathcal{L},\mathcal{L}) is singular because its first row is zero. AssumptionÂ 5.1 thus holds and it follows from TheoremÂ 5.2 that Î»MLâ€‹(â„’)=âˆsubscriptğœ†MLâ„’\lambda_{\textup{ML}(\mathcal{L})}=\infty if Yâ„’,m=(0,c,â€¦,c)subscriptğ‘Œâ„’ğ‘š0ğ‘â€¦ğ‘Y_{\mathcal{L},m}=(0,c,\ldots,c) for some câˆˆâ„ğ‘â„c\in\mathbb{R}.

5.2 Product Kernels and Multiple Lengthscales

Here we consider a setting where the covariance kernel is a product of stationary kernels equipped with dimensionwise lengthscale parameters. That is, Î¸={Î»1,â€¦,Î»d}ğœƒsubscriptğœ†1â€¦subscriptğœ†ğ‘‘\theta=\{\lambda_{1},\ldots,\lambda_{d}\} and the kernel has the product form

KÎ¸â€‹(x,y)=âˆi=1dKi,Î»iâ€‹(xi,yi)=âˆi=1dÎ¦iâ€‹(xiâˆ’yiÎ»i),subscriptğ¾ğœƒğ‘¥ğ‘¦superscriptsubscriptproductğ‘–1ğ‘‘subscriptğ¾ğ‘–subscriptğœ†ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptproductğ‘–1ğ‘‘subscriptÎ¦ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–subscriptğœ†ğ‘–K_{\theta}(x,y)=\prod_{i=1}^{d}K_{i,\lambda_{i}}(x_{i},y_{i})=\prod_{i=1}^{d}\Phi_{i}\bigg{(}\frac{x_{i}-y_{i}}{\lambda_{i}}\bigg{)}, (5.6)

where x=(x1,â€¦,xd)âˆˆâ„dğ‘¥subscriptğ‘¥1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘‘superscriptâ„ğ‘‘x=(x_{1},\ldots,x_{d})\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, y=(y1,â€¦,yd)âˆˆâ„dğ‘¦subscriptğ‘¦1â€¦subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘‘superscriptâ„ğ‘‘y=(y_{1},\ldots,y_{d})\in\mathbb{R}^{d} and Kiâ€‹(xi,yi)=Î¦iâ€‹(xiâˆ’yi)subscriptğ¾ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–subscriptÎ¦ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–K_{i}(x_{i},y_{i})=\Phi_{i}(x_{i}-y_{i}) are stationary kernels on â„â„\mathbb{R} parametrised by positive lengthscale parameters Î»isubscriptğœ†ğ‘–\lambda_{i}. Recall the definition of MatÃ©rn kernel fromÂ (2.3). The product MatÃ©rn kernel

KÎ¸â€‹(x,y)=Ïƒ2â€‹âˆi=1d[21âˆ’Î½iÎ“â€‹(Î½i)â€‹(2â€‹Î½iâ€‹|xiâˆ’yi|Î»i)Î½iâ€‹ğ’¦Î½iâ€‹(2â€‹Î½iâ€‹|xiâˆ’yi|Î»i)],subscriptğ¾ğœƒğ‘¥ğ‘¦superscriptğœ2superscriptsubscriptproductğ‘–1ğ‘‘delimited-[]superscript21subscriptğœˆğ‘–Î“subscriptğœˆğ‘–superscript2subscriptğœˆğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–subscriptğœ†ğ‘–subscriptğœˆğ‘–subscriptğ’¦subscriptğœˆğ‘–2subscriptğœˆğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–subscriptğœ†ğ‘–K_{\theta}(x,y)=\sigma^{2}\prod_{i=1}^{d}\Bigg{[}\frac{2^{1-\nu_{i}}}{\Gamma(\nu_{i})}\bigg{(}\frac{\sqrt{2\nu_{i}}\mathinner{\lvert x_{i}-y_{i}\rvert}}{\lambda_{i}}\bigg{)}^{\nu_{i}}\mathcal{K}_{\nu_{i}}\bigg{(}\frac{\sqrt{2\nu_{i}}\mathinner{\lvert x_{i}-y_{i}\rvert}}{\lambda_{i}}\bigg{)}\Bigg{]},

where Î½i>0subscriptğœˆğ‘–0\nu_{i}>0, is a commonly used product kernel of the formÂ (5.6).

For simplicity, let us consider maximum likelihood estimation of only one of the dğ‘‘d lengthscale parameters. For pâˆˆ{1,â€¦,d}ğ‘1â€¦ğ‘‘p\in\{1,\ldots,d\}, we are interested in the behaviour of

Î»p,ML=argâ€‹minÎ»p>0â¡â„“â€‹(Î»1,â€¦,Î»dâˆ£Y),subscriptğœ†ğ‘MLsubscriptargminsubscriptğœ†ğ‘0â„“subscriptğœ†1â€¦conditionalsubscriptğœ†ğ‘‘ğ‘Œ\lambda_{p,\textup{ML}}=\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{\lambda_{p}>0}\ell(\lambda_{1},\ldots,\lambda_{d}\mid Y), (5.7)

where â„“â€‹(Î»1,â€¦,Î»dâˆ£Y)â„“subscriptğœ†1â€¦conditionalsubscriptğœ†ğ‘‘ğ‘Œ\ell(\lambda_{1},\ldots,\lambda_{d}\mid Y) is the modified log-likelihood function inÂ (2.8) for Î¸={Î»1,â€¦,Î»d}ğœƒsubscriptğœ†1â€¦subscriptğœ†ğ‘‘\theta=\{\lambda_{1},\ldots,\lambda_{d}\} and the product kernel inÂ (5.6) and Î»isubscriptğœ†ğ‘–\lambda_{i} for iâ‰ pğ‘–ğ‘i\neq p are fixed. For product covariates Xğ‘‹X of the form

X=X1Ã—â‹¯Ã—Xd,Â whereÂ Xi={xi,1,â€¦,xi,ni}âŠ‚â„,formulae-sequenceğ‘‹subscriptğ‘‹1â‹¯subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘‘Â whereÂ subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘›ğ‘–â„X=X_{1}\times\cdots\times X_{d},\quad\text{ where }\quad X_{i}=\{x_{i,1},\ldots,x_{i,n_{i}}\}\subset\mathbb{R}, (5.8)

we say that the associated data Yğ‘ŒY are mğ‘šm-constant along dimension pğ‘p if

yi1,â€¦,idâˆ’mâ€‹(x1,i1,â€¦,xd,id)Â does not depend onÂ ip=1,â€¦,np,formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘¦subscriptğ‘–1â€¦subscriptğ‘–ğ‘‘ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘¥1subscriptğ‘–1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘–ğ‘‘Â does not depend onÂ subscriptğ‘–ğ‘1â€¦subscriptğ‘›ğ‘y_{i_{1},\ldots,i_{d}}-m(x_{1,i_{1}},\ldots,x_{d,i_{d}})\quad\text{ does not depend on }\quad i_{p}=1,\ldots,n_{p},

where the datum yi1,â€¦,idsubscriptğ‘¦subscriptğ‘–1â€¦subscriptğ‘–ğ‘‘y_{i_{1},\ldots,i_{d}} is associated with the covariate (x1,i1,â€¦,xd,id)âˆˆXsubscriptğ‘¥1subscriptğ‘–1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘–ğ‘‘ğ‘‹(x_{1,i_{1}},\ldots,x_{d,i_{d}})\in X. For example, the data

Y=(y1,1,y1,2,y1,3,y2,1,y2,2,y2,3)=(0,1,2,0,1,2)ğ‘Œsubscriptğ‘¦11subscriptğ‘¦12subscriptğ‘¦13subscriptğ‘¦21subscriptğ‘¦22subscriptğ‘¦23012012Y=(y_{1,1},y_{1,2},y_{1,3},y_{2,1},y_{2,2},y_{2,3})=(0,1,2,0,1,2)

are constant along dimension p=1ğ‘1p=1 for the product design

X={x1,1,x1,2}Ã—{x2,1,x2,2,x2,3}={(x1,1,x2,1),(x1,1,x2,2),(x1,1,x2,3),(x1,2,x2,1),(x1,2,x2,2),(x1,2,x2,3)}ğ‘‹subscriptğ‘¥11subscriptğ‘¥12subscriptğ‘¥21subscriptğ‘¥22subscriptğ‘¥23subscriptğ‘¥11subscriptğ‘¥21subscriptğ‘¥11subscriptğ‘¥22subscriptğ‘¥11subscriptğ‘¥23subscriptğ‘¥12subscriptğ‘¥21subscriptğ‘¥12subscriptğ‘¥22subscriptğ‘¥12subscriptğ‘¥23\begin{split}X=\{x_{1,1},x_{1,2}\}\times\{x_{2,1},x_{2,2},x_{2,3}\}=\big{\{}&(x_{1,1},x_{2,1}),(x_{1,1},x_{2,2}),(x_{1,1},x_{2,3}),\\ &(x_{1,2},x_{2,1}),(x_{1,2},x_{2,2}),(x_{1,2},x_{2,3})\big{\}}\end{split}

in â„2superscriptâ„2\mathbb{R}^{2} and the prior mean mâ‰¡0ğ‘š0m\equiv 0.

Theorem 5.3 (Estimation of multiple lengthscales)

Consider the product kernel inÂ (5.6) and suppose that the stationary kernels K1,â€¦,Kdsubscriptğ¾1â€¦subscriptğ¾ğ‘‘K_{1},\ldots,K_{d} on â„â„\mathbb{R} satisfy AssumptionÂ 2.2. If Xğ‘‹X has the product formÂ (5.8) with niâ‰¥1subscriptğ‘›ğ‘–1n_{i}\geq 1 for each i=1,â€¦,dğ‘–1â€¦ğ‘‘i=1,\ldots,d and the data Yğ‘ŒY are mğ‘šm-constant along dimension pâˆˆ{1,â€¦,d}ğ‘1â€¦ğ‘‘p\in\{1,\ldots,d\}, then

limÎ»pâ†’âˆâ„“â€‹(Î»1,â€¦,Î»dâˆ£Y)=âˆ’âˆÂ andÂ Î»p,ML=âˆ,formulae-sequencesubscriptâ†’subscriptğœ†ğ‘â„“subscriptğœ†1â€¦conditionalsubscriptğœ†ğ‘‘ğ‘ŒÂ andÂ subscriptğœ†ğ‘ML\lim_{\lambda_{p}\to\infty}\ell(\lambda_{1},\ldots,\lambda_{d}\mid Y)=-\infty\quad\text{ and }\quad\lambda_{p,\textup{ML}}=\infty,

where Î»p,MLsubscriptğœ†ğ‘ML\lambda_{p,\textup{ML}} is the maximum likelihood estimate of the pğ‘pth lengthscale parameter inÂ (5.7).

ProofÂ  See SectionÂ 7.9. The product form of the kernel and the covariates allow one to write the full covariance matrix KÎ¸â€‹(X,X)subscriptğ¾ğœƒğ‘‹ğ‘‹K_{\theta}(X,X) as a Kronecker product of Ki,Î»â€‹(Xi,Xi)subscriptğ¾ğ‘–ğœ†subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘–subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘–K_{i,\lambda}(X_{i},X_{i}). One may then utilise the properties of Kronecker products and subsequently follow the proof of TheoremÂ 2.3. Â 

Note that the constants C1subscriptğ¶1C_{1}, C2subscriptğ¶2C_{2} and Î±ğ›¼\alpha in AssumptionÂ 2.2 may differ from one constituent kernel Kisubscriptğ¾ğ‘–K_{i} to another. TheoremÂ 5.3 provides some theoretical justification for the use of maximum likelihood estimation of lengthscales as an automatic relevance determination methodÂ (Rasmussen and Williams, 2006, SectionÂ 5.1). When the data are independent of the pğ‘pth input dimension, the lengthscale for this dimension is set to infinite and the dimension is effectively ignored.

5.3 Infinitely Smooth Stationary Kernels

Commonly used infinitely smooth stationary kernels, such as the Gaussian and the inverse quadratic (or Cauchy) defined by

Î¦â€‹(z)=expâ¡(âˆ’âˆ¥zâˆ¥2)Â andÂ Î¦â€‹(z)=11+âˆ¥zâˆ¥2,formulae-sequenceÎ¦ğ‘§superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ‘§2Â andÂ Î¦ğ‘§11superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ‘§2\Phi(z)=\exp(-\mathinner{\lVert z\rVert}^{2})\quad\text{ and }\quad\Phi(z)=\frac{1}{1+\mathinner{\lVert z\rVert}^{2}}, (5.9)

respectively, do not satisfy AssumptionÂ 2.2 because their Fourier transforms decay (at least) exponentially. The exponential decay of their Fourier transforms implies that these kernels are analytic. The purpose of AssumptionÂ 2.2 is to guarantee that constant functions are contained in the RKHS of Kğ¾K on a bounded set, a result which in turn can be exploited to prove that the data-fit term Ymğ–³â€‹KÎ»â€‹(X,X)âˆ’1â€‹Ymsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘šğ–³subscriptğ¾ğœ†superscriptğ‘‹ğ‘‹1subscriptğ‘Œğ‘šY_{m}^{\mathsf{T}}K_{\lambda}(X,X)^{-1}Y_{m} is a bounded function of Î»ğœ†\lambda whenever the data are mğ‘šm-constant (see LemmaÂ 7.2). However, it is known that the RKHSs of analytic stationary kernels, such as those inÂ (5.9), do not contain constant functionsÂ (Steinwart etÂ al., 2006; Sun and Zhou, 2008; Minh, 2010; Dette and Zhigljavsky, 2021). But this does have to mean that the data-fit term explodes as Î»â†’âˆâ†’ğœ†\lambda\to\infty.

Increasing the lengthscale parameter is equivalent to coalescence of the points to the origin. That is, using the kernel KÎ»subscriptğ¾ğœ†K_{\lambda} and points Xğ‘‹X is equivalent to using the kernel Kğ¾K and the scaled points XÎ»={x1/Î»,â€¦,xn/Î»}subscriptğ‘‹ğœ†subscriptğ‘¥1ğœ†â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›ğœ†X_{\lambda}=\{x_{1}/\lambda,\ldots,x_{n}/\lambda\}, each of which tends to the origin as Î»â†’âˆâ†’ğœ†\lambda\to\infty. Suppose for simplicity that d=1ğ‘‘1d=1. When the points coalesce, oneâ€™s data effectively comprises the value at the origin of the data-generating function and its successive derivatives up to order nâˆ’1ğ‘›1n-1. We refer to SectionÂ 11 in Schaback (2008) and ChapterÂ 5 in Oettershagen (2017) for more discussion and some results regarding this phenomenon. The computations in SectionÂ 2 of Dette and Zhigljavsky (2021) are also relevant. If the data are mğ‘šm-constant such that Ym=(c,â€¦,c)subscriptğ‘Œğ‘šğ‘â€¦ğ‘Y_{m}=(c,\ldots,c) and the kernel Kâ€‹(x,y)=Î¦â€‹(xâˆ’y)ğ¾ğ‘¥ğ‘¦Î¦ğ‘¥ğ‘¦K(x,y)=\Phi(x-y) is sufficiently smooth, this reasoning suggests the conjecture that

limÎ»â†’âˆYmğ–³â€‹KÎ»â€‹(X,X)âˆ’1â€‹Ym=limÎ»â†’âˆYmğ–³â€‹Kâ€‹(XÎ»,XÎ»)âˆ’1â€‹Ym=D0ğ–³â€‹Wâˆ’1â€‹D0subscriptâ†’ğœ†superscriptsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘šğ–³subscriptğ¾ğœ†superscriptğ‘‹ğ‘‹1subscriptğ‘Œğ‘šsubscriptâ†’ğœ†superscriptsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘šğ–³ğ¾superscriptsubscriptğ‘‹ğœ†subscriptğ‘‹ğœ†1subscriptğ‘Œğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptğ·0ğ–³superscriptğ‘Š1subscriptğ·0\lim_{\lambda\to\infty}Y_{m}^{\mathsf{T}}K_{\lambda}(X,X)^{-1}Y_{m}=\lim_{\lambda\to\infty}Y_{m}^{\mathsf{T}}K(X_{\lambda},X_{\lambda})^{-1}Y_{m}=D_{0}^{\mathsf{T}}W^{-1}D_{0} (5.10)

where D0=(c,0,â€¦,0)âˆˆâ„nsubscriptğ·0ğ‘0â€¦0superscriptâ„ğ‘›D_{0}=(c,0,\ldots,0)\in\mathbb{R}^{n} and the Wronskian Wâˆˆâ„nÃ—nğ‘Šsuperscriptâ„ğ‘›ğ‘›W\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times n} has the elements

(W)i+1,j+1=âˆ‚i+jâˆ‚viâ€‹âˆ‚wjK(v,w)|v=0w=0(W)_{i+1,j+1}=\frac{\partial^{i+j}}{\partial v^{i}\partial w^{j}}K(v,w)\Bigl{|}_{\begin{subarray}{c}v=0\\ w=0\end{subarray}} (5.11)

for i,j=0,â€¦,nâˆ’1formulae-sequenceğ‘–ğ‘—0â€¦ğ‘›1i,j=0,\ldots,n-1. The conjectured limit D0ğ–³â€‹Wâˆ’1â€‹D0superscriptsubscriptğ·0ğ–³superscriptğ‘Š1subscriptğ·0D_{0}^{\mathsf{T}}W^{-1}D_{0} is the data-fit term inÂ (5.2) for the information functionals defined as Liâ€‹f=f(iâˆ’1)â€‹(0)subscriptğ¿ğ‘–ğ‘“superscriptğ‘“ğ‘–10L_{i}f=f^{(i-1)}(0) for i=1,â€¦,nğ‘–1â€¦ğ‘›i=1,\ldots,n and general mğ‘šm-constant data inÂ (5.4). A proof ofÂ (5.10) is the main ingredient in the proof of the following theorem, which partially generalises TheoremÂ 2.3 for infinitely differentiable kernels when d=1ğ‘‘1d=1.

Theorem 5.4

Let d=1ğ‘‘1d=1 and Kâ€‹(x,y)=Î¦â€‹(xâˆ’y)ğ¾ğ‘¥ğ‘¦Î¦ğ‘¥ğ‘¦K(x,y)=\Phi(x-y). Suppose that (i) the function Î¦:â„â†’â„:Î¦â†’â„â„\Phi\colon\mathbb{R}\to\mathbb{R} is integrable and infinitely differentiable in a neighbourhood of the origin; (ii) Î¦(k)â€‹(0)=0superscriptÎ¦ğ‘˜00\Phi^{(k)}(0)=0 for every odd kğ‘˜k; and (iii) the Fourier transform of Î¦Î¦\Phi is everywhere positive. If nâ‰¥1ğ‘›1n\geq 1 and the data Yğ‘ŒY are mğ‘šm-constant, then

limÎ»â†’âˆâ„“â€‹(Î»âˆ£Y)=âˆ’âˆÂ andÂ Î»ML=âˆ.formulae-sequencesubscriptâ†’ğœ†â„“conditionalğœ†ğ‘ŒÂ andÂ subscriptğœ†ML\lim_{\lambda\to\infty}\ell(\lambda\mid Y)=-\infty\quad\text{ and }\quad\lambda_{\textup{ML}}=\infty.

ProofÂ  See SectionÂ 7.10. The proof uses EquationÂ (32) in BarthelmÃ© and Usevich (2021). Â 

6 Conclusion and Implications

In this article we have proved that Gaussian process regression with noiseless data and a stationary covariance kernel is ill-posed if the lengthscale parameter of the kernel is estimated using maximum likelihood: When the data differ from the prior mean by a constant mean shift, the maximum likelihood estimate of the lengthscale parameter is infinite (TheoremÂ 2.3) and the conditional Gaussian process is degenerate (TheoremÂ 2.6). As shown in SectionÂ 3, these conclusions remain valid under more general parametrisations and also applies to leave-one-out cross-validation.

6.1 Practical Implications

In a way, our results imply a practical simplification. If the data are mğ‘šm-constant (which, when the prior mean mğ‘šm is known and fixed, is trivial to check), there is no need for numerical optimisation of the log-likelihood function as one can use TheoremÂ 2.3 to set Î»ML=âˆsubscriptğœ†ML\lambda_{\textup{ML}}=\infty and TheoremÂ 2.6 to compute the conditional mean and covariance. However, degeneracy of the resulting conditional process implies that there is no predictive uncertainty and the conditional process is therefore useless as a tool for uncertainty quantification. Except for switching to a non-stationary kernel, we do not know of a good approach to fix this, and it may be that some non-stationary kernels are equally problematic and induce similar behaviour when some of their parameters are estimated.

A numerical issue that is encountered when the data are close to being mğ‘šm-constant is that of ill-conditioning of the covariance matrix. As Î»â†’âˆâ†’ğœ†\lambda\to\infty, the condition number of the covariance matrix KÎ»â€‹(X,X)subscriptğ¾ğœ†ğ‘‹ğ‘‹K_{\lambda}(X,X) increases with a rate related to the smoothness of the kernel. This means that one cannot compute the modified log-likelihood function for large values of Î»ğœ†\lambda. In practice one therefore has to either introduce a regularisation parameter to upper bound the condition number as a function of Î»ğœ†\lambda or select a finite maximal lengthscale Î»max>0subscriptğœ†max0\lambda_{\textup{max}}>0 for which â„“â€‹(Î»âˆ£Y)â„“conditionalğœ†ğ‘Œ\ell(\lambda\mid Y) can be reliably computed and find the maximum likelihood estimate in (0,Î»max]0subscriptğœ†max(0,\lambda_{\textup{max}}]. When the data are mğ‘šm-constant, restricting the feasible set for Î»ğœ†\lambda to (0,Î»max]0subscriptğœ†max(0,\lambda_{\textup{max}}] is likely to result in Î»ML=Î»maxsubscriptğœ†MLsubscriptğœ†max\lambda_{\textup{ML}}=\lambda_{\textup{max}}, so that the user effectively selects an arbitrary (though probably fairly large) lengthscale in this case. The dependence of predictions in Î»maxsubscriptğœ†max\lambda_{\textup{max}} may or may not be problematic depending on the context.

A practical recommendation borne out by our results is that all Gaussian process implementations which use maximum likelihood but not regularisation should check if the data are mğ‘šm-constant. If the check indicates that the data are mğ‘šm-constant, an implementation should either (a) forgo lengthscale estimation and output a degenerate conditional process or (b) throw an error and inform the user of the problem. If the approachÂ (a) is chosen it should be made clear to the user that the output is degenerate as this may have important ramifications in the applied context. A more general research programme suggests itself:

  1. (i)

    To characterise, for each estimator of the kernel parameters Î¸ğœƒ\theta, the problematic data sets Yğ‘ŒY which cause Gaussian process regression or interpolation to be ill-posed.

  2. (ii)

    To hard-code Gaussian process software to throw an error (or at least a warning) when such data are encountered.

6.2 Theoretical Implications

When analysing the convergence of Gaussian process regression as nâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘›n\to\infty, it is typically assumed that the covariance kernel is fixed. To the best of our knowledge, in the deterministic interpolation regime only Teckentrup (2020) and Wynne etÂ al. (2021) allow the kernel parameters other than scaling parameter Ïƒğœ\sigma from SectionÂ 3.3 (which does not affect the conditional mean) to vary. Their results are generic in that no specific parameter estimation method is considered and the parameter estimates are simply assumed to remain within certain sets. In Wynne etÂ al. (2021) only a smoothness parameter, such as the parameter Î½ğœˆ\nu of MatÃ©rn kernelsÂ (2.3), is allowed to vary. Teckentrup (2020, TheoremÂ 3.5) considers kernels which satisfyÂ AssumptionÂ 2.2 and proves that the conditional mean inÂ (2.4) tends to the true data-generating function fğ‘“f such that Y=fâ€‹(X)ğ‘Œğ‘“ğ‘‹Y=f(X) if (i) this function has certain smoothness and (ii) there is a compact set which contains the estimate of Î»ğœ†\lambda for every nğ‘›n. As we have seen in this article, the second assumption fails if fğ‘“f happens to be a mean shift of the prior mean (i.e., f=m+cğ‘“ğ‘šğ‘f=m+c for some câˆˆâ„ğ‘â„c\in\mathbb{R}) and Î»ğœ†\lambda is estimated using maximum likelihood. This demonstrates that unless one imposes an artificial upper bound on the parameter estimates, smoothness assumptions alone are not sufficient for comprehensive convergence analysis of Gaussian process regression.

6.3 On Estimation of Other Parameters

We conclude by pointing out that our ill-posedness results are specific to lengthscale estimation and should not be expected to extend to estimation of other kernel parameters. Two examples serve to illustrate this. First, consider the scale parametrisation KÏƒâ€‹(x,y)=Ïƒ2â€‹Kâ€‹(x,y)subscriptğ¾ğœğ‘¥ğ‘¦superscriptğœ2ğ¾ğ‘¥ğ‘¦K_{\sigma}(x,y)=\sigma^{2}K(x,y) for a scale parameter Ïƒ>0ğœ0\sigma>0. FromÂ (2.8) it is straightforward to compute that the maximum likelihood estimate of Ïƒğœ\sigma is available in closed form:

ÏƒML=Ymğ–³â€‹Kâ€‹(X,X)âˆ’1â€‹Ymn.subscriptğœMLsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘šğ–³ğ¾superscriptğ‘‹ğ‘‹1subscriptğ‘Œğ‘šğ‘›\sigma_{\textup{ML}}=\sqrt{\frac{Y_{m}^{\mathsf{T}}K(X,X)^{-1}Y_{m}}{n}}.

Here only the data Y=mâ€‹(X)ğ‘Œğ‘šğ‘‹Y=m(X) yield a problematic parameter estimate ÏƒML=0subscriptğœML0\sigma_{\textup{ML}}=0 that results in degenerate predictive distributions. Consider then estimation of the smoothness parameter Î½>0ğœˆ0\nu>0 of a MatÃ©rn kernel KÎ½subscriptğ¾ğœˆK_{\nu} inÂ (2.3). The presence of the coefficient 21âˆ’Î½/Î“â€‹(Î½)superscript21ğœˆÎ“ğœˆ2^{1-\nu}/\Gamma(\nu) ensures that KÎ½â€‹(x,x)=Ïƒ2subscriptğ¾ğœˆğ‘¥ğ‘¥superscriptğœ2K_{\nu}(x,x)=\sigma^{2} for every Î½>0ğœˆ0\nu>0, which has two implications:

  • â€¢

    As is well known, KÎ½â€‹(x,y)subscriptğ¾ğœˆğ‘¥ğ‘¦K_{\nu}(x,y) tends to the Gaussian kernel Ïƒ2â€‹expâ¡(âˆ’âˆ¥xâˆ’yâˆ¥2/(2â€‹Î»2))superscriptğœ2superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ‘¥ğ‘¦22superscriptğœ†2\sigma^{2}\exp(-\mathinner{\lVert x-y\rVert}^{2}\!/(2\lambda^{2})) as Î½â†’âˆâ†’ğœˆ\nu\to\infty for all x,yâˆˆâ„dğ‘¥ğ‘¦superscriptâ„ğ‘‘x,y\in\mathbb{R}^{d}.

  • â€¢

    As Î½â†’0â†’ğœˆ0\nu\to 0, KÎ½â€‹(x,y)â†’Ïƒ2â†’subscriptğ¾ğœˆğ‘¥ğ‘¦superscriptğœ2K_{\nu}(x,y)\to\sigma^{2} if x=yğ‘¥ğ‘¦x=y and KÎ½â€‹(x,y)â†’0â†’subscriptğ¾ğœˆğ‘¥ğ‘¦0K_{\nu}(x,y)\to 0 if xâ‰ yğ‘¥ğ‘¦x\neq y. The latter of these claims follows from the facts that ğ’¦0â€‹(z)subscriptğ’¦0ğ‘§\mathcal{K}_{0}(z), the Bessel function of the second kind of zeroth order, is well-defined if zâ‰ 0ğ‘§0z\neq 0 and Î“â€‹(Î½)â†’âˆâ†’Î“ğœˆ\Gamma(\nu)\to\infty as Î½â†’0â†’ğœˆ0\nu\to 0.

This shows that both potentially problematic limiting cases, Î½â†’0â†’ğœˆ0\nu\to 0 and Î½â†’âˆâ†’ğœˆ\nu\to\infty, yield valid positive-definite kernels. Consequently, degenerate predictive distributions can never arise from estimation of the MatÃ©rn smoothness parameter.

7 Proofs

This section contains proofs for the results in SectionsÂ 2, 3, 4 andÂ 5.

7.1 Interpolation in Reproducing Kernel Hilbert Spaces

Let Î©Î©\Omega be an arbitrary set and K:Î©Ã—Î©â†’â„:ğ¾â†’Î©Î©â„K\colon\Omega\times\Omega\to\mathbb{R} a positive-definite kernel, which means that

âˆ‘n=1nâˆ‘j=1naiâ€‹ajâ€‹Kâ€‹(xi,xj)>0superscriptsubscriptğ‘›1ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ‘›subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘—ğ¾subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—0\sum_{n=1}^{n}\sum_{j=1}^{n}a_{i}a_{j}K(x_{i},x_{j})>0 (7.1)

for any nâˆˆâ„•ğ‘›â„•n\in\mathbb{N}, any non-zero vector a=(a1,â€¦,an)ğ‘subscriptğ‘1â€¦subscriptğ‘ğ‘›a=(a_{1},\ldots,a_{n}), and any distinct points xiâˆˆÎ©subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–Î©x_{i}\in\Omega. The kernel is positive-semidefinite if the inequality inÂ (7.1) is not required to be strict. Then Kğ¾K induces a unique reproducing kernel Hilbert space (RKHS), Hâ€‹(K,Î©)ğ»ğ¾Î©H(K,\Omega). This is a Hilbert space consisting of real-valued functions defined on Î©Î©\Omega and is equipped with an inner product âŸ¨â‹…,â‹…âŸ©Hâ€‹(K,Î©)subscriptâ‹…â‹…ğ»ğ¾Î©\langle\cdot,\cdot\rangle_{H(K,\Omega)} and the corresponding norm âˆ¥â‹…âˆ¥Hâ€‹(K,Î©)subscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥â‹…ğ»ğ¾Î©\mathinner{\lVert\cdot\rVert}_{H(K,\Omega)}. The kernel translate Kâ€‹(â‹…,x)ğ¾â‹…ğ‘¥K(\cdot,x) is an element of Hâ€‹(K,Î©)ğ»ğ¾Î©H(K,\Omega) for every xâˆˆÎ©ğ‘¥Î©x\in\Omega and the kernel has the reproducing property

âŸ¨Kâ€‹(â‹…,x),fâŸ©Hâ€‹(K,Î©)=fâ€‹(x)Â for allÂ xâˆˆÎ©â€‹Â andÂ â€‹fâˆˆHâ€‹(K,Î©).formulae-sequencesubscriptğ¾â‹…ğ‘¥ğ‘“ğ»ğ¾Î©ğ‘“ğ‘¥Â for allÂ ğ‘¥Î©Â andÂ ğ‘“ğ»ğ¾Î©\langle K(\cdot,x),f\rangle_{H(K,\Omega)}=f(x)\quad\text{ for all }\quad x\in\Omega\>\text{ and }\>f\in H(K,\Omega).

It is usually not straightforward to determine whether or not a given function is an element of Hâ€‹(K,Î©)ğ»ğ¾Î©H(K,\Omega). However, the RKHS of a kernel which satisfies AssumptionÂ 2.2 on the rate of decay of its Fourier transform is a Sobolev space; see SectionÂ 7.3. For more information on RKHSs we refer the reader to Berlinet and Thomas-Agnan (2004) and ChaptersÂ 10 andÂ 16 in Wendland (2005).

We are interested in optimal interpolation in an RKHS. Let f:Î©â†’â„:ğ‘“â†’Î©â„f\colon\Omega\to\mathbb{R} be any function (i.e., not necessarily an element of the RKHS) that is to be interpolated at a set of distinct points X={xi}i=1nâŠ‚Î©ğ‘‹superscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘–1ğ‘›Î©X=\{x_{i}\}_{i=1}^{n}\subset\Omega. The kernel interpolant sf,Xsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘“ğ‘‹s_{f,X} is the unique minimum norm interpolant toÂ fğ‘“f at these points:

sf,X=argâ€‹minsâˆˆHâ€‹(K,Î©)â¡{âˆ¥sâˆ¥Hâ€‹(K,Î©):sâ€‹(xi)=fâ€‹(xi)â€‹Â for everyÂ â€‹i=1,â€¦,n}.subscriptğ‘ ğ‘“ğ‘‹subscriptargminğ‘ ğ»ğ¾Î©:subscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ‘ ğ»ğ¾Î©ğ‘ subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘“subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–Â for everyÂ ğ‘–1â€¦ğ‘›s_{f,X}=\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{s\in H(K,\Omega)}\big{\{}\mathinner{\lVert s\rVert}_{H(K,\Omega)}\,\mathrel{\mathop{\ordinarycolon}}\,s(x_{i})=f(x_{i})\text{ for every }i=1,\ldots,n\big{\}}. (7.2)

The kernel interpolant has the explicit linear-algebraic form

sf,Xâ€‹(x)=Kâ€‹(x,X)ğ–³â€‹Kâ€‹(X,X)âˆ’1â€‹fâ€‹(X),subscriptğ‘ ğ‘“ğ‘‹ğ‘¥ğ¾superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘‹ğ–³ğ¾superscriptğ‘‹ğ‘‹1ğ‘“ğ‘‹s_{f,X}(x)=K(x,X)^{\mathsf{T}}K(X,X)^{-1}f(X), (7.3)

which equals the conditional mean inÂ (2.4) when mâ‰¡0ğ‘š0m\equiv 0. This is the famous equivalence between Gaussian process interpolation and optimal interpolation in an RKHS whose origins can be traced back at least to the work of Kimeldorf and Wahba (1970). FromÂ (7.3) it is straightforward to compute thatÂ (e.g., Fasshauer, 2011, SectionÂ 5.1)

âˆ¥sf,Xâˆ¥Hâ€‹(K,Î©)2=fâ€‹(X)ğ–³â€‹Kâ€‹(X,X)âˆ’1â€‹fâ€‹(X),superscriptsubscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ‘ ğ‘“ğ‘‹ğ»ğ¾Î©2ğ‘“superscriptğ‘‹ğ–³ğ¾superscriptğ‘‹ğ‘‹1ğ‘“ğ‘‹\mathinner{\lVert s_{f,X}\rVert}_{H(K,\Omega)}^{2}=f(X)^{\mathsf{T}}K(X,X)^{-1}f(X), (7.4)

which equals the data-fit term inÂ (2.8) for mâ‰¡0ğ‘š0m\equiv 0. Note that a particular implication ofÂ (7.2) andÂ (7.4) is that fâ€‹(X)ğ–³â€‹Kâ€‹(X,X)âˆ’1â€‹fâ€‹(X)â‰¤âˆ¥fâˆ¥Hâ€‹(K,Î©)2ğ‘“superscriptğ‘‹ğ–³ğ¾superscriptğ‘‹ğ‘‹1ğ‘“ğ‘‹superscriptsubscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ‘“ğ»ğ¾Î©2f(X)^{\mathsf{T}}K(X,X)^{-1}f(X)\leq\mathinner{\lVert f\rVert}_{H(K,\Omega)}^{2} if fâˆˆHâ€‹(K,Î©)ğ‘“ğ»ğ¾Î©f\in H(K,\Omega). How these properties of sf,Xsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘“ğ‘‹s_{f,X} follow is explained in more detail in the proof of PropositionÂ 7.10 concerning interpolation based on general linear data. For the conditional variance we use the notation

PXâ€‹(x)2=Kâ€‹(x,x)âˆ’Kâ€‹(x,X)ğ–³â€‹Kâ€‹(X,X)âˆ’1â€‹Kâ€‹(X,x),subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘‹superscriptğ‘¥2ğ¾ğ‘¥ğ‘¥ğ¾superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘‹ğ–³ğ¾superscriptğ‘‹ğ‘‹1ğ¾ğ‘‹ğ‘¥P_{X}(x)^{2}=K(x,x)-K(x,X)^{\mathsf{T}}K(X,X)^{-1}K(X,x), (7.5)

which makes the dependency on the points Xğ‘‹X explicit. Now, for every xâˆˆÎ©ğ‘¥Î©x\in\Omega it holds thatÂ (e.g., Wendland, 2005, TheoremÂ 11.4)

|fâ€‹(x)âˆ’sf,Xâ€‹(x)|â‰¤âˆ¥fâˆ¥Hâ€‹(K,Î©)â€‹PXâ€‹(x)ğ‘“ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘ ğ‘“ğ‘‹ğ‘¥subscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ‘“ğ»ğ¾Î©subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘‹ğ‘¥\mathinner{\lvert f(x)-s_{f,X}(x)\rvert}\leq\mathinner{\lVert f\rVert}_{H(K,\Omega)}P_{X}(x) (7.6)

if fâˆˆHâ€‹(K,Î©)ğ‘“ğ»ğ¾Î©f\in H(K,\Omega), so that the conditional standard deviation controls the interpolation error.

7.2 On Notation

The proofs require notation that is more expressive than what we have used elsewhere in this article. Therefore the conditional variance inÂ (2.5) equals the conditional varianceÂ (7.5) whose dependency on the covariates has been made explicit. Similarly, the function sğ‘ s inÂ (2.6) equals the kernel interpolant sf,Xsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘“ğ‘‹s_{f,X} inÂ (7.3) for any function fğ‘“f such that fâ€‹(X)=Ymğ‘“ğ‘‹subscriptğ‘Œğ‘šf(X)=Y_{m}. It is often necessary or useful to indicate that various quantities depend on the kernel parameters (eitherÂ Î¸ğœƒ\theta orÂ Î»ğœ†\lambda). We use subscripts for this purpose. Subscripts are also used as shorthands for point sets formed by removing some elements of X={xi}i=1nğ‘‹superscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘–1ğ‘›X=\{x_{i}\}_{i=1}^{n} in the following way: Xk={xi}i=1ksubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘–1ğ‘˜X_{k}=\{x_{i}\}_{i=1}^{k} and Xn,k=Xâˆ–{xk}subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘›ğ‘˜ğ‘‹subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜X_{n,k}=X\setminus\{x_{k}\}. Analogous notation is used for the conditional standard deviation and mean and the kernel interpolant constructed at these point sets, so that

PÎ¸,k=PÎ¸,Xk=PÎ¸,{x1,â€¦,xk}Â andÂ PÎ¸,n,k=PÎ¸,Xn,k=PÎ¸,Xâˆ–{xk}formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘ƒğœƒğ‘˜subscriptğ‘ƒğœƒsubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘ƒğœƒsubscriptğ‘¥1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜Â andÂ subscriptğ‘ƒğœƒğ‘›ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘ƒğœƒsubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘›ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘ƒğœƒğ‘‹subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜P_{\theta,k}=P_{\theta,X_{k}}=P_{\theta,\{x_{1},\ldots,x_{k}\}}\quad\text{ and }\quad P_{\theta,n,k}=P_{\theta,X_{n,k}}=P_{\theta,X\setminus\{x_{k}\}}

and

sÎ¸,k=sÎ¸,f,Xk=sÎ¸,f,{x1,â€¦,xk}Â andÂ sÎ¸,n,k=sÎ¸,f,Xn,k=sÎ¸,f,Xâˆ–{xk}formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘ ğœƒğ‘˜subscriptğ‘ ğœƒğ‘“subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘ ğœƒğ‘“subscriptğ‘¥1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜Â andÂ subscriptğ‘ ğœƒğ‘›ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘ ğœƒğ‘“subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘›ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘ ğœƒğ‘“ğ‘‹subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜s_{\theta,k}=s_{\theta,f,X_{k}}=s_{\theta,f,\{x_{1},\ldots,x_{k}\}}\quad\text{ and }\quad s_{\theta,n,k}=s_{\theta,f,X_{n,k}}=s_{\theta,f,X\setminus\{x_{k}\}}

for kâ‰¤nğ‘˜ğ‘›k\leq n and fğ‘“f such that fâ€‹(X)=Ymğ‘“ğ‘‹subscriptğ‘Œğ‘šf(X)=Y_{m}. These notational conventions are reintroduced preceding their use in the proofs.

7.3 Sobolev Spaces

For Î±â‰¥0ğ›¼0\alpha\geq 0, the Sobolev space W2Î±â€‹(â„d)superscriptsubscriptğ‘Š2ğ›¼superscriptâ„ğ‘‘W_{2}^{\alpha}(\mathbb{R}^{d}) consists of square-integrable functions f:â„dâ†’â„:ğ‘“â†’superscriptâ„ğ‘‘â„f\colon\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R} such that

âˆ¥fâˆ¥W2Î±â€‹(â„d)2=âˆ«â„d(1+âˆ¥Î¾âˆ¥2)Î±â€‹|f^â€‹(Î¾)|2â€‹dâ¡Î¾<âˆ.superscriptsubscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ‘“superscriptsubscriptğ‘Š2ğ›¼superscriptâ„ğ‘‘2subscriptsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘superscript1superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğœ‰2ğ›¼superscript^ğ‘“ğœ‰2dğœ‰\mathinner{\lVert f\rVert}_{W_{2}^{\alpha}(\mathbb{R}^{d})}^{2}=\int_{\mathbb{R}^{d}}(1+\mathinner{\lVert\xi\rVert}^{2})^{\alpha}\mathinner{\lvert\widehat{f}(\xi)\rvert}^{2}\operatorname{d\!}\xi<\infty. (7.7)

On Î©âŠ‚â„dÎ©superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\Omega\subset\mathbb{R}^{d}, the Sobolev space W2Î±â€‹(Î©)superscriptsubscriptğ‘Š2ğ›¼Î©W_{2}^{\alpha}(\Omega) consists of those f:Î©â†’â„:ğ‘“â†’Î©â„f\colon\Omega\to\mathbb{R} which admit an extension feâˆˆW2Î±â€‹(â„d)subscriptğ‘“ğ‘’superscriptsubscriptğ‘Š2ğ›¼superscriptâ„ğ‘‘f_{e}\in W_{2}^{\alpha}(\mathbb{R}^{d}) such that fe|Î©=fevaluated-atsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘’Î©ğ‘“f_{e}|_{\Omega}=f. The norm of W2Î±â€‹(Î©)superscriptsubscriptğ‘Š2ğ›¼Î©W_{2}^{\alpha}(\Omega) is

âˆ¥fâˆ¥W2Î±â€‹(Î©)=inffeâˆˆW2Î±â€‹(â„d){âˆ¥feâˆ¥W2Î±â€‹(â„d):fe|Î©=f}.subscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ‘“superscriptsubscriptğ‘Š2ğ›¼Î©subscriptinfimumsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘’superscriptsubscriptğ‘Š2ğ›¼superscriptâ„ğ‘‘:subscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ‘“ğ‘’superscriptsubscriptğ‘Š2ğ›¼superscriptâ„ğ‘‘evaluated-atsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘’Î©ğ‘“\mathinner{\lVert f\rVert}_{W_{2}^{\alpha}(\Omega)}=\inf_{f_{e}\in W_{2}^{\alpha}(\mathbb{R}^{d})}\big{\{}\mathinner{\lVert f_{e}\rVert}_{W_{2}^{\alpha}(\mathbb{R}^{d})}\,\mathrel{\mathop{\ordinarycolon}}\,f_{e}|_{\Omega}=f\big{\}}. (7.8)

If Î±âˆˆâ„•0ğ›¼subscriptâ„•0\alpha\in\mathbb{N}_{0}, W2Î±â€‹(â„d)superscriptsubscriptğ‘Š2ğ›¼superscriptâ„ğ‘‘W_{2}^{\alpha}(\mathbb{R}^{d}) consists of functions whose weak derivatives up to order Î±ğ›¼\alpha exist and are square-integrable. It is a standard resultÂ (e.g., Wendland, 2005, CorollaryÂ 10.13) that for a kernel Kğ¾K which satisfies AssumptionÂ 2.2 the RKHS Hâ€‹(K,â„d)ğ»ğ¾superscriptâ„ğ‘‘H(K,\mathbb{R}^{d}) is norm-equivalent to W2Î±â€‹(â„d)superscriptsubscriptğ‘Š2ğ›¼superscriptâ„ğ‘‘W_{2}^{\alpha}(\mathbb{R}^{d}). This is to say that Hâ€‹(K,â„d)ğ»ğ¾superscriptâ„ğ‘‘H(K,\mathbb{R}^{d}) and W2Î±â€‹(â„d)superscriptsubscriptğ‘Š2ğ›¼superscriptâ„ğ‘‘W_{2}^{\alpha}(\mathbb{R}^{d}) are equal as sets and that there are positive constants C1subscriptğ¶1C_{1} and C2subscriptğ¶2C_{2} such that

C1â€‹âˆ¥fâˆ¥W2Î±â€‹(â„d)â‰¤âˆ¥fâˆ¥Hâ€‹(K,â„d)â‰¤C2â€‹âˆ¥fâˆ¥W2Î±â€‹(â„d)subscriptğ¶1subscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ‘“superscriptsubscriptğ‘Š2ğ›¼superscriptâ„ğ‘‘subscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ‘“ğ»ğ¾superscriptâ„ğ‘‘subscriptğ¶2subscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ‘“superscriptsubscriptğ‘Š2ğ›¼superscriptâ„ğ‘‘C_{1}\mathinner{\lVert f\rVert}_{W_{2}^{\alpha}(\mathbb{R}^{d})}\leq\mathinner{\lVert f\rVert}_{H(K,\mathbb{R}^{d})}\leq C_{2}\mathinner{\lVert f\rVert}_{W_{2}^{\alpha}(\mathbb{R}^{d})}

for every fâˆˆHâ€‹(K,â„d)ğ‘“ğ»ğ¾superscriptâ„ğ‘‘f\in H(K,\mathbb{R}^{d}). An analogous result carries over to Hâ€‹(K,Î©)ğ»ğ¾Î©H(K,\Omega), which is related to Hâ€‹(K,â„d)ğ»ğ¾superscriptâ„ğ‘‘H(K,\mathbb{R}^{d}) in the same way as W2Î±â€‹(Î©)superscriptsubscriptğ‘Š2ğ›¼Î©W_{2}^{\alpha}(\Omega) is to W2Î±â€‹(â„d)superscriptsubscriptğ‘Š2ğ›¼superscriptâ„ğ‘‘W_{2}^{\alpha}(\mathbb{R}^{d}) viaÂ (7.8). We use the following two facts in the proof of TheoremÂ 2.3:

  • â€¢

    Let BğµB be any open ball centered at the origin. Then constant functions are contained in W2Î±â€‹(Î©)superscriptsubscriptğ‘Š2ğ›¼Î©W_{2}^{\alpha}(\Omega) for any Î±â‰¥0ğ›¼0\alpha\geq 0 because one can construct a bump function which is constant in BğµB and whose Fourier transform decays with a super-algebraic rate.

  • â€¢

    The function Î¦Î¦\Phi, which defines Kğ¾K in AssumptionÂ 2.2, is HÃ¶lder continuous with the exponent Î²â€‹(Î±)=minâ¡{1,Î±âˆ’d/2}>0ğ›½ğ›¼1ğ›¼ğ‘‘20{\beta(\alpha)=\min\{1,\alpha-d/2\}>0} on any sufficiently regular domain Î©Î©\Omega (e.g., an open ball). That is, there is a positive constant Cğ¶C such that

    |Î¦â€‹(0)âˆ’Î¦â€‹(x)|â‰¤Câ€‹âˆ¥xâˆ¥Î²â€‹(Î±)Î¦0Î¦ğ‘¥ğ¶superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ‘¥ğ›½ğ›¼\mathinner{\lvert\Phi(0)-\Phi(x)\rvert}\leq C\mathinner{\lVert x\rVert}^{\beta(\alpha)} (7.9)

    for any xâˆˆÎ©ğ‘¥Î©x\in\Omega. This assertion is a consequence of the classical inclusion relation between Sobolev and HÃ¶lder spacesÂ (e.g., Triebel, 1978, RemarkÂ 2 on p.Â 206). That Î¦Î¦\Phi is an element of W2Î±â€‹(â„d)superscriptsubscriptğ‘Š2ğ›¼superscriptâ„ğ‘‘W_{2}^{\alpha}(\mathbb{R}^{d}) is easy to verify usingÂ (2.9) andÂ (7.7).

7.4 Proof of TheoremÂ 2.3

We split the proof of TheoremÂ 2.3, which is repeated below, in two.

See 2.3

EquationÂ 2.11 is a rather straightforward consequence ofÂ (7.4) when one interprets Î»ğœ†\lambda as a scaling of the covariate set instead of a kernel parameter, while proving EquationÂ 2.12 requires some more work, including upper and lower bounds for the conditional variance. Most of the proof of EquationÂ 2.11 is contained in the following lemmas, which will be used again in SectionÂ 7.6.

Lemma 7.1 (Continuity of the data-fit and model complexity)

Suppose that Î¦Î¦\Phi is continuous and nâ‰¥1ğ‘›1n\geq 1. Then the functions

fdfâ€‹(Î»)=Ymğ–³â€‹KÎ»â€‹(X,X)âˆ’1â€‹YmÂ andÂ fmcâ€‹(Î»)=logâ€‹detKÎ»â€‹(X,X)formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘“dfğœ†superscriptsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘šğ–³subscriptğ¾ğœ†superscriptğ‘‹ğ‘‹1subscriptğ‘Œğ‘šÂ andÂ subscriptğ‘“mcğœ†subscriptğ¾ğœ†ğ‘‹ğ‘‹f_{\textup{df}}(\lambda)=Y_{m}^{\mathsf{T}}K_{\lambda}(X,X)^{-1}Y_{m}\quad\text{ and }\quad f_{\textup{mc}}(\lambda)=\log\det K_{\lambda}(X,X)

are well-defined and continuous on (0,âˆ)0(0,\infty).

ProofÂ  Define XÎ»={xi/Î»}i=1nsubscriptğ‘‹ğœ†superscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğœ†ğ‘–1ğ‘›X_{\lambda}=\{x_{i}/\lambda\}_{i=1}^{n} and observe that KÎ»â€‹(X,X)=Kâ€‹(XÎ»,XÎ»)subscriptğ¾ğœ†ğ‘‹ğ‘‹ğ¾subscriptğ‘‹ğœ†subscriptğ‘‹ğœ†K_{\lambda}(X,X)=K(X_{\lambda},X_{\lambda}). Since Kğ¾K is a positive-definite kernel and the covariates Xğ‘‹X are distinct, this shows that KÎ»â€‹(X,X)subscriptğ¾ğœ†ğ‘‹ğ‘‹K_{\lambda}(X,X) is positive-definite and hence non-singular for every Î»>0ğœ†0\lambda>0. In particular, detKÎ»â€‹(X,X)>0subscriptğ¾ğœ†ğ‘‹ğ‘‹0\det K_{\lambda}(X,X)>0 for every Î»>0ğœ†0\lambda>0 by positive-definiteness. Therefore the functions fdfsubscriptğ‘“dff_{\textup{df}} and fmcsubscriptğ‘“mcf_{\textup{mc}} are well-defined. Because Kâ€‹(x,y)=Î¦â€‹(xâˆ’y)ğ¾ğ‘¥ğ‘¦Î¦ğ‘¥ğ‘¦K(x,y)=\Phi(x-y) is continuous, each element of KÎ»â€‹(X,X)subscriptğ¾ğœ†ğ‘‹ğ‘‹K_{\lambda}(X,X) is a continuous function of Î»ğœ†\lambda. From the definition of the determinant it immediately follows that fmcsubscriptğ‘“mcf_{\textup{mc}} is continuous. The continuity of fdfsubscriptğ‘“dff_{\textup{df}} is then a consequence of, for example, Cramerâ€™s rule and the positivity of detKÎ»â€‹(X,X)subscriptğ¾ğœ†ğ‘‹ğ‘‹\det K_{\lambda}(X,X). Â 

Lemma 7.2 (Boundedness of the data-fit term)

Suppose that Kğ¾K satisfies AssumptionÂ 2.2 and nâ‰¥1ğ‘›1n\geq 1. If the data Yğ‘ŒY are mğ‘šm-constant, then there is a constant a>0ğ‘0a>0 such that

supÎ»>0Ymğ–³â€‹KÎ»â€‹(X,X)âˆ’1â€‹Ymâ‰¤a.subscriptsupremumğœ†0superscriptsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘šğ–³subscriptğ¾ğœ†superscriptğ‘‹ğ‘‹1subscriptğ‘Œğ‘šğ‘\sup_{\lambda>0}Y_{m}^{\mathsf{T}}K_{\lambda}(X,X)^{-1}Y_{m}\leq a.

ProofÂ  Because the data Yğ‘ŒY are mğ‘šm-constant, we can write Ym=Yâˆ’mâ€‹(X)=fâ€‹(X)subscriptğ‘Œğ‘šğ‘Œğ‘šğ‘‹ğ‘“ğ‘‹Y_{m}=Y-m(X)=f(X) for some constant function fğ‘“f. Define XÎ»={xi/Î»}i=1nsubscriptğ‘‹ğœ†superscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğœ†ğ‘–1ğ‘›X_{\lambda}=\{x_{i}/\lambda\}_{i=1}^{n} and observe that, since fâ€‹(XÎ»)ğ‘“subscriptğ‘‹ğœ†f(X_{\lambda}) does not depend onÂ Î»ğœ†\lambda,

Ymğ–³â€‹KÎ»â€‹(X,X)âˆ’1â€‹Ym=fâ€‹(XÎ»)ğ–³â€‹Kâ€‹(XÎ»,XÎ»)âˆ’1â€‹fâ€‹(XÎ»).superscriptsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘šğ–³subscriptğ¾ğœ†superscriptğ‘‹ğ‘‹1subscriptğ‘Œğ‘šğ‘“superscriptsubscriptğ‘‹ğœ†ğ–³ğ¾superscriptsubscriptğ‘‹ğœ†subscriptğ‘‹ğœ†1ğ‘“subscriptğ‘‹ğœ†Y_{m}^{\mathsf{T}}K_{\lambda}(X,X)^{-1}Y_{m}=f(X_{\lambda})^{\mathsf{T}}K(X_{\lambda},X_{\lambda})^{-1}f(X_{\lambda}).

The RKHS Hâ€‹(K,B)ğ»ğ¾ğµH(K,B) contains constant functions if BğµB is any open ball centered at the origin by the results in SectionÂ 7.3. Because Xğ‘‹X contains a finite number of points, we can trivially select BğµB such that XâŠ‚Bğ‘‹ğµX\subset B. Then the set XÎ»subscriptğ‘‹ğœ†X_{\lambda} is also contained in BğµB whenever Î»â‰¥1ğœ†1\lambda\geq 1. Therefore fâˆˆHâ€‹(K,B)ğ‘“ğ»ğ¾ğµf\in H(K,B) and it follows fromÂ (7.2) andÂ (7.4) that

fâ€‹(XÎ»)ğ–³â€‹Kâ€‹(XÎ»,XÎ»)âˆ’1â€‹fâ€‹(XÎ»)â‰¤âˆ¥fâˆ¥Hâ€‹(K,B)2ğ‘“superscriptsubscriptğ‘‹ğœ†ğ–³ğ¾superscriptsubscriptğ‘‹ğœ†subscriptğ‘‹ğœ†1ğ‘“subscriptğ‘‹ğœ†superscriptsubscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ‘“ğ»ğ¾ğµ2f(X_{\lambda})^{\mathsf{T}}K(X_{\lambda},X_{\lambda})^{-1}f(X_{\lambda})\leq\mathinner{\lVert f\rVert}_{H(K,B)}^{2} (7.10)

if Î»â‰¥1ğœ†1\lambda\geq 1. Because Kâ€‹(x,y)=Î¦â€‹(xâˆ’y)ğ¾ğ‘¥ğ‘¦Î¦ğ‘¥ğ‘¦K(x,y)=\Phi(x-y) for Î¦Î¦\Phi which is continuous and integrable on â„dsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbb{R}^{d},

Kâ€‹(xiÎ»,xiÎ»)=Î¦â€‹(0)>0Â andÂ limÎ»â†’0Kâ€‹(xiÎ»,xjÎ»)=limÎ»â†’0Î¦â€‹(xiâˆ’xjÎ»)=0formulae-sequenceğ¾subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğœ†subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğœ†Î¦00Â andÂ subscriptâ†’ğœ†0ğ¾subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğœ†subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—ğœ†subscriptâ†’ğœ†0Î¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—ğœ†0K\bigg{(}\frac{x_{i}}{\lambda},\frac{x_{i}}{\lambda}\bigg{)}=\Phi(0)>0\quad\text{ and }\quad\lim_{\lambda\to 0}K\bigg{(}\frac{x_{i}}{\lambda},\frac{x_{j}}{\lambda}\bigg{)}=\lim_{\lambda\to 0}\Phi\bigg{(}\frac{x_{i}-x_{j}}{\lambda}\bigg{)}=0

for all iâ‰ jğ‘–ğ‘—i\neq j. That is, KÎ»â€‹(X,X)=Kâ€‹(XÎ»,XÎ»)subscriptğ¾ğœ†ğ‘‹ğ‘‹ğ¾subscriptğ‘‹ğœ†subscriptğ‘‹ğœ†K_{\lambda}(X,X)=K(X_{\lambda},X_{\lambda}) tends to a non-zero diagonal matrix as Î»â†’0â†’ğœ†0\lambda\to 0. Thus by LemmaÂ 7.1, which guarantees the Î»ğœ†\lambda-continuity of the data-fit term,

limÎ»â†’0Ymğ–³â€‹KÎ»â€‹(X,X)âˆ’1â€‹Ym=Î¦â€‹(0)âˆ’1â€‹âˆ¥Ymâˆ¥2<âˆ.subscriptâ†’ğœ†0superscriptsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘šğ–³subscriptğ¾ğœ†superscriptğ‘‹ğ‘‹1subscriptğ‘Œğ‘šÎ¦superscript01superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ‘Œğ‘š2\lim_{\lambda\to 0}Y_{m}^{\mathsf{T}}K_{\lambda}(X,X)^{-1}Y_{m}=\Phi(0)^{-1}\mathinner{\lVert Y_{m}\rVert}^{2}<\infty. (7.11)

FromÂ (7.10) andÂ (7.11) and LemmaÂ 7.1 we conclude that there is a constant a>0ğ‘0a>0 such that

Ymğ–³â€‹KÎ»â€‹(X,X)âˆ’1â€‹Ym=fâ€‹(XÎ»)ğ–³â€‹Kâ€‹(XÎ»,XÎ»)âˆ’1â€‹fâ€‹(XÎ»)â‰¤asuperscriptsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘šğ–³subscriptğ¾ğœ†superscriptğ‘‹ğ‘‹1subscriptğ‘Œğ‘šğ‘“superscriptsubscriptğ‘‹ğœ†ğ–³ğ¾superscriptsubscriptğ‘‹ğœ†subscriptğ‘‹ğœ†1ğ‘“subscriptğ‘‹ğœ†ğ‘Y_{m}^{\mathsf{T}}K_{\lambda}(X,X)^{-1}Y_{m}=f(X_{\lambda})^{\mathsf{T}}K(X_{\lambda},X_{\lambda})^{-1}f(X_{\lambda})\leq a

for every Î»>0ğœ†0\lambda>0. Â 

Proof of EquationÂ 2.11 By LemmaÂ 7.2, there is a>0ğ‘0a>0 such that

0â‰¤Ymğ–³â€‹KÎ»â€‹(X,X)âˆ’1â€‹Ymâ‰¤a0superscriptsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘šğ–³subscriptğ¾ğœ†superscriptğ‘‹ğ‘‹1subscriptğ‘Œğ‘šğ‘0\leq Y_{m}^{\mathsf{T}}K_{\lambda}(X,X)^{-1}Y_{m}\leq a (7.12)

for all Î»>0ğœ†0\lambda>0. Stationarity and continuity of Î¦Î¦\Phi imply that KÎ»â€‹(X,X)subscriptğ¾ğœ†ğ‘‹ğ‘‹K_{\lambda}(X,X) converges to the identity matrix times Î¦â€‹(0)Î¦0\Phi(0) as Î»â†’0â†’ğœ†0\lambda\to 0 and to the singular matrix of Î¦â€‹(0)Î¦0\Phi(0)â€™s as Î»â†’âˆâ†’ğœ†\lambda\to\infty. Thus it follows from LemmaÂ 7.1 that

logâ€‹detKÎ»â€‹(X,X)â†’âˆ’âˆâ†’subscriptğ¾ğœ†ğ‘‹ğ‘‹\log\det K_{\lambda}(X,X)\to-\infty (7.13)

if and only if Î»â†’âˆâ†’ğœ†\lambda\to\infty. By combiningÂ (7.12) andÂ (7.13) we conclude that

â„“â€‹(Î»âˆ£Y)=Ymğ–³â€‹KÎ»â€‹(X,X)âˆ’1â€‹Ym+logâ€‹detKÎ»â€‹(X,X)â†’âˆ’âˆâ„“conditionalğœ†ğ‘Œsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘šğ–³subscriptğ¾ğœ†superscriptğ‘‹ğ‘‹1subscriptğ‘Œğ‘šsubscriptğ¾ğœ†ğ‘‹ğ‘‹â†’\ell(\lambda\mid Y)=Y_{m}^{\mathsf{T}}K_{\lambda}(X,X)^{-1}Y_{m}+\log\det K_{\lambda}(X,X)\to-\infty

if and only if Î»â†’âˆâ†’ğœ†\lambda\to\infty. Therefore Î»ML=argâ€‹minÎ»>0â¡â„“â€‹(Î»âˆ£Y)=âˆsubscriptğœ†MLsubscriptargminğœ†0â„“conditionalğœ†ğ‘Œ\lambda_{\textup{ML}}=\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{\lambda>0}\ell(\lambda\mid Y)=\infty. Â 

Three auxiliary results are needed to prove EquationÂ 2.12. The first of theseâ€”or its variantsâ€”is well known in scattered data approximation literatureÂ (e.g., Schaback, 1995). The version that we need here is contained in the proof of TheoremÂ 4.4 in Karvonen etÂ al. (2020).

Proposition 7.3

Suppose that Kğ¾K satisfies AssumptionÂ 2.2 and let X={xi}i=1nğ‘‹superscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘–1ğ‘›X=\{x_{i}\}_{i=1}^{n} be any set of distinct points in â„dsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbb{R}^{d}. Define âˆ¥xâˆ’Xâˆ¥=mini=1,â€¦,nâ¡âˆ¥xâˆ’xiâˆ¥delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ‘¥ğ‘‹subscriptğ‘–1â€¦ğ‘›delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–\mathinner{\lVert x-X\rVert}=\min_{i=1,\ldots,n}\mathinner{\lVert x-x_{i}\rVert}. Then there is a positive constantÂ Cğ¶C, which does not depend on xğ‘¥x or Xğ‘‹X, such that

PXâ€‹(x)2â‰¥Câ€‹âˆ¥xâˆ’Xâˆ¥2â€‹Î±âˆ’dsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘‹superscriptğ‘¥2ğ¶superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ‘¥ğ‘‹2ğ›¼ğ‘‘P_{X}(x)^{2}\geq C\mathinner{\lVert x-X\rVert}^{2\alpha-d}

for any xâˆˆâ„dğ‘¥superscriptâ„ğ‘‘x\in\mathbb{R}^{d} for which âˆ¥xâˆ’Xâˆ¥â‰¤1delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ‘¥ğ‘‹1\mathinner{\lVert x-X\rVert}\leq 1, where Î±>d/2ğ›¼ğ‘‘2\alpha>d/2 is the constant in AssumptionÂ 2.2.

The second auxiliary result, which is standard and essentially ExerciseÂ 8.66 in Iske (2018), gives a rough upper bound on the conditional variance under AssumptionÂ 2.2.

Proposition 7.4

Suppose that Kğ¾K satisfies AssumptionÂ 2.2 and let X={xi}i=1nğ‘‹superscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘–1ğ‘›X=\{x_{i}\}_{i=1}^{n} be any set of distinct points in â„dsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbb{R}^{d}. Let âˆ¥xâˆ’Xâˆ¥=mini=1,â€¦,nâ¡âˆ¥xâˆ’xiâˆ¥delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ‘¥ğ‘‹subscriptğ‘–1â€¦ğ‘›delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–\mathinner{\lVert x-X\rVert}=\min_{i=1,\ldots,n}\mathinner{\lVert x-x_{i}\rVert} and Î²â€‹(Î±)=minâ¡{1,Î±âˆ’d/2}>0ğ›½ğ›¼1ğ›¼ğ‘‘20\beta(\alpha)=\min\{1,\alpha-d/2\}>0, where Î±>d/2ğ›¼ğ‘‘2\alpha>d/2 is the constant in AssumptionÂ 2.2. Then there is a positive constant Cğ¶C, which does not depend on xğ‘¥x or Xğ‘‹X, such that

PXâ€‹(x)2â‰¤Câ€‹âˆ¥xâˆ’Xâˆ¥Î²â€‹(Î±)subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘‹superscriptğ‘¥2ğ¶superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ‘¥ğ‘‹ğ›½ğ›¼P_{X}(x)^{2}\leq C\mathinner{\lVert x-X\rVert}^{\beta(\alpha)}

for any xâˆˆâ„dğ‘¥superscriptâ„ğ‘‘x\in\mathbb{R}^{d} for which âˆ¥xâˆ’Xâˆ¥delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ‘¥ğ‘‹\mathinner{\lVert x-X\rVert} is sufficiently small.

ProofÂ  Let xâˆ—âˆˆXsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘‹x^{*}\in X be such that âˆ¥xâˆ’xâˆ—âˆ¥=âˆ¥xâˆ’Xâˆ¥delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¥delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ‘¥ğ‘‹\mathinner{\lVert x-x^{*}\rVert}=\mathinner{\lVert x-X\rVert}. Because the standard deviation is a non-decreasing function in that PXâ€‹(x)â‰¤PXâ€²â€‹(x)subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘‹ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘ƒsuperscriptğ‘‹â€²ğ‘¥P_{X}(x)\leq P_{X^{\prime}}(x) for any xğ‘¥x if Xâ€²âŠ‚Xsuperscriptğ‘‹â€²ğ‘‹X^{\prime}\subset XÂ (e.g., Wendland, 2005, TheoremÂ 16.11), we have

PXâ€‹(x)â‰¤P{xâˆ—}â€‹(x).subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘‹ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘ƒsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¥P_{X}(x)\leq P_{\{x^{*}\}}(x). (7.14)

Using the stationarity assumption andÂ (7.5) we write

P{xâˆ—}â€‹(x)2=Kâ€‹(x,x)âˆ’Kâ€‹(x,xâˆ—)2Kâ€‹(xâˆ—,xâˆ—)=Î¦â€‹(0)âˆ’Î¦â€‹(xâˆ’xâˆ—)2Î¦â€‹(0)=1Î¦â€‹(0)â€‹(Î¦â€‹(0)+Î¦â€‹(xâˆ’xâˆ—))â€‹(Î¦â€‹(0)âˆ’Î¦â€‹(xâˆ’xâˆ—)).subscriptğ‘ƒsuperscriptğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¥2ğ¾ğ‘¥ğ‘¥ğ¾superscriptğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¥2ğ¾superscriptğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¥Î¦0Î¦superscriptğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¥2Î¦01Î¦0Î¦0Î¦ğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¥Î¦0Î¦ğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¥\begin{split}P_{\{x^{*}\}}(x)^{2}=K(x,x)-\frac{K(x,x^{*})^{2}}{K(x^{*},x^{*})}&=\Phi(0)-\frac{\Phi(x-x^{*})^{2}}{\Phi(0)}\\ &=\frac{1}{\Phi(0)}\big{(}\Phi(0)+\Phi(x-x^{*})\big{)}\big{(}\Phi(0)-\Phi(x-x^{*})\big{)}.\end{split}

Applying the HÃ¶lder conditionÂ (7.9) to |Î¦â€‹(0)âˆ’Î¦â€‹(xâˆ’xâˆ—)|Î¦0Î¦ğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¥\mathinner{\lvert\Phi(0)-\Phi(x-x^{*})\rvert} and using Î¦â€‹(0)â‰¥Î¦â€‹(xâˆ’xâˆ—)Î¦0Î¦ğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¥\Phi(0)\geq\Phi(x-x^{*}), which follows from the positive-definiteness of Kâ€‹(x,y)=Î¦â€‹(xâˆ’y)ğ¾ğ‘¥ğ‘¦Î¦ğ‘¥ğ‘¦K(x,y)=\Phi(x-y), yields the estimate

P{xâˆ—}â€‹(x)2â‰¤Câ€‹âˆ¥xâˆ’xâˆ—âˆ¥Î²â€‹(Î±)=Câ€‹âˆ¥xâˆ’Xâˆ¥Î²â€‹(Î±)subscriptğ‘ƒsuperscriptğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¥2ğ¶superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¥ğ›½ğ›¼ğ¶superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ‘¥ğ‘‹ğ›½ğ›¼P_{\{x^{*}\}}(x)^{2}\leq C\mathinner{\lVert x-x^{*}\rVert}^{\beta(\alpha)}=C\mathinner{\lVert x-X\rVert}^{\beta(\alpha)}

for a certain positive constant Cğ¶C which depends only on Î¦Î¦\Phi. Using this bound inÂ (7.14) concludes the proof. Â 

Our third auxiliary result is an expression for the modified log-likelihood function. Although this expression has appeared in the literatureÂ (e.g., Xu and Stein, 2017, SectionÂ 4.2.2), we have not encountered its proof and therefore provide one based entirely on linear algebra, block matrix inversion, and determinantal identities. The expressions for the individual terms of the modified log-likelihood function are relatively well known. For the data-fit term, see Schaback and Werner (2006, TheoremÂ 6) or MÃ¼ller (2008, Bemerkung 3.1.4). We also point the reader to SectionÂ 3 in Scheuerer (2011). The expression for the model complexity term appear in literature on determinantal point processesÂ (e.g., Bardenet and Hardy, 2020, SectionÂ 2.4). For the purposes of this proposition and the proof of EquationÂ 2.12 we use the notation

PÎ¸,kâ€‹(x)=PÎ¸,{x1,â€¦,xk}â€‹(x)Â andÂ sÎ¸,kâ€‹(x)=sÎ¸,f,{x1,â€¦,xk}â€‹(x)formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘ƒğœƒğ‘˜ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘ƒğœƒsubscriptğ‘¥1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜ğ‘¥Â andÂ subscriptğ‘ ğœƒğ‘˜ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘ ğœƒğ‘“subscriptğ‘¥1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜ğ‘¥P_{\theta,k}(x)=P_{\theta,\{x_{1},\ldots,x_{k}\}}(x)\quad\text{ and }\quad s_{\theta,k}(x)=s_{\theta,f,\{x_{1},\ldots,x_{k}\}}(x)

for kâ‰¤nğ‘˜ğ‘›k\leq n.

Proposition 7.5

If the points X={xi}i=1nğ‘‹superscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘–1ğ‘›X=\{x_{i}\}_{i=1}^{n} are distinct, then

Ymğ–³â€‹KÎ¸â€‹(X,X)âˆ’1â€‹Ym=âˆ‘k=0nâˆ’1(yk+1âˆ’mâ€‹(xk+1)âˆ’sÎ¸,kâ€‹(xk+1)PÎ¸,kâ€‹(xk+1))2superscriptsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘šğ–³subscriptğ¾ğœƒsuperscriptğ‘‹ğ‘‹1subscriptğ‘Œğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘˜0ğ‘›1superscriptsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘˜1ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜1subscriptğ‘ ğœƒğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜1subscriptğ‘ƒğœƒğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜12Y_{m}^{\mathsf{T}}K_{\theta}(X,X)^{-1}Y_{m}=\sum_{k=0}^{n-1}\bigg{(}\frac{y_{k+1}-m(x_{k+1})-s_{\theta,k}(x_{k+1})}{P_{\theta,k}(x_{k+1})}\bigg{)}^{2} (7.15)

and

detKÎ¸â€‹(X,X)=âˆk=0nâˆ’1PÎ¸,kâ€‹(xk+1)2,subscriptğ¾ğœƒğ‘‹ğ‘‹superscriptsubscriptproductğ‘˜0ğ‘›1subscriptğ‘ƒğœƒğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜12\det K_{\theta}(X,X)=\prod_{k=0}^{n-1}P_{\theta,k}(x_{k+1})^{2}, (7.16)

where PÎ¸,0â€‹(x1)2=KÎ¸â€‹(x1,x1)subscriptğ‘ƒğœƒ0superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥12subscriptğ¾ğœƒsubscriptğ‘¥1subscriptğ‘¥1P_{\theta,0}(x_{1})^{2}=K_{\theta}(x_{1},x_{1}) and sÎ¸,0â€‹(x1)=0subscriptğ‘ ğœƒ0subscriptğ‘¥10s_{\theta,0}(x_{1})=0.

ProofÂ  Denote ym,k=ykâˆ’mâ€‹(xk)subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘šğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘˜ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜y_{m,k}=y_{k}-m(x_{k}) and Ym,k=(ym,1,â€¦,ym,k)âˆˆâ„ksubscriptğ‘Œğ‘šğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘š1â€¦subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘šğ‘˜superscriptâ„ğ‘˜Y_{m,k}=(y_{m,1},\ldots,y_{m,k})\in\mathbb{R}^{k} so that

Ymğ–³â€‹KÎ¸â€‹(X,X)âˆ’1â€‹Ym=(ym,nYm,nâˆ’1)ğ–³â€‹(KÎ¸â€‹(xn,xn)KÎ¸â€‹(xn,Xnâˆ’1)ğ–³KÎ¸â€‹(xn,Xnâˆ’1)KÎ¸â€‹(Xnâˆ’1,Xnâˆ’1))âˆ’1â€‹(ym,nYm,nâˆ’1).superscriptsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘šğ–³subscriptğ¾ğœƒsuperscriptğ‘‹ğ‘‹1subscriptğ‘Œğ‘šsuperscriptmatrixsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘šğ‘›subscriptğ‘Œğ‘šğ‘›1ğ–³superscriptmatrixsubscriptğ¾ğœƒsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›subscriptğ¾ğœƒsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘›1ğ–³subscriptğ¾ğœƒsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘›1subscriptğ¾ğœƒsubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘›1subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘›11matrixsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘šğ‘›subscriptğ‘Œğ‘šğ‘›1Y_{m}^{\mathsf{T}}K_{\theta}(X,X)^{-1}Y_{m}=\begin{pmatrix}y_{m,n}\\ Y_{m,n-1}\end{pmatrix}^{\mathsf{T}}\begin{pmatrix}K_{\theta}(x_{n},x_{n})&K_{\theta}(x_{n},X_{n-1})^{\mathsf{T}}\\ K_{\theta}(x_{n},X_{n-1})&K_{\theta}(X_{n-1},X_{n-1})\end{pmatrix}^{-1}\begin{pmatrix}y_{m,n}\\ Y_{m,n-1}\end{pmatrix}.

The block matrix inversion formula, a few lines of straightforward algebra, andÂ (2.4) andÂ (2.5) then yield

Ymğ–³â€‹KÎ¸â€‹(X,X)âˆ’1â€‹Ym=(ym,nâˆ’sÎ¸,nâˆ’1â€‹(xn)PÎ¸,nâˆ’1â€‹(xn))2+Ym,nâˆ’1ğ–³â€‹KÎ¸â€‹(Xnâˆ’1,Xnâˆ’1)âˆ’1â€‹Ym,nâˆ’1,superscriptsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘šğ–³subscriptğ¾ğœƒsuperscriptğ‘‹ğ‘‹1subscriptğ‘Œğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘šğ‘›subscriptğ‘ ğœƒğ‘›1subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›subscriptğ‘ƒğœƒğ‘›1subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›2superscriptsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘šğ‘›1ğ–³subscriptğ¾ğœƒsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘›1subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘›11subscriptğ‘Œğ‘šğ‘›1Y_{m}^{\mathsf{T}}K_{\theta}(X,X)^{-1}Y_{m}=\bigg{(}\frac{y_{m,n}-s_{\theta,n-1}(x_{n})}{P_{\theta,n-1}(x_{n})}\bigg{)}^{2}+Y_{m,n-1}^{\mathsf{T}}K_{\theta}(X_{n-1},X_{n-1})^{-1}Y_{m,n-1},

iteration of which yields the formÂ (7.15) for the data-fit term. The block determinant identity and the expressionÂ (2.5) for the conditional variance yield

detKÎ¸â€‹(X,X)=(KÎ¸â€‹(xn,xn)KÎ¸â€‹(xn,Xnâˆ’1)ğ–³KÎ¸â€‹(xn,Xnâˆ’1)KÎ¸â€‹(Xnâˆ’1,Xnâˆ’1))=[KÎ¸â€‹(xn,xn)âˆ’KÎ¸â€‹(xn,Xnâˆ’1)ğ–³â€‹KÎ¸â€‹(Xnâˆ’1,Xnâˆ’1)âˆ’1â€‹KÎ¸â€‹(xn,Xnâˆ’1)]Ã—detKÎ¸(Xnâˆ’1,Xnâˆ’1)=PÎ¸,nâˆ’1â€‹(xn)2â€‹detKÎ¸â€‹(Xnâˆ’1,Xnâˆ’1),subscriptğ¾ğœƒğ‘‹ğ‘‹matrixsubscriptğ¾ğœƒsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›subscriptğ¾ğœƒsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘›1ğ–³subscriptğ¾ğœƒsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘›1subscriptğ¾ğœƒsubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘›1subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘›1delimited-[]subscriptğ¾ğœƒsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›subscriptğ¾ğœƒsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘›1ğ–³subscriptğ¾ğœƒsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘›1subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘›11subscriptğ¾ğœƒsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘›1subscriptğ¾ğœƒsubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘›1subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘›1subscriptğ‘ƒğœƒğ‘›1superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›2subscriptğ¾ğœƒsubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘›1subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘›1\begin{split}\det K_{\theta}(X,X)={}&\begin{pmatrix}K_{\theta}(x_{n},x_{n})&K_{\theta}(x_{n},X_{n-1})^{\mathsf{T}}\\ K_{\theta}(x_{n},X_{n-1})&K_{\theta}(X_{n-1},X_{n-1})\end{pmatrix}\\ ={}&\big{[}K_{\theta}(x_{n},x_{n})-K_{\theta}(x_{n},X_{n-1})^{\mathsf{T}}K_{\theta}(X_{n-1},X_{n-1})^{-1}K_{\theta}(x_{n},X_{n-1})\big{]}\\ &\quad\times\det K_{\theta}(X_{n-1},X_{n-1})\\ ={}&P_{\theta,n-1}(x_{n})^{2}\det K_{\theta}(X_{n-1},X_{n-1}),\end{split}

iteration of which producesÂ (7.16). Â 

Lemma 7.6

Suppose that Kğ¾K satisfies AssumptionÂ 2.2 and let X={xi}i=1nğ‘‹superscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘–1ğ‘›X=\{x_{i}\}_{i=1}^{n} be any set of distinct points in â„dsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbb{R}^{d}. Then there is a constantÂ Cğ¶C, which does not depend on Î»ğœ†\lambda, such that

logâ€‹detKÎ»â€‹(X,X)â‰¥âˆ’(2â€‹Î±âˆ’d)â€‹nâ€‹logâ¡Î»+Csubscriptğ¾ğœ†ğ‘‹ğ‘‹2ğ›¼ğ‘‘ğ‘›ğœ†ğ¶\log\det K_{\lambda}(X,X)\geq-(2\alpha-d)n\log\lambda+C

for every sufficiently large Î»>0ğœ†0\lambda>0, where Î±>d/2ğ›¼ğ‘‘2\alpha>d/2 is the constant in AssumptionÂ 2.2.

ProofÂ  Let Xk={x1,â€¦,xk}subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¥1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜X_{k}=\{x_{1},\ldots,x_{k}\} and XÎ»,k=Î»âˆ’1â€‹Xk={Î»âˆ’1â€‹xi}i=1ksubscriptğ‘‹ğœ†ğ‘˜superscriptğœ†1subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptsuperscriptğœ†1subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘–1ğ‘˜X_{\lambda,k}=\lambda^{-1}X_{k}=\{\lambda^{-1}x_{i}\}_{i=1}^{k}. Because

PÎ»,kâ€‹(xk+1)=PXÎ»,kâ€‹(Î»âˆ’1â€‹xk+1)subscriptğ‘ƒğœ†ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜1subscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘‹ğœ†ğ‘˜superscriptğœ†1subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜1P_{\lambda,k}(x_{k+1})=P_{X_{\lambda,k}}(\lambda^{-1}x_{k+1})

and

âˆ¥Î»âˆ’1â€‹xk+1âˆ’XÎ»,kâˆ¥=mini=1,â€¦,kâ¡âˆ¥Î»âˆ’1â€‹(xk+1âˆ’xi)âˆ¥=Î»âˆ’1â€‹mini=1,â€¦,kâ¡âˆ¥xk+1âˆ’xiâˆ¥=Î»âˆ’1â€‹âˆ¥xk+1âˆ’Xkâˆ¥,delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥superscriptğœ†1subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜1subscriptğ‘‹ğœ†ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘–1â€¦ğ‘˜delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥superscriptğœ†1subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜1subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–superscriptğœ†1subscriptğ‘–1â€¦ğ‘˜delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜1subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–superscriptğœ†1delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜1subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘˜\begin{split}\mathinner{\lVert\lambda^{-1}x_{k+1}-X_{\lambda,k}\rVert}=\min_{i=1,\ldots,k}\mathinner{\lVert\lambda^{-1}(x_{k+1}-x_{i})\rVert}&=\lambda^{-1}\min_{i=1,\ldots,k}\mathinner{\lVert x_{k+1}-x_{i}\rVert}\\ &=\lambda^{-1}\mathinner{\lVert x_{k+1}-X_{k}\rVert},\end{split}

it follows from PropositionÂ 7.3, when applied to the points XÎ»,ksubscriptğ‘‹ğœ†ğ‘˜X_{\lambda,k}, that, for a positive constant Cğ¶C which does not depend on kğ‘˜k or Î»ğœ†\lambda,

logâ¡[PÎ»,kâ€‹(xk+1)2]=logâ¡[PXÎ»,kâ€‹(Î»âˆ’1â€‹xk+1)2]â‰¥âˆ’(2â€‹Î±âˆ’d)â€‹logâ¡Î»+(2â€‹Î±âˆ’d)â€‹logâ¡âˆ¥xk+1âˆ’Xkâˆ¥+logâ¡Csubscriptğ‘ƒğœ†ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜12subscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘‹ğœ†ğ‘˜superscriptsuperscriptğœ†1subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜122ğ›¼ğ‘‘ğœ†2ğ›¼ğ‘‘delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜1subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘˜ğ¶\begin{split}\log[P_{\lambda,k}(x_{k+1})^{2}]&=\log[P_{X_{\lambda,k}}(\lambda^{-1}x_{k+1})^{2}]\\ &\geq-(2\alpha-d)\log\lambda+(2\alpha-d)\log\mathinner{\lVert x_{k+1}-X_{k}\rVert}+\log C\end{split}

when Î»ğœ†\lambda is large enough that âˆ¥Î»âˆ’1â€‹xk+1âˆ’XÎ»,kâˆ¥â‰¤1delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥superscriptğœ†1subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜1subscriptğ‘‹ğœ†ğ‘˜1\mathinner{\lVert\lambda^{-1}x_{k+1}-X_{\lambda,k}\rVert}\leq 1. EquationÂ (7.16) implies that

logâ€‹detKÎ»â€‹(X,X)=âˆ‘k=0nâˆ’1logâ¡[PÎ»,kâ€‹(xk+1)2],subscriptğ¾ğœ†ğ‘‹ğ‘‹superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜0ğ‘›1subscriptğ‘ƒğœ†ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜12\log\det K_{\lambda}(X,X)=\sum_{k=0}^{n-1}\log[P_{\lambda,k}(x_{k+1})^{2}],

which yields the claim. Â 

Proof of EquationÂ 2.12 Under the assumption that the data are not mğ‘šm-constant we can freely order {x1,â€¦,xn}subscriptğ‘¥1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›\{x_{1},\ldots,x_{n}\} such that y1âˆ’mâ€‹(x1)â‰ y2âˆ’mâ€‹(x2)subscriptğ‘¦1ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘¥1subscriptğ‘¦2ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘¥2y_{1}-m(x_{1})\neq y_{2}-m(x_{2}). Then for the second term of the data-fit inÂ (7.15) we have

y2âˆ’mâ€‹(x2)âˆ’sÎ»,1â€‹(x2)PÎ»,1â€‹(x2)=y2âˆ’mâ€‹(x2)âˆ’KÎ»â€‹(x2,x1)â€‹KÎ»â€‹(x1,x1)âˆ’1â€‹(y1âˆ’mâ€‹(x1))PÎ»,1â€‹(x2).subscriptğ‘¦2ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘¥2subscriptğ‘ ğœ†1subscriptğ‘¥2subscriptğ‘ƒğœ†1subscriptğ‘¥2subscriptğ‘¦2ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘¥2subscriptğ¾ğœ†subscriptğ‘¥2subscriptğ‘¥1subscriptğ¾ğœ†superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥1subscriptğ‘¥11subscriptğ‘¦1ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘¥1subscriptğ‘ƒğœ†1subscriptğ‘¥2\frac{y_{2}-m(x_{2})-s_{\lambda,1}(x_{2})}{P_{\lambda,1}(x_{2})}=\frac{y_{2}-m(x_{2})-K_{\lambda}(x_{2},x_{1})K_{\lambda}(x_{1},x_{1})^{-1}(y_{1}-m(x_{1}))}{P_{\lambda,1}(x_{2})}. (7.17)

By the stationarity assumption, the numerator on the right-hand side ofÂ (7.17) is

y2âˆ’mâ€‹(x2)âˆ’Î¦â€‹(x2âˆ’x1Î»)â€‹Î¦â€‹(0)âˆ’1â€‹(y1âˆ’mâ€‹(x1)).subscriptğ‘¦2ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘¥2Î¦subscriptğ‘¥2subscriptğ‘¥1ğœ†Î¦superscript01subscriptğ‘¦1ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘¥1y_{2}-m(x_{2})-\Phi\bigg{(}\frac{x_{2}-x_{1}}{\lambda}\bigg{)}\Phi(0)^{-1}(y_{1}-m(x_{1})).

As Î»â†’âˆâ†’ğœ†\lambda\to\infty, the numerator therefore tends to y2âˆ’mâ€‹(x2)âˆ’(y1âˆ’mâ€‹(x1))â‰ 0subscriptğ‘¦2ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘¥2subscriptğ‘¦1ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘¥10y_{2}-m(x_{2})-(y_{1}-m(x_{1}))\neq 0. Consequently, there is a positive constant C1subscriptğ¶1C_{1} independent of Î»ğœ†\lambda such that

â„“â€‹(Î»âˆ£Y)=Ymğ–³â€‹KÎ»â€‹(X,X)âˆ’1â€‹Ym+logâ€‹detKÎ»â€‹(X,X)=âˆ‘k=0nâˆ’1(yk+1âˆ’mâ€‹(xk+1)âˆ’sÎ»,kâ€‹(xk+1)PÎ»,kâ€‹(xk+1))2+logâ€‹detKÎ»â€‹(X,X)â‰¥C1PÎ»,1â€‹(x2)2+logâ€‹detKÎ»â€‹(X,X)â„“conditionalğœ†ğ‘Œsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘šğ–³subscriptğ¾ğœ†superscriptğ‘‹ğ‘‹1subscriptğ‘Œğ‘šsubscriptğ¾ğœ†ğ‘‹ğ‘‹superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜0ğ‘›1superscriptsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘˜1ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜1subscriptğ‘ ğœ†ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜1subscriptğ‘ƒğœ†ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜12subscriptğ¾ğœ†ğ‘‹ğ‘‹subscriptğ¶1subscriptğ‘ƒğœ†1superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥22subscriptğ¾ğœ†ğ‘‹ğ‘‹\begin{split}\ell(\lambda\mid Y)&=Y_{m}^{\mathsf{T}}K_{\lambda}(X,X)^{-1}Y_{m}+\log\det K_{\lambda}(X,X)\\ &=\sum_{k=0}^{n-1}\bigg{(}\frac{y_{k+1}-m(x_{k+1})-s_{\lambda,k}(x_{k+1})}{P_{\lambda,k}(x_{k+1})}\bigg{)}^{2}+\log\det K_{\lambda}(X,X)\\ &\geq\frac{C_{1}}{P_{\lambda,1}(x_{2})^{2}}+\log\det K_{\lambda}(X,X)\end{split}

for all sufficiently large Î»ğœ†\lambda, where we have discarded all other terms of the data-fit inÂ (7.15) except the k=1ğ‘˜1k=1 term. PropositionÂ 7.4 yields the upper bound

PÎ»,1â€‹(x2)2â‰¤C2â€‹Î»âˆ’Î²â€‹(Î±)subscriptğ‘ƒğœ†1superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥22subscriptğ¶2superscriptğœ†ğ›½ğ›¼P_{\lambda,1}(x_{2})^{2}\leq C_{2}\lambda^{-\beta(\alpha)} (7.18)

for Î²â€‹(Î±)>0ğ›½ğ›¼0\beta(\alpha)>0, a certain positive constant C2subscriptğ¶2C_{2} independent of Î»ğœ†\lambda, and all sufficiently large Î»ğœ†\lambda. This bound and LemmaÂ 7.6 then give

â„“â€‹(Î»âˆ£Y)â‰¥C1PÎ»,1â€‹(x2)2+logâ€‹detKÎ»â€‹(X,X)â‰¥C1â€‹C2âˆ’1â€‹Î»Î²â€‹(Î±)âˆ’(2â€‹Î±âˆ’d)â€‹nâ€‹logâ¡Î»+C3â„“conditionalğœ†ğ‘Œsubscriptğ¶1subscriptğ‘ƒğœ†1superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥22subscriptğ¾ğœ†ğ‘‹ğ‘‹subscriptğ¶1superscriptsubscriptğ¶21superscriptğœ†ğ›½ğ›¼2ğ›¼ğ‘‘ğ‘›ğœ†subscriptğ¶3\ell(\lambda\mid Y)\geq\frac{C_{1}}{P_{\lambda,1}(x_{2})^{2}}+\log\det K_{\lambda}(X,X)\geq C_{1}C_{2}^{-1}\lambda^{\beta(\alpha)}-(2\alpha-d)n\log\lambda+C_{3}

when Î»ğœ†\lambda is sufficiently large and where none of the constants depend on Î»ğœ†\lambda. Therefore

limÎ»â†’âˆâ„“â€‹(Î»âˆ£Y)â‰¥limÎ»â†’âˆ(C1â€‹C2âˆ’1â€‹Î»Î²â€‹(Î±)âˆ’(2â€‹Î±âˆ’d)â€‹nâ€‹logâ¡Î»)=âˆsubscriptâ†’ğœ†â„“conditionalğœ†ğ‘Œsubscriptâ†’ğœ†subscriptğ¶1superscriptsubscriptğ¶21superscriptğœ†ğ›½ğ›¼2ğ›¼ğ‘‘ğ‘›ğœ†\lim_{\lambda\to\infty}\ell(\lambda\mid Y)\geq\lim_{\lambda\to\infty}\big{(}C_{1}C_{2}^{-1}\lambda^{\beta(\alpha)}-(2\alpha-d)n\log\lambda\big{)}=\infty

since Î²â€‹(Î±)>0ğ›½ğ›¼0\beta(\alpha)>0. This concludes the proof. Â 

We point out that the lower bound on logâ€‹detKÎ»â€‹(X,X)subscriptğ¾ğœ†ğ‘‹ğ‘‹\log\det K_{\lambda}(X,X) in LemmaÂ 7.6 is of independent interest. See TheoremsÂ 4.5 andÂ 6.3 in BarthelmÃ© and Usevich (2021) for other results on the behaviour of detKÎ»â€‹(X,X)subscriptğ¾ğœ†ğ‘‹ğ‘‹\det K_{\lambda}(X,X) as Î»â†’âˆâ†’ğœ†\lambda\to\infty.

7.5 Proof of TheoremÂ 2.6

See 2.6

ProofÂ  Because the data are mğ‘šm-constant, there is a constant function fâ‰¡cğ‘“ğ‘f\equiv c for some câˆˆâ„ğ‘â„c\in\mathbb{R} such that Ym=Yâˆ’mâ€‹(X)=fâ€‹(X)subscriptğ‘Œğ‘šğ‘Œğ‘šğ‘‹ğ‘“ğ‘‹Y_{m}=Y-m(X)=f(X). Recall from SectionÂ 7.3 that AssumptionÂ 2.2 implies that fğ‘“f is an element of Hâ€‹(K,B)ğ»ğ¾ğµH(K,B) for an open ball BğµB that can be selected such that XâŠ‚Bğ‘‹ğµX\subset B. Let XÎ»={xi/Î»}i=1nsubscriptğ‘‹ğœ†superscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğœ†ğ‘–1ğ‘›X_{\lambda}=\{x_{i}/\lambda\}_{i=1}^{n} and write

Î¼Î»â€‹(x)=mâ€‹(x)+sÎ»â€‹(x)=mâ€‹(x)+sf,XÎ»â€‹(Î»âˆ’1â€‹x).subscriptğœ‡ğœ†ğ‘¥ğ‘šğ‘¥subscriptğ‘ ğœ†ğ‘¥ğ‘šğ‘¥subscriptğ‘ ğ‘“subscriptğ‘‹ğœ†superscriptğœ†1ğ‘¥\mu_{\lambda}(x)=m(x)+s_{\lambda}(x)=m(x)+s_{f,X_{\lambda}}(\lambda^{-1}x).

The RKHS error estimateÂ (7.6) yields, for any Î»â‰¥1ğœ†1\lambda\geq 1,

|mâ€‹(x)+câˆ’Î¼Î»â€‹(x)|=|fâ€‹(Î»âˆ’1â€‹x)âˆ’sf,XÎ»â€‹(Î»âˆ’1â€‹x)|â‰¤âˆ¥fâˆ¥Hâ€‹(K,B)â€‹PXÎ»â€‹(Î»âˆ’1â€‹x).ğ‘šğ‘¥ğ‘subscriptğœ‡ğœ†ğ‘¥ğ‘“superscriptğœ†1ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘ ğ‘“subscriptğ‘‹ğœ†superscriptğœ†1ğ‘¥subscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ‘“ğ»ğ¾ğµsubscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘‹ğœ†superscriptğœ†1ğ‘¥\mathinner{\lvert m(x)+c-\mu_{\lambda}(x)\rvert}=\mathinner{\lvert f(\lambda^{-1}x)-s_{f,X_{\lambda}}(\lambda^{-1}x)\rvert}\leq\mathinner{\lVert f\rVert}_{H(K,B)}P_{X_{\lambda}}(\lambda^{-1}x). (7.19)

As in the proof of EquationÂ 2.12, PropositionÂ 7.4 yields the bound

PÎ»â€‹(x)2=PXÎ»â€‹(Î»âˆ’1â€‹x)2â‰¤Câ€‹Î»âˆ’Î²â€‹(Î±)subscriptğ‘ƒğœ†superscriptğ‘¥2subscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘‹ğœ†superscriptsuperscriptğœ†1ğ‘¥2ğ¶superscriptğœ†ğ›½ğ›¼P_{\lambda}(x)^{2}=P_{X_{\lambda}}(\lambda^{-1}x)^{2}\leq C\lambda^{-\beta(\alpha)} (7.20)

for Î²=minâ¡{1,Î±âˆ’d/2}>0ğ›½1ğ›¼ğ‘‘20\beta=\min\{1,\alpha-d/2\}>0 and a positive constant Cğ¶C which does not depend on Î»ğœ†\lambda. The claim limÎ»â†’âˆÎ¼Î»â€‹(x)=mâ€‹(x)+csubscriptâ†’ğœ†subscriptğœ‡ğœ†ğ‘¥ğ‘šğ‘¥ğ‘\lim_{\lambda\to\infty}\mu_{\lambda}(x)=m(x)+c is proved by inserting this bound inÂ (7.19). The claim for the conditional covariance follows fromÂ (7.20) and the Cauchyâ€“Schwarz covariance inequality PÎ»â€‹(x,y)2â‰¤PÎ»â€‹(x)â€‹PÎ»â€‹(y)subscriptğ‘ƒğœ†superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¦2subscriptğ‘ƒğœ†ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘ƒğœ†ğ‘¦P_{\lambda}(x,y)^{2}\leq P_{\lambda}(x)P_{\lambda}(y). Â 

Remark 7.7

Note in the above proof it is sufficient that PÎ»â€‹(x)subscriptğ‘ƒğœ†ğ‘¥P_{\lambda}(x) tends to zero as Î»â†’âˆâ†’ğœ†\lambda\to\infty. Unlike in the proof of EquationÂ 2.12, the rate with which this convergence occurs is of no importance. From the proof of PropositionÂ 7.4 it is easy to see that a sufficient condition for limÎ»â†’âˆPÎ»â€‹(x)=0subscriptâ†’ğœ†subscriptğ‘ƒğœ†ğ‘¥0\lim_{\lambda\to\infty}P_{\lambda}(x)=0 is that Kâ€‹(x,y)=Î¦â€‹(xâˆ’y)ğ¾ğ‘¥ğ‘¦Î¦ğ‘¥ğ‘¦K(x,y)=\Phi(x-y) for a continuous Î¦:â„dâ†’â„:Î¦â†’superscriptâ„ğ‘‘â„\Phi\colon\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R}. Therefore TheoremÂ 2.6 holds if Kğ¾K is a continuous stationary kernel such that constant functions are contained in Hâ€‹(K,B)ğ»ğ¾ğµH(K,B) for some open ball BğµB centered at the origin. This generalisation can be extended also to EquationÂ 2.11 and TheoremÂ 3.1. Further generalisations are discussed in SectionÂ 5.

7.6 Proofs for SectionÂ 3

Recall the notational conventions reviewed in SectionÂ 7.2. In addition, denote

XÎ»,n,k=Î»âˆ’1â€‹Xn,k={Î»âˆ’1â€‹xi}iâ‰ k.subscriptğ‘‹ğœ†ğ‘›ğ‘˜superscriptğœ†1subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘›ğ‘˜subscriptsuperscriptğœ†1subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘˜X_{\lambda,n,k}=\lambda^{-1}X_{n,k}=\{\lambda^{-1}x_{i}\}_{i\neq k}.

See 3.1

ProofÂ  Since the data are mğ‘šm-constant, there is a constant function fğ‘“f such that Ym=Yâˆ’mâ€‹(X)=fâ€‹(X)subscriptğ‘Œğ‘šğ‘Œğ‘šğ‘‹ğ‘“ğ‘‹Y_{m}=Y-m(X)=f(X). Recall from SectionÂ 7.3 that AssumptionÂ 2.2 implies that fğ‘“f is an element of Hâ€‹(K,B)ğ»ğ¾ğµH(K,B) for an open ball BğµB that can be selected such that XâŠ‚Bğ‘‹ğµX\subset B. Observe that Î¼Î»,n,kâ€‹(x)=mâ€‹(x)+sÎ»,n,kâ€‹(x)subscriptğœ‡ğœ†ğ‘›ğ‘˜ğ‘¥ğ‘šğ‘¥subscriptğ‘ ğœ†ğ‘›ğ‘˜ğ‘¥\mu_{\lambda,n,k}(x)=m(x)+s_{\lambda,n,k}(x). PropositionÂ 7.4 and the RKHS error estimateÂ (7.6) yield, for any Î»â‰¥1ğœ†1\lambda\geq 1 and a constant C1subscriptğ¶1C_{1} which does not depend on Î»ğœ†\lambda,

â„“CVâ€‹(Î»âˆ£Y)=âˆ‘k=1n[(ykâˆ’Î¼Î»,n,kâ€‹(xk)PÎ»,n,kâ€‹(xk))2+logâ¡[PÎ»,n,kâ€‹(xk)2]]=âˆ‘k=1n[(fâ€‹(Î»âˆ’1â€‹xk)âˆ’sf,XÎ»,n,kâ€‹(Î»âˆ’1â€‹xk)PXÎ»,n,kâ€‹(Î»âˆ’1â€‹xk))2+logâ¡[PXÎ»,n,kâ€‹(Î»âˆ’1â€‹xk)2]]â‰¤nâ€‹âˆ¥fâˆ¥Hâ€‹(K,B)2âˆ’Î²â€‹(Î±)â€‹nâ€‹logâ¡Î»+C1,subscriptâ„“CVconditionalğœ†ğ‘Œsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ‘›delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘˜subscriptğœ‡ğœ†ğ‘›ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘ƒğœ†ğ‘›ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜2subscriptğ‘ƒğœ†ğ‘›ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜2superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ‘›delimited-[]superscriptğ‘“superscriptğœ†1subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘ ğ‘“subscriptğ‘‹ğœ†ğ‘›ğ‘˜superscriptğœ†1subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘‹ğœ†ğ‘›ğ‘˜superscriptğœ†1subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜2subscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘‹ğœ†ğ‘›ğ‘˜superscriptsuperscriptğœ†1subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜2ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ‘“ğ»ğ¾ğµ2ğ›½ğ›¼ğ‘›ğœ†subscriptğ¶1\begin{split}\ell_{\textup{CV}}(\lambda\mid Y)&=\sum_{k=1}^{n}\bigg{[}\bigg{(}\frac{y_{k}-\mu_{\lambda,n,k}(x_{k})}{P_{\lambda,n,k}(x_{k})}\bigg{)}^{2}+\log[P_{\lambda,n,k}(x_{k})^{2}]\bigg{]}\\ &=\sum_{k=1}^{n}\bigg{[}\bigg{(}\frac{f(\lambda^{-1}x_{k})-s_{f,X_{\lambda,n,k}}(\lambda^{-1}x_{k})}{P_{X_{\lambda,n,k}}(\lambda^{-1}x_{k})}\bigg{)}^{2}+\log[P_{X_{\lambda,n,k}}(\lambda^{-1}x_{k})^{2}]\bigg{]}\\ &\leq n\mathinner{\lVert f\rVert}_{H(K,B)}^{2}-\beta(\alpha)n\log\lambda+C_{1},\end{split}

which establishes that

limÎ»â†’âˆâ„“CVâ€‹(Î»âˆ£Y)=âˆ’âˆsubscriptâ†’ğœ†subscriptâ„“CVconditionalğœ†ğ‘Œ\lim_{\lambda\to\infty}\ell_{\textup{CV}}(\lambda\mid Y)=-\infty (7.21)

since Î²â€‹(Î±)=minâ¡{1,Î±âˆ’d/2}>0ğ›½ğ›¼1ğ›¼ğ‘‘20\beta(\alpha)=\min\{1,\alpha-d/2\}>0. Because KÎ»â€‹(x,y)â†’0â†’subscriptğ¾ğœ†ğ‘¥ğ‘¦0K_{\lambda}(x,y)\to 0 as Î»â†’0â†’ğœ†0\lambda\to 0 if xâ‰ yğ‘¥ğ‘¦x\neq y, it is easy to compute fromÂ (2.4) andÂ (2.5) that

limÎ»â†’0sÎ»,n,kâ€‹(xk)=0Â andlimÎ»â†’0PÎ»,n,kâ€‹(xk)=Î¦â€‹(0)>0formulae-sequencesubscriptâ†’ğœ†0subscriptğ‘ ğœ†ğ‘›ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜0Â andsubscriptâ†’ğœ†0subscriptğ‘ƒğœ†ğ‘›ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜Î¦00\lim_{\lambda\to 0}s_{\lambda,n,k}(x_{k})=0\quad\text{ and}\quad\lim_{\lambda\to 0}P_{\lambda,n,k}(x_{k})=\sqrt{\Phi(0)}>0

for every kğ‘˜k. Therefore

limÎ»â†’0â„“CVâ€‹(Î»âˆ£Y)=câ€‹nâ€‹Î¦â€‹(0)âˆ’1+nâ€‹logâ¡Î¦â€‹(0)>âˆ’âˆ,subscriptâ†’ğœ†0subscriptâ„“CVconditionalğœ†ğ‘Œğ‘ğ‘›Î¦superscript01ğ‘›Î¦0\lim_{\lambda\to 0}\ell_{\textup{CV}}(\lambda\mid Y)=cn\Phi(0)^{-1}+n\log\Phi(0)>-\infty,

so that it follows from EquationÂ (7.21) and the fact that â„“CVâ€‹(Î»âˆ£Y)subscriptâ„“CVconditionalğœ†ğ‘Œ\ell_{\textup{CV}}(\lambda\mid Y) is continuous that Î»CV=argâ€‹minÎ»>0â¡â„“CVâ€‹(Î»âˆ£Y)=âˆsubscriptğœ†CVsubscriptargminğœ†0subscriptâ„“CVconditionalğœ†ğ‘Œ{\lambda_{\textup{CV}}=\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{\lambda>0}\ell_{\textup{CV}}(\lambda\mid Y)=\infty}. Â 

Remark 7.8

Proving that limÎ»â†’âˆâ„“CVâ€‹(Î»âˆ£Y)=âˆsubscriptâ†’ğœ†subscriptâ„“CVconditionalğœ†ğ‘Œ\lim_{\lambda\to\infty}\ell_{\textup{CV}}(\lambda\mid Y)=\infty and Î»CV<âˆsubscriptğœ†CV\lambda_{\textup{CV}}<\infty if the data are not mğ‘šm-constant is more challenging than the same for the maximum likelihood estimate. This is because in the proof of EquationÂ 2.12 one could exploit a recursive form of the modified log-likelihood function that follows from PropositionÂ 7.5 and obtain a closed-form expression for the term in which the conditional mean and variance are based on one data point. If n>2ğ‘›2n>2, it is more difficult to analyse any of the analogous terms in â„“CVâ€‹(Î»âˆ£Y)subscriptâ„“CVconditionalğœ†ğ‘Œ\ell_{\textup{CV}}(\lambda\mid Y) because each of these terms is built out of conditional moments based on nâˆ’1ğ‘›1n-1 points.

See 3.3

ProofÂ  The modified log-likelihood function is

â„“â€‹(Î»,Î²âˆ£Y)=(Yâˆ’Vâ€‹(X)â€‹Î²)ğ–³â€‹KÎ»â€‹(X,X)âˆ’1â€‹(Yâˆ’Vâ€‹(X)â€‹Î²)+logâ€‹detKÎ»â€‹(X,X).â„“ğœ†conditionalğ›½ğ‘Œsuperscriptğ‘Œğ‘‰ğ‘‹ğ›½ğ–³subscriptğ¾ğœ†superscriptğ‘‹ğ‘‹1ğ‘Œğ‘‰ğ‘‹ğ›½subscriptğ¾ğœ†ğ‘‹ğ‘‹\ell(\lambda,\beta\mid Y)=(Y-V(X)\beta)^{\mathsf{T}}K_{\lambda}(X,X)^{-1}(Y-V(X)\beta)+\log\det K_{\lambda}(X,X).

By TheoremÂ 2.3 and identification of Yâˆ’Vâ€‹(X)â€‹Î²ğ‘Œğ‘‰ğ‘‹ğ›½Y-V(X)\beta as the vector Ymsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘šY_{m}, â„“â€‹(Î»,Î²âˆ£Y)â„“ğœ†conditionalğ›½ğ‘Œ\ell(\lambda,\beta\mid Y) tends to negative infinity for a fixed Î²âˆˆâ„qğ›½superscriptâ„ğ‘\beta\in\mathbb{R}^{q} if and only if Yâˆ’Vâ€‹(X)â€‹Î²=(c,â€¦,c)âˆˆâ„nğ‘Œğ‘‰ğ‘‹ğ›½ğ‘â€¦ğ‘superscriptâ„ğ‘›Y-V(X)\beta=(c,\ldots,c)\in\mathbb{R}^{n} for some câˆˆâ„ğ‘â„c\in\mathbb{R} and Î»â†’âˆâ†’ğœ†\lambda\to\infty. Furthermore, because the data-fit term is non-negative and model complexity does not depend on Î²ğ›½\beta, â„“â€‹(Î»,Î²âˆ£Y)â„“ğœ†conditionalğ›½ğ‘Œ\ell(\lambda,\beta\mid Y) cannot tend to negative infinity if Î»ğœ†\lambda is kept fixed. We conclude that Î»ML=âˆsubscriptğœ†ML\lambda_{\textup{ML}}=\infty because by the assumption inÂ (3.4) there is Î²âˆ—âˆˆâ„qsuperscriptğ›½superscriptâ„ğ‘\beta^{*}\in\mathbb{R}^{q} for which Yâˆ’Vâ€‹(X)â€‹Î²âˆ—=(c,â€¦,c)ğ‘Œğ‘‰ğ‘‹superscriptğ›½ğ‘â€¦ğ‘Y-V(X)\beta^{*}=(c,\ldots,c). Â 

See 3.5

ProofÂ  Recall that ÏƒMLsubscriptğœML\sigma_{\textup{ML}} and Î»MLsubscriptğœ†ML\lambda_{\textup{ML}} are any minimisers of

â„“â€‹(Î»,Ïƒâˆ£Y)=1Ïƒ2â€‹Ymğ–³â€‹KÎ»â€‹(X,X)âˆ’1â€‹Ym+logâ€‹detKÎ»â€‹(X,X)+nâ€‹logâ¡Ïƒ2.â„“ğœ†conditionalğœğ‘Œ1superscriptğœ2superscriptsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘šğ–³subscriptğ¾ğœ†superscriptğ‘‹ğ‘‹1subscriptğ‘Œğ‘šsubscriptğ¾ğœ†ğ‘‹ğ‘‹ğ‘›superscriptğœ2\ell(\lambda,\sigma\mid Y)=\frac{1}{\sigma^{2}}Y_{m}^{\mathsf{T}}K_{\lambda}(X,X)^{-1}Y_{m}+\log\det K_{\lambda}(X,X)+n\log\sigma^{2}. (7.22)

For a fixed Î»ğœ†\lambda it is straightforward to compute that the maximum likelihood estimate ofÂ Ïƒğœ\sigma is

ÏƒMLâ€‹(Î»)=Ymğ–³â€‹KÎ»â€‹(X,X)âˆ’1â€‹Ymn.subscriptğœMLğœ†superscriptsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘šğ–³subscriptğ¾ğœ†superscriptğ‘‹ğ‘‹1subscriptğ‘Œğ‘šğ‘›\sigma_{\textup{ML}}(\lambda)=\sqrt{\frac{Y_{m}^{\mathsf{T}}K_{\lambda}(X,X)^{-1}Y_{m}}{n}}.

Plugging this estimate inÂ (7.22) yields that Î»MLsubscriptğœ†ML\lambda_{\textup{ML}} is any minimiser of

â„“â€‹(Î»,ÏƒMLâ€‹(Î»)âˆ£Y)=n+logâ€‹detKÎ»â€‹(X,X)+nâ€‹logâ¡(Ymğ–³â€‹KÎ»â€‹(X,X)âˆ’1â€‹Ym)âˆ’nâ€‹logâ¡n.â„“ğœ†conditionalsubscriptğœMLğœ†ğ‘Œğ‘›subscriptğ¾ğœ†ğ‘‹ğ‘‹ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘šğ–³subscriptğ¾ğœ†superscriptğ‘‹ğ‘‹1subscriptğ‘Œğ‘šğ‘›ğ‘›\ell(\lambda,\sigma_{\textup{ML}}(\lambda)\mid Y)=n+\log\det K_{\lambda}(X,X)+n\log(Y_{m}^{\mathsf{T}}K_{\lambda}(X,X)^{-1}Y_{m})-n\log n.

The term nâ€‹logâ¡(Ymğ–³â€‹KÎ»â€‹(X,X)âˆ’1â€‹Ym)ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘šğ–³subscriptğ¾ğœ†superscriptğ‘‹ğ‘‹1subscriptğ‘Œğ‘šn\log(Y_{m}^{\mathsf{T}}K_{\lambda}(X,X)^{-1}Y_{m}) is bounded as a function of Î»ğœ†\lambda by LemmaÂ 7.2 and because we have assumed that Ymâ‰ 0subscriptğ‘Œğ‘š0Y_{m}\neq 0. A straightforward adaptation of the proof ofÂ (2.11) then establishes the claim. Â 

7.7 Proof of TheoremÂ 4.1

See 4.1

ProofÂ  Recall that the MAP estimator is any minimiser of

â„“MAPâ€‹(Î»âˆ£Y)=12â€‹â„“â€‹(Î»âˆ£Y)âˆ’logâ¡pâ€‹(Î»),subscriptâ„“MAPconditionalğœ†ğ‘Œ12â„“conditionalğœ†ğ‘Œğ‘ğœ†\ell_{\textup{MAP}}(\lambda\mid Y)=\frac{1}{2}\ell(\lambda\mid Y)-\log p(\lambda),

where â„“â€‹(Î»âˆ£Y)â„“conditionalğœ†ğ‘Œ\ell(\lambda\mid Y) is the modified log-likelihood function inÂ (2.8). If the data are not mğ‘šm-constant, it follows from TheoremÂ 2.3 that â„“â€‹(Î»âˆ£Y)â†’âˆâ†’â„“conditionalğœ†ğ‘Œ\ell(\lambda\mid Y)\to\infty as Î»â†’âˆâ†’ğœ†\lambda\to\infty. Since pğ‘p is a probability density function, it holds that âˆ’logâ¡pâ€‹(Î»)â†’âˆâ†’ğ‘ğœ†-\log p(\lambda)\to\infty as Î»â†’âˆâ†’ğœ†\lambda\to\infty. Consequently,

limÎ»â†’âˆâ„“MAPâ€‹(Î»âˆ£Y)=âˆÂ andÂ Î»MAP<âˆformulae-sequencesubscriptâ†’ğœ†subscriptâ„“MAPconditionalğœ†ğ‘ŒÂ andÂ subscriptğœ†MAP\lim_{\lambda\to\infty}\ell_{\textup{MAP}}(\lambda\mid Y)=\infty\quad\text{ and }\quad\lambda_{\textup{MAP}}<\infty (7.23)

if the data are not mğ‘šm-constant. Suppose then that the data are mğ‘šm-constant. The non-negativity of the data-fit term and LemmaÂ 7.6 yield

â„“MAPâ€‹(Î»âˆ£Y)â‰¥âˆ’(Î±âˆ’d/2)â€‹nâ€‹logâ¡Î»+Câˆ’logâ¡pâ€‹(Î»)=âˆ’logâ¡[Î»(Î±âˆ’d/2)â€‹nâ€‹pâ€‹(Î»)]+Csubscriptâ„“MAPconditionalğœ†ğ‘Œğ›¼ğ‘‘2ğ‘›ğœ†ğ¶ğ‘ğœ†superscriptğœ†ğ›¼ğ‘‘2ğ‘›ğ‘ğœ†ğ¶\ell_{\textup{MAP}}(\lambda\mid Y)\geq-(\alpha-d/2)n\log\lambda+C-\log p(\lambda)=-\log[\lambda^{(\alpha-d/2)n}p(\lambda)]+C

for a constant Cğ¶C that does not depend on Î»ğœ†\lambda. That âˆ’logâ¡[Î»(Î±âˆ’d/2)â€‹nâ€‹pâ€‹(Î»)]â†’âˆâ†’superscriptğœ†ğ›¼ğ‘‘2ğ‘›ğ‘ğœ†-\log[\lambda^{(\alpha-d/2)n}p(\lambda)]\to\infty as Î»â†’âˆâ†’ğœ†\lambda\to\infty is true by assumptionÂ (4.4). ThereforeÂ (7.23) holds also when the data are mğ‘šm-constant. Â 

7.8 Proof of TheoremÂ 5.2

We begin with a technical lemma which is used to establish some properties of the information functionals.

Lemma 7.9

Let Î©Î©\Omega be a vector space and Kğ¾K and KÎ³subscriptğ¾ğ›¾K_{\gamma} two positive-semidefinite kernels on Î©Î©\Omega such that

KÎ³â€‹(x,y)=Kâ€‹(Î³â€‹x,Î³â€‹y)Â for someÂ Î³>0Â and allÂ x,yâˆˆÎ©.formulae-sequencesubscriptğ¾ğ›¾ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ¾ğ›¾ğ‘¥ğ›¾ğ‘¦Â for someÂ formulae-sequenceğ›¾0Â and allÂ ğ‘¥ğ‘¦Î©K_{\gamma}(x,y)=K(\gamma x,\gamma y)\quad\text{ for some }\quad\gamma>0\quad\text{ and all }\quad x,y\in\Omega.

Let fÎ³subscriptğ‘“ğ›¾f_{\gamma} be the function xâ†¦fâ€‹(Î³â€‹x)maps-toğ‘¥ğ‘“ğ›¾ğ‘¥x\mapsto f(\gamma x) for any f:Î©â†’â„:ğ‘“â†’Î©â„f\colon\Omega\to\mathbb{R} and, given a linear functional Iğ¼I, define IÎ³subscriptğ¼ğ›¾I_{\gamma} via IÎ³â€‹f=Iâ€‹fÎ³subscriptğ¼ğ›¾ğ‘“ğ¼subscriptğ‘“ğ›¾I_{\gamma}f=If_{\gamma}. Then it holds that

  1. 1.

    if fâˆˆHâ€‹(K,Î©)ğ‘“ğ»ğ¾Î©f\in H(K,\Omega), then fÎ³âˆˆHâ€‹(KÎ³,Î©)subscriptğ‘“ğ›¾ğ»subscriptğ¾ğ›¾Î©f_{\gamma}\in H(K_{\gamma},\Omega);

  2. 2.

    if Iğ¼I is a bounded linear functional on Hâ€‹(KÎ³,Î©)ğ»subscriptğ¾ğ›¾Î©H(K_{\gamma},\Omega), then IÎ³subscriptğ¼ğ›¾I_{\gamma} is bounded on Hâ€‹(K,Î©)ğ»ğ¾Î©H(K,\Omega);

  3. 3.

    if linear functionals I1,â€¦,Insubscriptğ¼1â€¦subscriptğ¼ğ‘›I_{1},\ldots,I_{n} are linearly independent on Hâ€‹(KÎ³,Î©)ğ»subscriptğ¾ğ›¾Î©H(K_{\gamma},\Omega), then I1,Î³,â€¦,In,Î³subscriptğ¼1ğ›¾â€¦subscriptğ¼ğ‘›ğ›¾I_{1,\gamma},\ldots,I_{n,\gamma} are linearly independent on Hâ€‹(K,Î©)ğ»ğ¾Î©H(K,\Omega).

ProofÂ  By a classical resultÂ (e.g., Paulsen and Raghupathi, 2016, TheoremÂ 3.11) a function fğ‘“f is an element of Hâ€‹(K,Î©)ğ»ğ¾Î©H(K,\Omega) if and only if there is câ‰¥0ğ‘0c\geq 0 such that c2â€‹Kâ€‹(x,y)âˆ’fâ€‹(x)â€‹fâ€‹(y)superscriptğ‘2ğ¾ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘“ğ‘¥ğ‘“ğ‘¦c^{2}K(x,y)-f(x)f(y) defines a positive-semidefinite kernel. If fâˆˆHâ€‹(K,Î©)ğ‘“ğ»ğ¾Î©f\in H(K,\Omega), then âˆ¥fâˆ¥Hâ€‹(K,Î©)subscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ‘“ğ»ğ¾Î©\mathinner{\lVert f\rVert}_{H(K,\Omega)} equals the smallest cğ‘c for which this kernel is positive-semidefinite. Let fâˆˆHâ€‹(K,Î©)ğ‘“ğ»ğ¾Î©f\in H(K,\Omega). Therefore c2â€‹Kâ€‹(x,y)âˆ’fâ€‹(x)â€‹fâ€‹(y)superscriptğ‘2ğ¾ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘“ğ‘¥ğ‘“ğ‘¦c^{2}K(x,y)-f(x)f(y) defines a positive-semidefinite kernel for some câ‰¥0ğ‘0c\geq 0 and

c2â€‹Kâ€‹(Î³â€‹x,Î³â€‹y)âˆ’fâ€‹(Î³â€‹x)â€‹fâ€‹(Î³â€‹y)=c2â€‹KÎ³â€‹(x,y)âˆ’fÎ³â€‹(x)â€‹fÎ³â€‹(y)superscriptğ‘2ğ¾ğ›¾ğ‘¥ğ›¾ğ‘¦ğ‘“ğ›¾ğ‘¥ğ‘“ğ›¾ğ‘¦superscriptğ‘2subscriptğ¾ğ›¾ğ‘¥ğ‘¦subscriptğ‘“ğ›¾ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘“ğ›¾ğ‘¦c^{2}K(\gamma x,\gamma y)-f(\gamma x)f(\gamma y)=c^{2}K_{\gamma}(x,y)-f_{\gamma}(x)f_{\gamma}(y) (7.24)

also defines a positive-semidefinite kernel. Consequently, fÎ³âˆˆâ„‹â€‹(KÎ³,Î©)subscriptğ‘“ğ›¾â„‹subscriptğ¾ğ›¾Î©f_{\gamma}\in\mathcal{H}(K_{\gamma},\Omega). Furthermore, because c=âˆ¥fâˆ¥Hâ€‹(K,Î©)ğ‘subscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ‘“ğ»ğ¾Î©c=\mathinner{\lVert f\rVert}_{H(K,\Omega)} is the smallest cğ‘c for which the kernels inÂ (7.24) are positive-semidefinite, we conclude that âˆ¥fÎ³âˆ¥Hâ€‹(KÎ³,Î©)=âˆ¥fâˆ¥Hâ€‹(K,Î©)subscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ‘“ğ›¾ğ»subscriptğ¾ğ›¾Î©subscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ‘“ğ»ğ¾Î©\mathinner{\lVert f_{\gamma}\rVert}_{H(K_{\gamma},\Omega)}=\mathinner{\lVert f\rVert}_{H(K,\Omega)}. Because Iğ¼I is bounded on Hâ€‹(KÎ³,Î©)ğ»subscriptğ¾ğ›¾Î©H(K_{\gamma},\Omega) and fÎ³subscriptğ‘“ğ›¾f_{\gamma} is an element of Hâ€‹(KÎ³,Î©)ğ»subscriptğ¾ğ›¾Î©H(K_{\gamma},\Omega), there is a constant C>0ğ¶0C>0, which does not depend on fğ‘“f, such that

|IÎ³â€‹f|=|Iâ€‹fÎ³|â‰¤Câ€‹âˆ¥fÎ³âˆ¥Hâ€‹(KÎ³,Î©)=Câ€‹âˆ¥fâˆ¥Hâ€‹(K,Î©).subscriptğ¼ğ›¾ğ‘“ğ¼subscriptğ‘“ğ›¾ğ¶subscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ‘“ğ›¾ğ»subscriptğ¾ğ›¾Î©ğ¶subscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ‘“ğ»ğ¾Î©\mathinner{\lvert I_{\gamma}f\rvert}=\mathinner{\lvert If_{\gamma}\rvert}\leq C\mathinner{\lVert f_{\gamma}\rVert}_{H(K_{\gamma},\Omega)}=C\mathinner{\lVert f\rVert}_{H(K,\Omega)}.

This concludes the proof of the first two claims. The third claim also follows because we have proved that fÎ³âˆˆHâ€‹(KÎ³,Î©)subscriptğ‘“ğ›¾ğ»subscriptğ¾ğ›¾Î©f_{\gamma}\in H(K_{\gamma},\Omega) if fâˆˆHâ€‹(K,Î©)ğ‘“ğ»ğ¾Î©f\in H(K,\Omega) and it holds that
