a1â€‹I1,Î³â€‹(f)+â‹¯+anâ€‹In,Î³â€‹(f)=a1â€‹I1â€‹(fÎ³)+â‹¯+amâ€‹Inâ€‹(fÎ³)subscriptğ‘1subscriptğ¼1ğ›¾ğ‘“â‹¯subscriptğ‘ğ‘›subscriptğ¼ğ‘›ğ›¾ğ‘“subscriptğ‘1subscriptğ¼1subscriptğ‘“ğ›¾â‹¯subscriptğ‘ğ‘šsubscriptğ¼ğ‘›subscriptğ‘“ğ›¾a_{1}I_{1,\gamma}(f)+\cdots+a_{n}I_{n,\gamma}(f)=a_{1}I_{1}(f_{\gamma})+\cdots+a_{m}I_{n}(f_{\gamma})

for any a1,â€¦,anâˆˆâ„subscriptğ‘1â€¦subscriptğ‘ğ‘›â„a_{1},\ldots,a_{n}\in\mathbb{R}. Â 

The following proposition is a generalisation of the minimum-norm property for interpolation based on point evaluations that was reviewed in SectionÂ 7.1. We have not been able to locate a convenient reference and therefore provide a proof.

Proposition 7.10

Let Kğ¾K be a positive-definite kernel on a set Î©Î©\Omega. If fâˆˆHâ€‹(K,Î©)ğ‘“ğ»ğ¾Î©f\in H(K,\Omega), then

â„â€‹(f)ğ–³â€‹Kâ€‹(â„,â„)âˆ’1â€‹â„â€‹(f)â‰¤âˆ¥fâˆ¥Hâ€‹(K,Î©)2â„superscriptğ‘“ğ–³ğ¾superscriptâ„â„1â„ğ‘“superscriptsubscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ‘“ğ»ğ¾Î©2\mathcal{I}(f)^{\mathsf{T}}K(\mathcal{I},\mathcal{I})^{-1}\mathcal{I}(f)\leq\mathinner{\lVert f\rVert}_{H(K,\Omega)}^{2} (7.25)

for every nâ‰¥1ğ‘›1n\geq 1 and every collection â„={I1,â€¦,In}â„subscriptğ¼1â€¦subscriptğ¼ğ‘›\mathcal{I}=\{I_{1},\ldots,I_{n}\} of nğ‘›n non-trivial linear functionals which are linearly independent and bounded on Hâ€‹(K,Î©)ğ»ğ¾Î©H(K,\Omega).

ProofÂ  Let sâ„â€‹fsubscriptğ‘ â„ğ‘“s_{\mathcal{I}}f be the minimum-norm interpolant to fğ‘“f in Hâ€‹(K,Î©)ğ»ğ¾Î©H(K,\Omega), which is to say that

sâ„â€‹f=argâ€‹minsâˆˆHâ€‹(K,Î©)â¡{âˆ¥sâˆ¥Hâ€‹(K,Î©):Iâ€‹s=Iâ€‹fâ€‹Â for allÂ â€‹Iâˆˆâ„}.subscriptğ‘ â„ğ‘“subscriptargminğ‘ ğ»ğ¾Î©:subscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ‘ ğ»ğ¾Î©ğ¼ğ‘ ğ¼ğ‘“Â for allÂ ğ¼â„s_{\mathcal{I}}f=\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{s\in H(K,\Omega)}\big{\{}\mathinner{\lVert s\rVert}_{H(K,\Omega)}\,\mathrel{\mathop{\ordinarycolon}}\,Is=If\text{ for all }I\in\mathcal{I}\big{\}}.

By, for example, TheoremÂ 16.1 in Wendland (2005) or SectionÂ 3.3 in Oettershagen (2017) this interpolant is unique and has the explicit form

(sâ„â€‹f)â€‹(x)=Iâ€‹(f)ğ–³â€‹Kâ€‹(â„,â„)âˆ’1â€‹Kâ€‹(â„,x)=âˆ‘i=1nIiyâ€‹(Kâ€‹(x,y))â€‹(Kâ€‹(â„,â„)âˆ’1â€‹â„â€‹(f))i.subscriptğ‘ â„ğ‘“ğ‘¥ğ¼superscriptğ‘“ğ–³ğ¾superscriptâ„â„1ğ¾â„ğ‘¥superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ¼ğ‘–ğ‘¦ğ¾ğ‘¥ğ‘¦subscriptğ¾superscriptâ„â„1â„ğ‘“ğ‘–(s_{\mathcal{I}}f)(x)=I(f)^{\mathsf{T}}K(\mathcal{I},\mathcal{I})^{-1}K(\mathcal{I},x)=\sum_{i=1}^{n}I_{i}^{y}(K(x,y))(K(\mathcal{I},\mathcal{I})^{-1}\mathcal{I}(f))_{i}.

Recall that we use superscripts to indicate the argument with respect to which a functional is to be applied. Because âŸ¨Ijyâ€‹Kâ€‹(â‹…,y),Iixâ€‹Kâ€‹(x,â‹…)âŸ©Hâ€‹(K,Î©)=Iixâ€‹Ijyâ€‹Kâ€‹(x,y)subscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğ¼ğ‘—ğ‘¦ğ¾â‹…ğ‘¦superscriptsubscriptğ¼ğ‘–ğ‘¥ğ¾ğ‘¥â‹…ğ»ğ¾Î©superscriptsubscriptğ¼ğ‘–ğ‘¥superscriptsubscriptğ¼ğ‘—ğ‘¦ğ¾ğ‘¥ğ‘¦\langle I_{j}^{y}K(\cdot,y),I_{i}^{x}K(x,\cdot)\rangle_{H(K,\Omega)}=I_{i}^{x}I_{j}^{y}K(x,y), from the reproducing property we compute that

âˆ¥sâ„â€‹fâˆ¥Hâ€‹(K,Î©)2=âŸ¨sâ„â€‹f,sâ„â€‹fâŸ©Hâ€‹(K,Î©)=âˆ‘i,j=1mâŸ¨Ijyâ€‹Kâ€‹(â‹…,y),Iixâ€‹Kâ€‹(x,â‹…)âŸ©Hâ€‹(K,Î©)â€‹(Kâ€‹(â„,â„)âˆ’1â€‹â„â€‹(f))iâ€‹(Kâ€‹(â„,â„)âˆ’1â€‹â„â€‹(f))j=âˆ‘i,j=1nIixâ€‹Ijyâ€‹Kâ€‹(x,y)â€‹(Kâ€‹(â„,â„)âˆ’1â€‹â„â€‹(f))iâ€‹(Kâ€‹(â„,â„)âˆ’1â€‹â„â€‹(f))j=â„â€‹(f)ğ–³â€‹Kâ€‹(â„,â„)âˆ’1â€‹Kâ€‹(â„,â„)â€‹Kâ€‹(â„,â„)âˆ’1â€‹â„â€‹(f)=â„â€‹(f)ğ–³â€‹Kâ€‹(â„,â„)âˆ’1â€‹â„â€‹(f).superscriptsubscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ‘ â„ğ‘“ğ»ğ¾Î©2subscriptsubscriptğ‘ â„ğ‘“subscriptğ‘ â„ğ‘“ğ»ğ¾Î©superscriptsubscriptğ‘–ğ‘—1ğ‘šsubscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğ¼ğ‘—ğ‘¦ğ¾â‹…ğ‘¦superscriptsubscriptğ¼ğ‘–ğ‘¥ğ¾ğ‘¥â‹…ğ»ğ¾Î©subscriptğ¾superscriptâ„â„1â„ğ‘“ğ‘–subscriptğ¾superscriptâ„â„1â„ğ‘“ğ‘—superscriptsubscriptğ‘–ğ‘—1ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ¼ğ‘–ğ‘¥superscriptsubscriptğ¼ğ‘—ğ‘¦ğ¾ğ‘¥ğ‘¦subscriptğ¾superscriptâ„â„1â„ğ‘“ğ‘–subscriptğ¾superscriptâ„â„1â„ğ‘“ğ‘—â„superscriptğ‘“ğ–³ğ¾superscriptâ„â„1ğ¾â„â„ğ¾superscriptâ„â„1â„ğ‘“â„superscriptğ‘“ğ–³ğ¾superscriptâ„â„1â„ğ‘“\begin{split}\mathinner{\lVert s_{\mathcal{I}}f\rVert}_{H(K,\Omega)}^{2}&=\langle s_{\mathcal{I}}f,s_{\mathcal{I}}f\rangle_{H(K,\Omega)}\\ &=\sum_{i,j=1}^{m}\langle I_{j}^{y}K(\cdot,y),I_{i}^{x}K(x,\cdot)\rangle_{H(K,\Omega)}(K(\mathcal{I},\mathcal{I})^{-1}\mathcal{I}(f))_{i}(K(\mathcal{I},\mathcal{I})^{-1}\mathcal{I}(f))_{j}\\ &=\sum_{i,j=1}^{n}I_{i}^{x}I_{j}^{y}K(x,y)(K(\mathcal{I},\mathcal{I})^{-1}\mathcal{I}(f))_{i}(K(\mathcal{I},\mathcal{I})^{-1}\mathcal{I}(f))_{j}\\ &=\mathcal{I}(f)^{\mathsf{T}}K(\mathcal{I},\mathcal{I})^{-1}K(\mathcal{I},\mathcal{I})K(\mathcal{I},\mathcal{I})^{-1}\mathcal{I}(f)\\ &=\mathcal{I}(f)^{\mathsf{T}}K(\mathcal{I},\mathcal{I})^{-1}\mathcal{I}(f).\end{split}

If fâˆˆHâ€‹(K,Î©)ğ‘“ğ»ğ¾Î©f\in H(K,\Omega), the condition Iâ€‹s=Iâ€‹fğ¼ğ‘ ğ¼ğ‘“Is=If for all Iâˆˆâ„ğ¼â„I\in\mathcal{I} is trivially satisfied by s=fğ‘ ğ‘“s=f and therefore âˆ¥sâ„â€‹fâˆ¥Hâ€‹(K,Î©)2=â„â€‹(f)ğ–³â€‹Kâ€‹(â„,â„)âˆ’1â€‹â„â€‹(f)â‰¤âˆ¥fâˆ¥Hâ€‹(K,Î©)2superscriptsubscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ‘ â„ğ‘“ğ»ğ¾Î©2â„superscriptğ‘“ğ–³ğ¾superscriptâ„â„1â„ğ‘“superscriptsubscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ‘“ğ»ğ¾Î©2\mathinner{\lVert s_{\mathcal{I}}f\rVert}_{H(K,\Omega)}^{2}=\mathcal{I}(f)^{\mathsf{T}}K(\mathcal{I},\mathcal{I})^{-1}\mathcal{I}(f)\leq\mathinner{\lVert f\rVert}_{H(K,\Omega)}^{2}. Â 

These preliminaries suffice to prove TheoremÂ 5.2.

See 5.2

ProofÂ  Let Li,Î»subscriptğ¿ğ‘–ğœ†L_{i,\lambda} be linear functionals that are defined as Li,Î»f=Lif(â‹…/g(Î»))L_{i,\lambda}f=L_{i}f(\cdot/g(\lambda)) for fâˆˆHâ€‹(K,Î©)ğ‘“ğ»ğ¾Î©f\in H(K,\Omega). These functionals are well-defined because f(â‹…/g(Î»))âˆˆH(K1/Î»,Î©)âŠ‚F(Î©)f(\cdot/g(\lambda))\in H(K_{1/\lambda},\Omega)\subset F(\Omega) by LemmaÂ 7.9. Moreover, by LemmaÂ 7.9 and the assumption that there exists Î»1>0subscriptğœ†10\lambda_{1}>0 such that gâ€‹(Î»1)=1ğ‘”subscriptğœ†11g(\lambda_{1})=1, the linear functionals â„’Î»={L1,Î»,â€¦,Ln,Î»}subscriptâ„’ğœ†subscriptğ¿1ğœ†â€¦subscriptğ¿ğ‘›ğœ†\mathcal{L}_{\lambda}=\{L_{1,\lambda},\ldots,L_{n,\lambda}\} are linearly independent and bounded on Hâ€‹(K,Î©)=Hâ€‹(KÎ»1,Î©)ğ»ğ¾Î©ğ»subscriptğ¾subscriptğœ†1Î©H(K,\Omega)=H(K_{\lambda_{1}},\Omega) for every Î»>0ğœ†0\lambda>0. Because gğ‘”g is continuous and gâ€‹(Î»)â†’âˆâ†’ğ‘”ğœ†g(\lambda)\to\infty as Î»â†’âˆâ†’ğœ†\lambda\to\infty, there is Î»0>0subscriptğœ†00\lambda_{0}>0 such that gâ€‹(Î»)â‰¥1ğ‘”ğœ†1g(\lambda)\geq 1 for all Î»â‰¥Î»0ğœ†subscriptğœ†0\lambda\geq\lambda_{0}. The assumptions on Î©bsubscriptÎ©ğ‘\Omega_{b} imply that Î©bâŠ‚Î©b,Î»={gâ€‹(Î»)â€‹x:xâˆˆÎ©b}subscriptÎ©ğ‘subscriptÎ©ğ‘ğœ†:ğ‘”ğœ†ğ‘¥ğ‘¥subscriptÎ©ğ‘\Omega_{b}\subset\Omega_{b,\lambda}=\{g(\lambda)x\,\mathrel{\mathop{\ordinarycolon}}\,x\in\Omega_{b}\} if Î»â‰¥Î»0ğœ†subscriptğœ†0\lambda\geq\lambda_{0}. Let f1,f2âˆˆHâ€‹(K,Î©)subscriptğ‘“1subscriptğ‘“2ğ»ğ¾Î©f_{1},f_{2}\in H(K,\Omega) be such that f1=f2subscriptğ‘“1subscriptğ‘“2f_{1}=f_{2} on Î©bsubscriptÎ©ğ‘\Omega_{b}. Then f1(â‹…/g(Î»))=f2(â‹…/g(Î»))f_{1}(\cdot/g(\lambda))=f_{2}(\cdot/g(\lambda)) on Î©bâŠ‚Î©b,Î»subscriptÎ©ğ‘subscriptÎ©ğ‘ğœ†\Omega_{b}\subset\Omega_{b,\lambda} and thus

Li,Î»â€‹f1=Liâ€‹[f1â€‹(â‹…gâ€‹(Î»))]=Liâ€‹[f2â€‹(â‹…gâ€‹(Î»))]=Li,Î»â€‹f2subscriptğ¿ğ‘–ğœ†subscriptğ‘“1subscriptğ¿ğ‘–delimited-[]subscriptğ‘“1â‹…ğ‘”ğœ†subscriptğ¿ğ‘–delimited-[]subscriptğ‘“2â‹…ğ‘”ğœ†subscriptğ¿ğ‘–ğœ†subscriptğ‘“2L_{i,\lambda}f_{1}=L_{i}\bigg{[}f_{1}\bigg{(}\frac{\cdot}{g(\lambda)}\bigg{)}\bigg{]}=L_{i}\bigg{[}f_{2}\bigg{(}\frac{\cdot}{g(\lambda)}\bigg{)}\bigg{]}=L_{i,\lambda}f_{2}

by the assumption that Liâ€‹f1=Liâ€‹f2subscriptğ¿ğ‘–subscriptğ‘“1subscriptğ¿ğ‘–subscriptğ‘“2L_{i}f_{1}=L_{i}f_{2} for every iâˆˆ{1,â€¦,n}ğ‘–1â€¦ğ‘›i\in\{1,\ldots,n\} and all f1,f2âˆˆFâ€‹(Î©)subscriptğ‘“1subscriptğ‘“2ğ¹Î©f_{1},f_{2}\in F(\Omega) such that f1=f2subscriptğ‘“1subscriptğ‘“2f_{1}=f_{2} on Î©bsubscriptÎ©ğ‘\Omega_{b}. Therefore the functionals â„’Î»subscriptâ„’ğœ†\mathcal{L}_{\lambda} admit well-defined, bounded, and linearly independent restrictions on Hâ€‹(K,Î©b)ğ»ğ¾subscriptÎ©ğ‘H(K,\Omega_{b}) for every Î»â‰¥Î»0ğœ†subscriptğœ†0\lambda\geq\lambda_{0}. Let fâ‰¡cğ‘“ğ‘f\equiv c for câˆˆâ„ğ‘â„c\in\mathbb{R} be the constant function such that Yâ„’,m=â„’â€‹(f)subscriptğ‘Œâ„’ğ‘šâ„’ğ‘“Y_{\mathcal{L},m}=\mathcal{L}(f). Then

Yâ„’,mğ–³â€‹KÎ»â€‹(â„’,â„’)âˆ’1â€‹Yâ„’,m=â„’â€‹(f)ğ–³â€‹KÎ»â€‹(â„’,â„’)âˆ’1â€‹â„’â€‹(f)=â„’Î»â€‹(f)ğ–³â€‹Kâ€‹(â„’Î»,â„’Î»)âˆ’1â€‹â„’Î»â€‹(f)superscriptsubscriptğ‘Œâ„’ğ‘šğ–³subscriptğ¾ğœ†superscriptâ„’â„’1subscriptğ‘Œâ„’ğ‘šâ„’superscriptğ‘“ğ–³subscriptğ¾ğœ†superscriptâ„’â„’1â„’ğ‘“subscriptâ„’ğœ†superscriptğ‘“ğ–³ğ¾superscriptsubscriptâ„’ğœ†subscriptâ„’ğœ†1subscriptâ„’ğœ†ğ‘“Y_{\mathcal{L},m}^{\mathsf{T}}K_{\lambda}(\mathcal{L},\mathcal{L})^{-1}Y_{\mathcal{L},m}=\mathcal{L}(f)^{\mathsf{T}}K_{\lambda}(\mathcal{L},\mathcal{L})^{-1}\mathcal{L}(f)=\mathcal{L}_{\lambda}(f)^{\mathsf{T}}K(\mathcal{L}_{\lambda},\mathcal{L}_{\lambda})^{-1}\mathcal{L}_{\lambda}(f)

since f(â‹…/g(Î»))=ff(\cdot/g(\lambda))=f for constant functions. The assumption that fâˆˆHâ€‹(K,Î©b)ğ‘“ğ»ğ¾subscriptÎ©ğ‘f\in H(K,\Omega_{b}) and PropositionÂ 7.10 then imply that

supÎ»â‰¥Î»0Yâ„’,mğ–³â€‹KÎ»â€‹(â„’,â„’)âˆ’1â€‹Yâ„’,mâ‰¤âˆ¥fâˆ¥Hâ€‹(K,Î©b)2.subscriptsupremumğœ†subscriptğœ†0superscriptsubscriptğ‘Œâ„’ğ‘šğ–³subscriptğ¾ğœ†superscriptâ„’â„’1subscriptğ‘Œâ„’ğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ‘“ğ»ğ¾subscriptÎ©ğ‘2\sup_{\lambda\geq\lambda_{0}}Y_{\mathcal{L},m}^{\mathsf{T}}K_{\lambda}(\mathcal{L},\mathcal{L})^{-1}Y_{\mathcal{L},m}\leq\mathinner{\lVert f\rVert}_{H(K,\Omega_{b})}^{2}. (7.26)

By AssumptionÂ 5.1, the data-fit term Yâ„’,mğ–³â€‹KÎ»â€‹(â„’,â„’)âˆ’1â€‹Yâ„’,msuperscriptsubscriptğ‘Œâ„’ğ‘šğ–³subscriptğ¾ğœ†superscriptâ„’â„’1subscriptğ‘Œâ„’ğ‘šY_{\mathcal{L},m}^{\mathsf{T}}K_{\lambda}(\mathcal{L},\mathcal{L})^{-1}Y_{\mathcal{L},m} is continuous in Î»ğœ†\lambda (which can be proved similarly to LemmaÂ 7.1) and satisfies

lim supÎ»â†’0Yâ„’,mğ–³â€‹KÎ»â€‹(â„’,â„’)âˆ’1â€‹Yâ„’,mâ‰¤1Ïâ€‹âˆ¥Yâ„’,mâˆ¥2<âˆ,subscriptlimit-supremumâ†’ğœ†0superscriptsubscriptğ‘Œâ„’ğ‘šğ–³subscriptğ¾ğœ†superscriptâ„’â„’1subscriptğ‘Œâ„’ğ‘š1ğœŒsuperscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ‘Œâ„’ğ‘š2\limsup_{\lambda\to 0}Y_{\mathcal{L},m}^{\mathsf{T}}K_{\lambda}(\mathcal{L},\mathcal{L})^{-1}Y_{\mathcal{L},m}\leq\frac{1}{\rho}\mathinner{\lVert Y_{\mathcal{L},m}\rVert}^{2}<\infty,

where Ï=lim infÎ»â†’0eminâ€‹(KÎ»â€‹(â„’,â„’))>0ğœŒsubscriptlimit-infimumâ†’ğœ†0subscriptğ‘’minsubscriptğ¾ğœ†â„’â„’0\rho=\liminf_{\lambda\to 0}e_{\textup{min}}(K_{\lambda}(\mathcal{L},\mathcal{L}))>0. From this andÂ (7.26) it follows that there is aâ‰¥0ğ‘0a\geq 0 such that

0â‰¤Yâ„’,mğ–³â€‹KÎ»â€‹(â„’,â„’)âˆ’1â€‹Yâ„’,mâ‰¤a0superscriptsubscriptğ‘Œâ„’ğ‘šğ–³subscriptğ¾ğœ†superscriptâ„’â„’1subscriptğ‘Œâ„’ğ‘šğ‘0\leq Y_{\mathcal{L},m}^{\mathsf{T}}K_{\lambda}(\mathcal{L},\mathcal{L})^{-1}Y_{\mathcal{L},m}\leq a (7.27)

for all Î»>0ğœ†0\lambda>0, which is a generalisation of LemmaÂ 7.2. Finally, AssumptionÂ 5.1 implies that detKÎ»â€‹(â„’,â„’)â†’0â†’subscriptğ¾ğœ†â„’â„’0\det K_{\lambda}(\mathcal{L},\mathcal{L})\to 0 if and only if Î»â†’âˆâ†’ğœ†\lambda\to\infty since detKÎ»â€‹(â„’,â„’)subscriptğ¾ğœ†â„’â„’\det K_{\lambda}(\mathcal{L},\mathcal{L}) is a continuous function of Î»ğœ†\lambda and positive for every Î»>0ğœ†0\lambda>0 by positive-definiteness of KÎ»â€‹(â„’,â„’)=Kâ€‹(â„’Î»,â„’Î»)subscriptğ¾ğœ†â„’â„’ğ¾subscriptâ„’ğœ†subscriptâ„’ğœ†K_{\lambda}(\mathcal{L},\mathcal{L})=K(\mathcal{L}_{\lambda},\mathcal{L}_{\lambda}). We thus conclude fromÂ (7.27) that

â„“â€‹(Î»âˆ£Yâ„’)=Yâ„’,mğ–³â€‹KÎ»â€‹(â„’,â„’)âˆ’1â€‹Yâ„’,m+logâ€‹detKÎ»â€‹(â„’,â„’)â„“conditionalğœ†subscriptğ‘Œâ„’superscriptsubscriptğ‘Œâ„’ğ‘šğ–³subscriptğ¾ğœ†superscriptâ„’â„’1subscriptğ‘Œâ„’ğ‘šsubscriptğ¾ğœ†â„’â„’\ell(\lambda\mid Y_{\mathcal{L}})=Y_{\mathcal{L},m}^{\mathsf{T}}K_{\lambda}(\mathcal{L},\mathcal{L})^{-1}Y_{\mathcal{L},m}+\log\det K_{\lambda}(\mathcal{L},\mathcal{L})

is a sum two Î»ğœ†\lambda-continuous terms, the first of which is bounded while the second tends to negative infinity if and only if Î»â†’âˆâ†’ğœ†\lambda\to\infty. Therefore Î»MLâ€‹(â„’)=argâ€‹minÎ»>0â¡â„“â€‹(Î»âˆ£Yâ„’)=âˆsubscriptğœ†MLâ„’subscriptargminğœ†0â„“conditionalğœ†subscriptğ‘Œâ„’\lambda_{\textup{ML}(\mathcal{L})}=\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{\lambda>0}\ell(\lambda\mid Y_{\mathcal{L}})=\infty. Â 

7.9 Proof of TheoremÂ 5.3

See 5.3

ProofÂ  Because both the kernel KÎ¸subscriptğ¾ğœƒK_{\theta} and the covariates Xğ‘‹X have product forms, we may write the covariance matrix as

KÎ¸â€‹(X,X)=K1,Î»1â€‹(X1,X1)âŠ—â‹¯âŠ—Kd,Î»dâ€‹(Xd,Xd),subscriptğ¾ğœƒğ‘‹ğ‘‹tensor-productsubscriptğ¾1subscriptğœ†1subscriptğ‘‹1subscriptğ‘‹1â‹¯subscriptğ¾ğ‘‘subscriptğœ†ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘‘K_{\theta}(X,X)=K_{1,\lambda_{1}}(X_{1},X_{1})\otimes\cdots\otimes K_{d,\lambda_{d}}(X_{d},X_{d}),

where âŠ—tensor-product\otimes denotes the Kronecker product. We may assume that p=1ğ‘1p=1 without loss of generality. This means that we may write

Ym=Yâˆ’mâ€‹(X)=1n1âŠ—Ymâ€²,subscriptğ‘Œğ‘šğ‘Œğ‘šğ‘‹tensor-productsubscript1subscriptğ‘›1superscriptsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘šâ€²Y_{m}=Y-m(X)=1_{n_{1}}\otimes Y_{m}^{\prime},

where 1n1=(1,â€¦,1)âˆˆâ„n1subscript1subscriptğ‘›11â€¦1superscriptâ„subscriptğ‘›11_{n_{1}}=(1,\ldots,1)\in\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} and Ymâ€²âˆˆâ„nâ€²superscriptsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘šâ€²superscriptâ„superscriptğ‘›â€²Y_{m}^{\prime}\in\mathbb{R}^{n^{\prime}} for nâ€²=n2Ã—â‹¯Ã—ndsuperscriptğ‘›â€²subscriptğ‘›2â‹¯subscriptğ‘›ğ‘‘n^{\prime}=n_{2}\times\cdots\times n_{d} is a certain vector. Let A=K2,Î»2â€‹(X2,X2)âŠ—â‹¯âŠ—Kd,Î»dâ€‹(Xd,Xd)âˆˆâ„nâ€²Ã—nâ€²ğ´tensor-productsubscriptğ¾2subscriptğœ†2subscriptğ‘‹2subscriptğ‘‹2â‹¯subscriptğ¾ğ‘‘subscriptğœ†ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘‘superscriptâ„superscriptğ‘›â€²superscriptğ‘›â€²A=K_{2,\lambda_{2}}(X_{2},X_{2})\otimes\cdots\otimes K_{d,\lambda_{d}}(X_{d},X_{d})\in\mathbb{R}^{n^{\prime}\times n^{\prime}}. The properties of the Kronecker product yield

Ymğ–³â€‹KÎ¸â€‹(X,X)âˆ’1â€‹Ym=[1n1ğ–³â€‹K1,Î»1â€‹(X1,X1)âˆ’1â€‹1n1]Ã—[(Ymâ€²)ğ–³â€‹Aâˆ’1â€‹Ymâ€²]superscriptsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘šğ–³subscriptğ¾ğœƒsuperscriptğ‘‹ğ‘‹1subscriptğ‘Œğ‘šdelimited-[]superscriptsubscript1subscriptğ‘›1ğ–³subscriptğ¾1subscriptğœ†1superscriptsubscriptğ‘‹1subscriptğ‘‹11subscript1subscriptğ‘›1delimited-[]superscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘šâ€²ğ–³superscriptğ´1superscriptsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘šâ€²Y_{m}^{\mathsf{T}}K_{\theta}(X,X)^{-1}Y_{m}=\big{[}1_{n_{1}}^{\mathsf{T}}K_{1,\lambda_{1}}(X_{1},X_{1})^{-1}1_{n_{1}}\big{]}\times\big{[}(Y_{m}^{\prime})^{\mathsf{T}}A^{-1}Y_{m}^{\prime}\big{]}

and

detKÎ¸â€‹(X,X)=[detK1,Î»1â€‹(X1,X1)]nâ€²Ã—[detA]n1.subscriptğ¾ğœƒğ‘‹ğ‘‹superscriptdelimited-[]subscriptğ¾1subscriptğœ†1subscriptğ‘‹1subscriptğ‘‹1superscriptğ‘›â€²superscriptdelimited-[]ğ´subscriptğ‘›1\det K_{\theta}(X,X)=\big{[}\det K_{1,\lambda_{1}}(X_{1},X_{1})\big{]}^{n^{\prime}}\times[\det A]^{n_{1}}.

Because neither Ymâ€²superscriptsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘šâ€²Y_{m}^{\prime} nor Ağ´A depends on Î»1subscriptğœ†1\lambda_{1}, we may proceed as in the proof of TheoremÂ 2.3 to show that 1n1ğ–³â€‹K1,Î»1â€‹(X1,X1)âˆ’1â€‹1n1superscriptsubscript1subscriptğ‘›1ğ–³subscriptğ¾1subscriptğœ†1superscriptsubscriptğ‘‹1subscriptğ‘‹11subscript1subscriptğ‘›11_{n_{1}}^{\mathsf{T}}K_{1,\lambda_{1}}(X_{1},X_{1})^{-1}1_{n_{1}} is a bounded function of Î»1subscriptğœ†1\lambda_{1} while logâ€‹detK1,Î»1â€‹(X1,X1)subscriptğ¾1subscriptğœ†1subscriptğ‘‹1subscriptğ‘‹1\log\det K_{1,\lambda_{1}}(X_{1},X_{1}) tends to negative infinity as Î»1â†’âˆâ†’subscriptğœ†1\lambda_{1}\to\infty. Â 

7.10 Proof of TheoremÂ 5.4

Let d=1ğ‘‘1d=1 and Kâ€‹(x,y)=Î¦â€‹(xâˆ’y)ğ¾ğ‘¥ğ‘¦Î¦ğ‘¥ğ‘¦K(x,y)=\Phi(x-y) for an integrable function Î¦:â„â†’â„:Î¦â†’â„â„\Phi\colon\mathbb{R}\to\mathbb{R} that is infinitely differentiable in a neighbourhood of the origin. Define the diagonal matrix

Î”Î»=diagâ€‹(1,Î»âˆ’1,â€¦,Î»nâˆ’1)subscriptÎ”ğœ†diag1superscriptğœ†1â€¦superscriptğœ†ğ‘›1\Delta_{\lambda}=\mathrm{diag}(1,\lambda^{-1},\ldots,\lambda^{n-1})

and the Vandermonde matrix

Vâ€‹(X)=(1x1â‹¯x1nâˆ’1â‹®â‹®â‹±â‹®1xnâ‹¯xnnâˆ’1).ğ‘‰ğ‘‹matrix1subscriptğ‘¥1â‹¯superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥1ğ‘›1â‹®â‹®â‹±â‹®1subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›â‹¯superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›ğ‘›1V(X)=\begin{pmatrix}1&x_{1}&\cdots&x_{1}^{n-1}\\ \vdots&\vdots&\ddots&\vdots\\ 1&x_{n}&\cdots&x_{n}^{n-1}\end{pmatrix}.

It is a standard result in polynomial interpolation that the Vandermonde matrix is non-singular when xisubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x_{i} are distinct. Recall that Wğ‘ŠW is the Wronskian defined inÂ (5.11). The Wronskian is non-singular if the Fourier transform of Î¦Î¦\Phi is positiveÂ (Lee etÂ al., 2007, LemmaÂ 3.3). To see this, note first that

(âˆ’1)j(âˆ’i)i+jâˆ‚i+jâˆ‚viâ€‹âˆ‚wjK(v,w)|v=0w=0=(âˆ’i)i+jÎ¦(i+j)(0)=12â€‹Ï€âˆ«â„Î¾i+jÎ¦^(Î¾)dÎ¾(-1)^{j}(-\mathrm{i})^{i+j}\frac{\partial^{i+j}}{\partial v^{i}\partial w^{j}}K(v,w)\Bigl{|}_{\begin{subarray}{c}v=0\\ w=0\end{subarray}}=(-\mathrm{i})^{i+j}\Phi^{(i+j)}(0)=\frac{1}{2\pi}\int_{\mathbb{R}}\xi^{i+j}\widehat{\Phi}(\xi)\operatorname{d\!}\xi

and observe then that

âˆ‘i=0nâˆ’1âˆ‘j=0nâˆ’1aiâ€‹ajâ€‹Î¦(i+j)â€‹(0)=12â€‹Ï€â€‹âˆ«â„Î¦^â€‹(Î¾)â€‹(âˆ‘i=1naiâ€‹Î¾i)2â€‹dâ¡Î¾superscriptsubscriptğ‘–0ğ‘›1superscriptsubscriptğ‘—0ğ‘›1subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘—superscriptÎ¦ğ‘–ğ‘—012ğœ‹subscriptâ„^Î¦ğœ‰superscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›subscriptğ‘ğ‘–superscriptğœ‰ğ‘–2dğœ‰\sum_{i=0}^{n-1}\sum_{j=0}^{n-1}a_{i}a_{j}\Phi^{(i+j)}(0)=\frac{1}{2\pi}\int_{\mathbb{R}}\widehat{\Phi}(\xi)\Bigg{(}\sum_{i=1}^{n}a_{i}\xi^{i}\Bigg{)}^{2}\operatorname{d\!}\xi

is positive for any nâˆˆâ„•ğ‘›â„•n\in\mathbb{N} and any non-zero a=(a0,â€¦,anâˆ’1)âˆˆâ„nğ‘subscriptğ‘0â€¦subscriptğ‘ğ‘›1superscriptâ„ğ‘›a=(a_{0},\ldots,a_{n-1})\in\mathbb{R}^{n}. It follows from these equations that the Wronskian is non-singular because it can be written as a product of a positive-definite matrix with elements Î¦(i+j)â€‹(0)superscriptÎ¦ğ‘–ğ‘—0\Phi^{(i+j)}(0) and two non-singular diagonal matrices.

See 5.4

ProofÂ  We proceed as in the proof of EquationÂ 2.11 in SectionÂ 7.4 and conclude that to prove the claim it is sufficient to show that the limit limÎ»â†’âˆYmğ–³â€‹KÎ»â€‹(X,X)âˆ’1â€‹Ymsubscriptâ†’ğœ†superscriptsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘šğ–³subscriptğ¾ğœ†superscriptğ‘‹ğ‘‹1subscriptğ‘Œğ‘š\lim_{\lambda\to\infty}Y_{m}^{\mathsf{T}}K_{\lambda}(X,X)^{-1}Y_{m} exists and is finite. To prove that this is so we use EquationÂ (32) in BarthelmÃ© and Usevich (2021), which states that

KÎ»â€‹(X,X)=Vâ€‹(X)â€‹Î”Î»â€‹Wâ€‹Î”Î»â€‹Vâ€‹(X)ğ–³+Î»âˆ’nâ€‹[Vâ€‹(X)â€‹Î”Î»â€‹W1,Î»+W2,Î»â€‹Î”Î»â€‹Vâ€‹(X)ğ–³]+Î»âˆ’2â€‹nâ€‹W3,Î»,subscriptğ¾ğœ†ğ‘‹ğ‘‹ğ‘‰ğ‘‹subscriptÎ”ğœ†ğ‘ŠsubscriptÎ”ğœ†ğ‘‰superscriptğ‘‹ğ–³superscriptğœ†ğ‘›delimited-[]ğ‘‰ğ‘‹subscriptÎ”ğœ†subscriptğ‘Š1ğœ†subscriptğ‘Š2ğœ†subscriptÎ”ğœ†ğ‘‰superscriptğ‘‹ğ–³superscriptğœ†2ğ‘›subscriptğ‘Š3ğœ†K_{\lambda}(X,X)=V(X)\Delta_{\lambda}W\Delta_{\lambda}V(X)^{\mathsf{T}}+\lambda^{-n}\big{[}V(X)\Delta_{\lambda}W_{1,\lambda}+W_{2,\lambda}\Delta_{\lambda}V(X)^{\mathsf{T}}\big{]}+\lambda^{-2n}W_{3,\lambda},

where the matrices W1,Î»subscriptğ‘Š1ğœ†W_{1,\lambda}, W2,Î»subscriptğ‘Š2ğœ†W_{2,\lambda}, and W3,Î»subscriptğ‘Š3ğœ†W_{3,\lambda} are bounded as Î»â†’âˆâ†’ğœ†\lambda\to\infty. We may now use this equation to write

Ymğ–³â€‹KÎ»â€‹(X,X)âˆ’1â€‹Ym=Ymğ–³â€‹Vâ€‹(X)âˆ’ğ–³â€‹Î”Î»âˆ’1â€‹(W+AÎ»)âˆ’1â€‹Î”Î»âˆ’1â€‹Vâ€‹(X)âˆ’1â€‹Ym,superscriptsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘šğ–³subscriptğ¾ğœ†superscriptğ‘‹ğ‘‹1subscriptğ‘Œğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘šğ–³ğ‘‰superscriptğ‘‹ğ–³superscriptsubscriptÎ”ğœ†1superscriptğ‘Šsubscriptğ´ğœ†1superscriptsubscriptÎ”ğœ†1ğ‘‰superscriptğ‘‹1subscriptğ‘Œğ‘šY_{m}^{\mathsf{T}}K_{\lambda}(X,X)^{-1}Y_{m}=Y_{m}^{\mathsf{T}}V(X)^{-\mathsf{T}}\Delta_{\lambda}^{-1}(W+A_{\lambda})^{-1}\Delta_{\lambda}^{-1}V(X)^{-1}Y_{m}, (7.28)

where

AÎ»=Î»âˆ’nâ€‹[W1,Î»â€‹Vâ€‹(X)âˆ’ğ–³â€‹Î”Î»âˆ’1+Î”Î»âˆ’1â€‹Vâ€‹(X)âˆ’1â€‹W2,Î»]+Î»âˆ’2â€‹nâ€‹Î”Î»âˆ’1â€‹Vâ€‹(X)âˆ’1â€‹W3,Î»â€‹Vâ€‹(X)âˆ’ğ–³â€‹Î”Î»âˆ’1.subscriptğ´ğœ†superscriptğœ†ğ‘›delimited-[]subscriptğ‘Š1ğœ†ğ‘‰superscriptğ‘‹ğ–³superscriptsubscriptÎ”ğœ†1superscriptsubscriptÎ”ğœ†1ğ‘‰superscriptğ‘‹1subscriptğ‘Š2ğœ†superscriptğœ†2ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptÎ”ğœ†1ğ‘‰superscriptğ‘‹1subscriptğ‘Š3ğœ†ğ‘‰superscriptğ‘‹ğ–³superscriptsubscriptÎ”ğœ†1A_{\lambda}=\lambda^{-n}\big{[}W_{1,\lambda}V(X)^{-\mathsf{T}}\Delta_{\lambda}^{-1}+\Delta_{\lambda}^{-1}V(X)^{-1}W_{2,\lambda}\big{]}+\lambda^{-2n}\Delta_{\lambda}^{-1}V(X)^{-1}W_{3,\lambda}V(X)^{-\mathsf{T}}\Delta_{\lambda}^{-1}.

Since Î”Î»âˆ’1=ğ’ªâ€‹(Î»nâˆ’1)superscriptsubscriptÎ”ğœ†1ğ’ªsuperscriptğœ†ğ‘›1\Delta_{\lambda}^{-1}=\mathcal{O}(\lambda^{n-1}), we conclude that AÎ»=ğ’ªâ€‹(Î»âˆ’1)subscriptğ´ğœ†ğ’ªsuperscriptğœ†1A_{\lambda}=\mathcal{O}(\lambda^{-1}). Furthermore, from the assumption that Ym=(c,â€¦,c)subscriptğ‘Œğ‘šğ‘â€¦ğ‘Y_{m}=(c,\ldots,c) for some câˆˆâ„ğ‘â„c\in\mathbb{R} it follows that Vâ€‹(X)âˆ’1â€‹Ym=(c,0,â€¦,0)âˆˆâ„nğ‘‰superscriptğ‘‹1subscriptğ‘Œğ‘šğ‘0â€¦0superscriptâ„ğ‘›V(X)^{-1}Y_{m}=(c,0,\ldots,0)\in\mathbb{R}^{n}. Consequently, Î”Î»âˆ’1â€‹Vâ€‹(X)âˆ’1â€‹Ym=(c,0,â€¦,0)=D0superscriptsubscriptÎ”ğœ†1ğ‘‰superscriptğ‘‹1subscriptğ‘Œğ‘šğ‘0â€¦0subscriptğ·0\Delta_{\lambda}^{-1}V(X)^{-1}Y_{m}=(c,0,\ldots,0)=D_{0}. ThereforeÂ (7.28) yields

Ymğ–³â€‹KÎ»â€‹(X,X)âˆ’1â€‹Ym=D0ğ–³â€‹(W+AÎ»)âˆ’1â€‹D0â†’D0ğ–³â€‹Wâˆ’1â€‹D0<âˆÂ asÂ Î»â†’âˆ,formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘šğ–³subscriptğ¾ğœ†superscriptğ‘‹ğ‘‹1subscriptğ‘Œğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptğ·0ğ–³superscriptğ‘Šsubscriptğ´ğœ†1subscriptğ·0â†’superscriptsubscriptğ·0ğ–³superscriptğ‘Š1subscriptğ·0â†’Â asÂ ğœ†Y_{m}^{\mathsf{T}}K_{\lambda}(X,X)^{-1}Y_{m}=D_{0}^{\mathsf{T}}(W+A_{\lambda})^{-1}D_{0}\to D_{0}^{\mathsf{T}}W^{-1}D_{0}<\infty\quad\text{ as }\quad\lambda\to\infty,

where the Wronskian Wğ‘ŠW is, as noted earlier, non-singular. Â
